general_titles: COLLEGE OF ENGINEERING JUNIOR TRANSFER ADMISSION REQUIREMENTS
general_texts:
Admission to the UC Berkeley College of Engineering is highly competitive.


Application for junior transfer admissions to the Aerospace Engineering major will open in 2023-24 for admission in fall 2024. Applicants to the Aerospace Engineering major must complete all required core UCB preparation courses in order to be eligible for admission. Only applicants who have completed 100% of these required courses will be considered for admission. Required courses for admission to the major must be completed by the end of the spring semester prior to fall enrollment. A summer 2026 course is not considered to be "work in progress" for the fall 2026 selection process.


If a series of courses at a community college is required (e.g., Chemistry 101 + 102 + 103=Chemistry A and B), all the courses in the series must be completed, and must (unless otherwise indicated) be completed at the same community college. Partial completion (e.g., 2 of the 3 required courses) will result in zero credit toward the requirement(s), and the applicant will NOT be considered for admission. The only exception to the series rule is Math 54. If Math 54 is split into two different courses, one covering linear algebra and one covering differential equations, we strongly encourage applicants to take both courses at the same community college; however, the College of Engineering will accept linear algebra from one school and differential equations from a different school.


Lower division UC Berkeley courses required for graduation (but not admission) are also listed in the major agreements and are strongly recommended to be taken to strengthen one's application. The more of these courses completed, the stronger the application will be.


Required core courses for admission: (all these courses must be completed to be considered for admission)

- UCB MATH 51; 52; 53; 54

- UCB PHYSICS 7A; 7B

- One from UCB: ASTRON 7A; 10; BIOLOGY 1A/1AL; 1B; CHEM 1A/AL; 1B; 3A/3AL; 3B/3BL; MCELLBI 32; PHYSICS 7C

- UCB READING AND COMPOSITION A; B


Strongly recommended courses: (if your college offers the courses listed below and they are articulated, taking them will strengthen your application) If no articulation exists, students are strongly encouraged to take a course in SolidWorks and a course in Computer Programming.

- UCB ENGIN 7 or COMPSCI 61A

- UCB MAT SCI 45/45L

- UCB MEC ENG 40 or ENGIN 40

- UCB MEC ENG C85/CIV ENG C30


Admission is primarily based on the completeness of the applicant's lower division preparation and the level of academic achievement reflected in the student's grade point average. The UC applicant essay also plays an important role in the selection process at UC Berkeley. The College reviews the essay for evidence of interest in the student's chosen field and a thoughtful match between the academic program and the student's academic and career objectives.


The College of Engineering requires six humanities/social science courses, two of which must be reading and composition. The only non-technical admission requirement for the College of Engineering is the coursework equivalent to UC Berkeley's Reading and Compostion A and B, which must be taken for a letter grade. The College of Engineering does not recognize the Intersegmental General Education Transfer Curriculum (Cal-GETC/IGETC) and strongly discourages students from following this option due to the number of major-specific technical courses required for engineering transfer admission.


NOTE: The Reading and Compostion requirements cannot be satisfied by Cal-GETC/IGETC; applicants must complete the specific courses indicated as Reading and Composition A and B equivalents to be considered for admission. Failure to complete the exact courses listed will mean the applicant will NOT be considered for admission.


The remaining four humanities/social science requirement courses are not considered for admission purposes but are required for graduation. See http://engineering.berkeley.edu/hss for the College of Engineering humanities/social science breadth requirements and courses. Courses which are three semester units or more that appear in the following categories on the "General Education/Breadth" section of assist.org may be used to satisfy two of the remaining four humanities/social science course requirements for the College of Engineering. ARTS AND LITERATURE; HISTORICAL STUDIES; INTERNATIONAL STUDIES; PHILOSOPHY AND VALUES; SOCIAL AND BEHAVIORAL SCIENCES. Additionally, courses that teach a foreign language may be used to satisfy this requirement.


SAT/ACT/A-level test scores and letters of recommendation are NOT considered for admission.


NOTE: ALL REQUIRED COURSES AND ALL STRONGLY RECOMMENDED COURSES FOR THE MAJOR MUST BE TAKEN FOR A LETTER GRADE. FOR MORE INFORMATION, PLEASE CHECK THE COLLEGE'S WEB SITE FOR THE COLLEGE OF ENGINEERING UNDERGRADUATE GUIDE.


For more information:

http://engineering.berkeley.edu/admissions/undergraduate-admissions


College of Engineering Undergraduate Guide:

http://engineering.berkeley.edu/academics/undergraduate-guide


For more information on Aerospace Engineering:

http://www.aero.berkeley.edu


For more information on admission to UC Berkeley:

http://admissions.berkeley.edu


For more information on majors at UC Berkeley:

https://undergraduate.catalog.berkeley.edu/

Some Advanced Placement, International Baccalaureate, and A-Level exams can fulfill requirements in the College of Engineering. For details, please see https://engineering.berkeley.edu/students/undergraduate-guide/exams/.

COLLEGE ADMISSIONS REQUIREMENTS FOR TRANSFER STUDENTS 


THIS MAJOR IS OFFERED BY THE COLLEGE OF LETTERS AND SCIENCE (L&S)


IMPORTANT information for students applying for admission to L&S for the fall 2025 application cycle and beyond


Completion of Essential Skills requirements (Reading & Composition, Quantitative Reasoning, and Foreign Language) or

Cal-GETC/IGETC will no longer be a requirement for admission; however, completion of either is strongly recommended

prior to enrollment at UC Berkeley to ensure timely degree progress. More information on new polices is available on

the L&S Transfer Student Applicants website. 


By the end of the spring term preceding fall enrollment at Berkeley, you must complete: 


1) The 7-course pattern (as found in the UC Transfer Admission Eligibility Courses Menu in ASSIST):

·   Two transferable courses in English composition;

·   One transferable course in mathematical concepts and quantitative reasoning;

·   Four transferable college courses chosen from at least two of the following subject areas:

o arts and humanities

o social and behavioral sciences

o physical and biological sciences


AND


2) Major Requirements: 

Follow the guidance on preparation for this major below. 


For more information on L&S General Education requirements:


For information on courses that will satisfy L&S General Education (Essential Skills and

Seven-Course Breadth) requirements from your community college complete the following steps:

  1. Go to "Search below for articulation agreements: Major, department, and campus-specific general education agreements”
  2. Click on the down arrow to select: Academic Year, Institution: UC Berkeley, and Agreements with Other Institutions: (Your CA Community College). 
  3. Click on “View Agreements”.
  4. Under “View Agreement by” select “General Education/Breadth”. 
  5. Click on the “General Education/Breadth” radio button, then click on “View Agreement”


Learn more from the UC Berkeley Office of Undergraduate Admission and specifically about transfer admission preparation. 


Review all available majors at UC Berkeley.

Fall 2026 Admission for this Major:

Transfer students who select this major on their College of Letters and Science (L&S) application and are offered admission to L&S will be directly admitted into this major. If you are interested in this major, it is very important to select this major on your application, and complete as many lower-division major requirements as possible prior to transfer.

See details on preparation for this major below.


To prepare for the African American Studies major, complete introductory UC-transferable courses in subjects such as African American history, sociology, political science, economics, and literature.

If your course work has not been approved for articulation with the Berkeley requirements listed below, retain syllabi and reading lists for evaluation by the department.


For more information:

African American Studies

Undergraduate Advisor

(510) 642-8513


https://africam.berkeley.edu

Review all available majors at UC Berkeley.
AP and IB scores cannot be used to satisfy major requirements.

The group major in American Studies offers students the opportunity to study American society using a broad range of methods from a variety of disciplines in L&S and in the professional schools and colleges. Students who are interested in the American Studies major should:


- Review the "American Studies Student Handbook" available by mail or from the web site below.

- Meet with an adviser to plan your program as soon as you are accepted to UC Berkeley.

- Of the four lower division requirements (American Studies 10 plus three courses from the list below), only two need to be completed before applying to the major.

- Choose three courses from the list of acceptable courses (with no more than two courses from any one department).

- Other lower-division courses beyond those listed in section #2 may be approved on a case-to-case basis by an American Studies faculty advisor.



For more information:

Laura Spautz, Student Academic Advisor American Studies

(510) 642-9320

amerstd@berkeley.edu

https://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/

THIS MAJOR IS OFFERED BY THE COLLEGE OF LETTERS AND SCIENCE (L&S)


IMPORTANT information for students applying for admission to L&S for the fall 2025 application cycle and beyond


Completion of Essential Skills requirements (Reading & Composition, Quantitative Reasoning, and Foreign Language) or

Cal-GETC/IGETC will no longer be a requirement for admission; however, completion of either is strongly recommended

prior to enrollment at UC Berkeley to ensure timely degree progress. More information on new polices is available on

the L&S Transfer Student Applicants website. 


By the end of the spring term preceding fall enrollment at Berkeley, you must complete: 


1) The 7-course pattern (as found in the UC Transfer Admission Eligibility Courses Menu in ASSIST):

·   Two transferable courses in English composition;

·   One transferable course in mathematical concepts and quantitative reasoning;

·   Four transferable college courses chosen from at least two of the following subject areas:

o arts and humanities

o social and behavioral sciences

o physical and biological sciences


AND


2) Major Requirements: 

Follow the guidance on preparation for this major below. 


For more information on L&S General Education requirements:


For information on courses that will satisfy L&S General Education (Essential Skills and

Seven-Course Breadth) requirements from your community college complete the following steps:

  1. Go to "Search below for articulation agreements: Major, department, and campus-specific general education agreements”
  2. Click on the down arrow to select: Academic Year, Institution: UC Berkeley, and Agreements with Other Institutions: (Your CA Community College). 
  3. Click on “View Agreements”.
  4. Under “View Agreement by” select “General Education/Breadth”. 
  5. Click on the “General Education/Breadth” radio button, then click on “View Agreement”


Learn more from the UC Berkeley Office of Undergraduate Admission and specifically about transfer admission preparation. 


Review all available majors at UC Berkeley.

• Analytics is a high demand major.
  • Required lower-division courses:
  • Math 53, Math 54, Econ 1, 2 or 3C, and UGBA 10X must be completed prior to acceptance to the major and all must be taken for a letter grade.
  • Highly Recommend:
  • Engin 7, Comp Sci 61A, Data C8, and Data C88

• AP Math: Calculus AB with a score of 3 or higher (or AP Math: Calculus BC score of 3) will be accepted by the department for the Math 51 requirement at Berkeley. 
  • AP Math: Calculus BC score of 4 or 5 will be accepted by the major for the Math 52 requirement at Berkeley.

In the Analytics major, students will develop solid quantitative and data-driven problem solving skills through core courses in computing, probability/statistics, optimization, and data analytics, and will learn how to apply these skills in solving problems in an area of their choice. We outline four possible concentrations below, but many other areas can also benefit from deploying analytical methods. Students may design their own concentrations according to their interests, with guidance and approval from the Analytics faculty advisor in the Industrial Engineering and Operations Research (IEOR) Department.


Admission to Berkeley with the stated intent to major in Analytics does not guarantee acceptance into the major, a departmental application is required. Transfer students must apply to the Analytics major by the end of their first semester at UC Berkeley. Application information can be found at https://ieor.berkeley.edu/academics/ba-orms/


We do not accept applications from graduating seniors or students in their fourth (or later) year of studies, even if it is not the student's first major.


Prerequisite Coursework:

Prior to transferring to UC Berkeley, students are required to complete the following courses:


  • course equivalents of Math 51 & Math 52 (prerequisites to Math 53 and Math 54)


The department strongly recommends that the following courses are also completed prior to transferring to UC Berkeley. Any courses that are not completed prior to transfer must be completed by the end of the student's first term at UC Berkeley.


  • Math 53, Math 54, Econ 1, 2 or 3C, and UGBA 10X


All prerequisite courses must be taken for a letter grade. Transfer students must complete their prerequisite courses and apply to the major at the end of the first semester in which they are enrolled at UC Berkeley. UC Summer session prior to the academic year does not count as the first semester.


  • Engin 7, Comp Sci 61A, and Data C8 may be taken after acceptance to the major. Data C88 must be taken at Berkeley.


For more information:

Student Affairs Officer

Department of Operations Research and Industrial Engineering

(510) 642-5485

ieor-student-services@berkeley.edu

ORMS - UC Berkeley IEOR Department - Industrial Engineering & Operations Research

THIS MAJOR IS OFFERED BY THE COLLEGE OF LETTERS AND SCIENCE (L&S)


IMPORTANT information for students applying for admission to L&S for the fall 2025 application cycle and beyond


Completion of Essential Skills requirements (Reading & Composition, Quantitative Reasoning, and Foreign Language) or

Cal-GETC/IGETC will no longer be a requirement for admission; however, completion of either is strongly recommended

prior to enrollment at UC Berkeley to ensure timely degree progress. More information on new polices is available on

the L&S Transfer Student Applicants website. 


By the end of the spring term preceding fall enrollment at Berkeley, you must complete: 


1) The 7-course pattern (as found in the UC Transfer Admission Eligibility Courses Menu in ASSIST):

·   Two transferable courses in English composition;

·   One transferable course in mathematical concepts and quantitative reasoning;

·   Four transferable college courses chosen from at least two of the following subject areas:

o arts and humanities

o social and behavioral sciences

o physical and biological sciences


AND


2) Major Requirements: 

Follow the guidance on preparation for this major below. 


For more information on L&S General Education requirements:


For information on courses that will satisfy L&S General Education (Essential Skills and

Seven-Course Breadth) requirements from your community college complete the following steps:

  1. Go to "Search below for articulation agreements: Major, department, and campus-specific general education agreements”
  2. Click on the down arrow to select: Academic Year, Institution: UC Berkeley, and Agreements with Other Institutions: (Your CA Community College). 
  3. Click on “View Agreements”.
  4. Under “View Agreement by” select “General Education/Breadth”. 
  5. Click on the “General Education/Breadth” radio button, then click on “View Agreement”


Learn more from the UC Berkeley Office of Undergraduate Admission and specifically about transfer admission preparation. 


Review all available majors at UC Berkeley.

Preparing for the Ancient Greek and Roman Studies Major

Ancient Greek and Roman Studies (AGRS) is an interdisciplinary "area studies" major. It provides students with the opportunity to explore the rich diversity of Mediterranean antiquity in depth, alongside a relatively small cohort of undergraduates. While language study is an option, the major may be completed entirely in English. This major provides excellent preparation for various careers, including law, medicine, teaching, writing, and business, as well as for graduate study in fields such as Anthropology, Archaeology, History, and Art History.


Direct Admission

If you are admitted to UC Berkeley intending to major in Ancient Greek and Roman Studies, you will be directly admitted into the major. This means you do not need to apply or declare the major separately after admission.


To ensure a smooth transition and help you plan your coursework effectively, all admitted transfer students are required to meet with our undergraduate advisor shortly after admission. This meeting will help you develop a program plan to complete your major requirements and stay on track for graduation. You will receive information on how to schedule this meeting, either through Golden Bear Advising program or an email from the advisor, before the start of your first semester..

Lower Division Required Courses (Must be taken at UC Berkeley unless articulated)

Two of the following are required:   

  • AGRS 10A or AGRS 17A
  • AGRS 10B or AGRS 17B
  • AGRS R44 (may be substituted for either AGRS 10A/17A or AGRS 10B/17B, but not both.)

Important Note on Community College Credit:

Currently, there are no community college courses formally articulated through Assist.org that satisfy these specific

Berkeley lower-division requirements (AGRS 10A/17A, 10B/17B, R44).


However, if you have taken similar courses at your community college (sometimes referred to as Western Civilization

or similar broad surveys of Ancient Greece and Rome), they may be accepted to fulfill these requirements upon

departmental review and approval.


To request review for course articulation, please submit the course information and a course syllabus to our

undergraduate advisor (contact information is below).

Lower Division Elective (May potentially be fulfilled by transfer credit)

One lower division AGRS, GREEK or Latin course.

Important Note on Community College Credit:

If you have taken relevant courses at your community college that focus on Ancient Greece and Rome (in art history,

history, literature, etc.), they may be accepted to fulfill this elective requirement upon departmental review and

approval. Introductory Greek or Latin courses may also be eligible for articulation.


To request review for course articulation, please submit the course information and a course syllabus to our

undergraduate advisor (contact information is below).

 

Upper Division Required Course

One course from the AGRS 130 series. Must be taken at UCB in the Department of Ancient Greek and Roman Studies

Upper Division Electives

Five upper-division courses in AGRS (including upper-division Greek and Latin) or a closely related field; at least three of

these must be taken within the department.  

Notes:

  1. One of these five may be replaced by lower-division language study: Greek 1 + 2, Latin 1 + 2, or Greek or Latin 15.
  2. Any additional AGRS 130-series courses you take beyond the required one can be counted toward these upper-division electives.

 

Pre-Modern Culture Requirement (May potentially be fulfilled by transfer credit)

To broaden your perspective, you are required to complete one course (either lower- or upper-division) taken outside the

Ancient Greek and Roman Studies department. This course must focus on a pre-modern culture other than the Greco-Roman

world, although it can include cultures that overlapped with it (e.g., Ancient Egypt, Mesopotamia). Many departments across

campus offer courses that can fulfill this requirement (examples include courses in History, History of Art, and South and

Southeast Asian Studies, among others).


Important Note on Community College Credit:

This specific requirement may be fulfilled by completing a relevant course at a California Community College, subject to

departmental review and approval.


To request review for course articulation, please submit the course information and a course syllabus to our undergraduate

advisor (contact information is below).


Find Out More

The Berkeley Catalog and the department website provide more information about major requirements and course information.


Connect With Our Advisor!

We understand you may have questions as you plan your transfer! We encourage you to reach out if you have any questions

about the Ancient Greek and Roman Studies major at the University of California, Berkeley. Your key contact is our

Undergraduate Major Advisor (UMA):


Cassandra Dunn

Email: cassandrajj@berkeley.edu

Appointments: Schedule an appointment (in-person or remotely).

Department Website: https://dagrs.berkeley.edu/

general_texts:
This major is offered by the College of Environmental Design (CED).


The undergraduate program in Architecture leads to the Bachelor of Arts (BA) degree. Through its core courses, the program offers a broad introduction to the field of architecture, and through studies in the various areas it provides opportunities to prepare for specialization in the field in the areas of architectural design and representation, architectural technologies and building performance, architectural history, society and culture. In addition to offering a sound and well-rounded education, undergraduate studies can also provide pre-professional competency for entry-level employment in architecture, the option for graduate work in architecture, or further studies in a related environmental design field.


Many graduates go on to obtain Master of Architecture or related degrees; others work in architectural offices, construction, government, or industry. Employment opportunities exist also at the community level, particularly in those communities which traditionally have not been served by professional architectural practice. The overall aim of the undergraduate program is to establish a strong foundation for a diversity of careers and to provide for mobility and flexibility to suit changing individual opportunities.


Accreditation and Licensing. The BA degree is a pre-professional degree and provides the foundation for entry to a Master of Architecture program, the most widespread professional degree program in Architecture in the US. The BA degree can also be applied toward licensing requirements in the State of California. See the National Architectural Accrediting Board naab.org for more information on accreditation. See the California Architect’s Board cab.ca.gov and the National Council of Architectural Registration Board http://www.ncarb.org for more information on licensing.


MINIMUM ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS FOR ADMISSION


For information about admission to the Architecture major in the College of Environmental Design, see CED's prospective student website: http://ced.berkeley.edu/admissions/undergraduate/transfer-applicants/


-The personal insight questions section on the UC application is important in the selection process at Berkeley. The College reviews the personal insight questions for evidence of the student's interest in the chosen field and a thoughtful match between the academic program and the student's academic and career objectives.


-A minimum 3.0 overall UC transferable grade-point average is required for admission consideration.


-All courses required for admission, including breadth requirements, must be taken for a letter grade.


-For a competitive application, coursework should be completed by the end of the spring term that precedes fall enrollment at UC Berkeley.


-As a community college transfer applicant you must complete, at a minimum, course work identified on ASSIST.org as comparable to the following UC Berkeley courses:


LOWER-DIVISION MAJOR REQUIREMENTS

Environmental Design 1

Architecture 11A

Architecture 11B

Math 16A or 51

Physics 7A or 8A (this course will also fulfill CED's Physical Science breadth requirement)


Courses required for the Architecture major’s LOWER-DIVISION MAJOR REQUIREMENTS may also be used to complete the General Education requirement for admission, this includes CED Breadth or Cal-GETC/IGETC. For questions about Cal-GETC/IGETC certification, check with your community college counselor for more information.


GENERAL EDUCATION/BREADTH REQUIREMENTS


READING AND COMPOSITION (R&C)

Reading and Composition A

Reading and Composition B


SEVEN-COURSE BREADTH

Arts & Literature

Biological Science

Historical Studies

International Studies

Philosophy and Values

Physical Science (Physics 7A or 8A will also fulfill the lower-division major requirement)

Social and Behavioral Sciences


You must fulfill all of the required Lower-Division Major and General Education/Breadth Requirements outlined above to be considered for admission.


If you are using Cal-GETC/IGETC to fulfill CED's College Requirements, you must have full certification. Partial certification will not complete the requirements. Be sure to check with your community college about the procedures involved in certification of Cal-GETC/IGETC. The University will require the official certification by the July 1 deadline.


If you will not complete CaI-GETC/IGETC certification, you must follow exactly the articulation agreements between your school and the CED architecture major as described on this ASSIST.org website.


Regardless of how you complete the General Education/Breadth Requirements, you must also complete the Lower-Division Major Requirements with articulated courses outlined on ASSIST.org.


Highly recommended but not required: Knowledge of Adobe Suite and Rhinoceros.


For more information on applying to CED:

College of Environmental Design

Office of Undergraduate Advising

250 Bauer Wurster Hall

ced.berkeley.edu/ced/students/undergraduate-advising/

cedadvising@berkeley.edu


CED Prospective student website:

https://ced.berkeley.edu/admissions/undergraduate-admissions/transfer-eligibility-requirements 


For more information on admission to UC Berkeley:

https://admissions.berkeley.edu/


For more information on majors at UC Berkeley:

https://undergraduate.catalog.berkeley.edu/

All courses required for admission must be taken for a letter grade.


For a competitive application all requirements should be completed by the spring term that precedes fall enrollment. If your college does not offer courses articulated with ENV DES 1, you should find another school that does, or consider a plan to take the course in the summer that precedes fall enrollment at Berkeley. See the CED prospective student website for a list of colleges that offer articulated Environmental Design courses: https://ced.berkeley.edu/admissions/undergraduate-admissions/articulation.


Before applying, you may also wish to look into taking the mandatory Lower-Division Major Requirements at UC Berkeley during the summer (see http://summer.berkeley.edu) or via University Extension Concurrent Enrollment if class space is available (see https://extension.berkeley.edu/static/studentservices/concurrent/).


Some students are able to take one or more of the Lower-Division Major Requirements at UC Berkeley via the Intersegmental Cross-Enrollment program, which allows students who meet certain eligibility criteria AND are enrolled at a California community college to enroll in a maximum of one course per academic term at UC Berkeley on a space-available basis, paying community college fees. (See https://registrar.berkeley.edu/registration/visitor-and-exchange-programs/).


Finally, if it is impossible for you to attend a school that offers courses articulated with the mandatory Lower-Division Major Requirements, you may submit comparable courses for evaluation using the "Evaluation of Transfer Coursework: Prospective Students" form under Transfer Credit Evaluation & Curriculum Petition on this page: https://ced.berkeley.edu/advising/forms-documents

All courses required for admission, including General Education/Breadth requirements, must be taken for a letter grade.


Course work must be completed by the end of the spring term that precedes fall enrollment at Berkeley.


Students may use Advanced Placement (AP), A-Level Exams, and International Baccalaureate (IB) coursework to satisfy certain requirements. View our CED Advising website for more information on High School Exam Credit 


The College of Environmental Design (CED) will accept Cal-GETC/IGETC or Reading and Composition plus 7-Course Breadth to satisfy the General Education Requirements.


Cal-GETC/IGETC certification will fulfill some, but not all, of the lower division admissions requirements for the College of Environmental Design. Students must still complete all of the Lower-Division Major Requirements listed above.


IMPORTANT: Students applying to the College of Environmental Design should select breadth courses from the following lists with these caveats:


1. No more than two CED courses (Architecture, Landscape Architecture, Environmental Design, Urban Studies, and City and Regional Planning) may be used to fulfill CED's breadth requirements.


2. No more than two courses offered by the same department may be used towards the seven breadth requirements.


7 COURSE BREADTH REQUIREMENT


Take one course from each of the following seven areas:


ARTS AND LITERATURE: Courses that involve significant engagement with arts, literature, or language (excluding language instruction or the acquisition of technical skills), either through practical engagement with works of art or through the creation of art. (see approved course list below)


BIOLOGICAL SCIENCE: Courses in the biological sciences, with some cross-listings, as well as a selection of courses from related disciplines such as anthropology, nutritional sciences, and psychology. (see approved course list below)


HISTORICAL STUDIES: Most courses in the department of History, and other courses that deal primarily with the human events, institutions, and activities of the past. (see approved course list below)


INTERNATIONAL STUDIES: An in-depth exploration of political, cultural, artistic and/or socio-economic life centered on a country or region other than the United States and in the contemporary period. (see approved course list below)


PHILOSOPHY AND VALUES: Most courses in the department of Philosophy, plus courses with a major focus on religion, ethics, legal values, or leading philosophical figures. (see approved course list below)


PHYSICAL SCIENCE: Take one of the following: PHYSICS 7A or PHYSICS 8A. (see approved course list below)


SOCIAL AND BEHAVIORAL SCIENCES: Many courses in the departments of Economics, Legal Studies, Political Science, Sociology, Social Welfare, and many courses in anthropology, geography, and psychology. A variety of courses from other disciplines and some advanced language courses with a significant linguistic component are also acceptable. (see approved course list below)

COLLEGE ADMISSIONS REQUIREMENTS FOR TRANSFER STUDENTS 


THIS MAJOR IS OFFERED BY THE COLLEGE OF LETTERS AND SCIENCE (L&S)


IMPORTANT information for students applying for admission to L&S for the fall 2025 application cycle and beyond


Completion of Essential Skills requirements (Reading & Composition, Quantitative Reasoning, and Foreign Language) or

Cal-GETC/IGETC will no longer be a requirement for admission; however, completion of either is strongly recommended

prior to enrollment at UC Berkeley to ensure timely degree progress. More information on new polices is available on

the L&S Transfer Student Applicants website. 


By the end of the spring term preceding fall enrollment at Berkeley, you must complete: 


1) The 7-course pattern (as found in the UC Transfer Admission Eligibility Courses Menu in ASSIST):

·   Two transferable courses in English composition;

·   One transferable course in mathematical concepts and quantitative reasoning;

·   Four transferable college courses chosen from at least two of the following subject areas:

o arts and humanities

o social and behavioral sciences

o physical and biological sciences


AND


2) Major Requirements: 

Follow the guidance on preparation for this major below. 


For more information on L&S General Education requirements:


For information on courses that will satisfy L&S General Education (Essential Skills and

Seven-Course Breadth) requirements from your community college complete the following steps:

  1. Go to "Search below for articulation agreements: Major, department, and campus-specific general education agreements”
  2. Click on the down arrow to select: Academic Year, Institution: UC Berkeley, and Agreements with Other Institutions: (Your CA Community College). 
  3. Click on “View Agreements”.
  4. Under “View Agreement by” select “General Education/Breadth”. 
  5. Click on the “General Education/Breadth” radio button, then click on “View Agreement”


Learn more from the UC Berkeley Office of Undergraduate Admission and specifically about transfer admission preparation. 


Review all available majors at UC Berkeley.

• Art Practice is one of the University of California, Berkeley College of Letters and Science high demand majors where student demand exceeds teaching or facilities capacity. 


  • Required lower-division requirements:
  • Art 8  “ Introduction to Visual Thinking” must be taken at The University of California, Berkeley
  • Three lower division foundations courses from the following: Drawing, Painting, Sculpture, Ceramics, Video, Digital Photography, Printmaking, Performance, Social Practice. 
  • One lower division Art History requirement 


﻿For Junior Transfer Students, there are two pathways:

Transfer students can be directly admitted to the major upon acceptance into UC Berkeley, but must formally indicate the Art Practice major on their university application.


Undeclared (Discovery) transfer students can apply during their first semester at UC Berkeley but must already have: 

  • At least one undergraduate fine art studio class taken at community college
  • One Art History class taken at community college
  • Must be enrolled in ART 8 at UC Berkeley during their first semester (contact Student Services Advisor to confirm this)

Note that the first semester of your junior year is the very last semester you can apply to the Art Practice Major.
Exam credit is not accepted in lieu of required or recommended courses for this major.

• UC Berkeley’s Art Practice Department provides rigorous hands-on, conceptual, and critical studio art training within a world-renowned public research university. Students develop a cross-media understanding of fine art practices in a global context and gain valuable experience for a wide range of professional careers within contemporary art and culture. 2D, 3D, and time-based studio courses, research seminars, and professional development courses provide essential skills within conceptual and critical frameworks.


  • To learn more about University of California, Berkeley’s Art Practice program: 
  •   Art Practice Major


  • General contact information:
  • Location: Art Practice and Anthropology Building office #345
  • Major Advisor, Art Practice Department 
  • 510-643-9107

           Art Practice < University of California, Berkeley

Seven-Course Breadth) requirements from your community college complete the following steps:

  1. Go to "Search below for articulation agreements: Major, department, and campus-specific general education agreements”
  2. Click on the down arrow to select: Academic Year, Institution: UC Berkeley, and Agreements with Other Institutions: (Your CA Community College). 
  3. Click on “View Agreements”.
  4. Under “View Agreement by” select “General Education/Breadth”. 
  5. Click on the “General Education/Breadth” radio button, then click on “View Agreement”


Learn more from the UC Berkeley Office of Undergraduate Admission and specifically about transfer admission preparation. 


Review all available majors at UC Berkeley.

The Asian American and Asian Diaspora Studies Program offers a unified and comprehensive undergraduate curriculum that seeks to make at least three major contributions.


First, it prepares students for positions of service and leadership in Asian American communities. To do this, the program draws heavily on the curricula of such schools and departments as Education, Public Health, Law, and Sociology. The program itself offers instruction in those areas relating to the special needs of Asian American communities.


Second, the program explores the hitherto neglected aspects of the cultural, political, and historical experience of Asians in the United States, and prepares students for graduate work in their own and allied fields.


Third, the program broadens the curriculum at Berkeley to include instruction that reflects the conditions of Asians and other Third World people living in America.


For more information contact Major Advisors:


Dewey St. Germaine

(510) 643-6420

deweystg@berkeley.edu


Laura Jimenez-Olvera

(510) 642-0243

lauraj@berkeley.edu

The Department of Astronomy offers an undergraduate major and minor in Astrophysics. This program prepares students for astrophysics graduate work or other advanced degrees in related science and engineering fields. It also prepares students for careers in teaching or for working in data science, the tech industry, and other technical fields.


For more information:                                                 

Academic Advisor                                              

astroadvising@berkeley.edu                                           

https://astro.berkeley.edu

AP Calculus AB with a score of 3,4, or 5 for Math 51

AP Calculus BC with a score of 3 or 4 for Math 51

AP Calculus BC with a score of 5 for Math 51 and Math 52

ASTRONOMY 7A and 7B

ASTRON 7A and 7B are not required but are highly recommended for the major.


ASTRON 7A and ASTRON 7B requires students to use the laws of modern physics to describe and interpret astronomical phenomena.


If a course comparable to ASTRON 7A is not available, the department recommends that students take a course comparable to Berkeley's ASTRON 10 in order to gain some exposure to the material. However, ASTRON 10 is not required for the major.


Most community colleges do not offer an equivalent Introduction to Astrophysics course. Transfer students should take this course during their first semester at UC Berkeley or take ASTRON 7AB the summer before their incoming semester if it is offered.


PHYSICS 7A, 7B and 7C

This institution may cover the topics in Berkeley's Physics 7ABC series in a different order. Students who transfer before completing courses equivalent to the entire 7ABC series may need to enroll in Berkeley's PHYSICS 49 to complete missing topics such as wave motion (7A) or heat (7B).


COMPUTER PROGRAMMING

Those not familiar with a computer programming language are urged to include an introductory course in Computer Science. Python is the most recommended programming language to learn.

general_texts:
Admission to the UC Berkeley College of Engineering is highly competitive.


Applicants to the Bioengineering major must complete all required core UCB preparation courses in order to be eligible for admission. Only applicants who have completed 100% of these required courses will be considered for admission. Required courses for admission to the major must be completed by the end of the spring semester prior to fall enrollment. A summer 2026 course is not considered to be "work in progress" for the fall 2026 selection process.


If a series of courses at a community college is required (e.g., Chemistry 101 + 102 + 103=Chemistry A and B), all the courses in the series must be completed, and must (unless otherwise indicated) be completed at the same community college. Partial completion (e.g., 2 of the 3 required courses) will result in zero credit toward the requirement(s), and the applicant will NOT be considered for admission. The only exception to the series rule is Math 54. If Math 54 is split into two different courses, one covering linear algebra and one covering differential equations, we strongly encourage applicants to take both courses at the same community college; however, the College of Engineering will accept linear algebra from one school and differential equations from a different school.


Lower division UC Berkeley courses required for graduation (but not admission) are also listed in the major agreements and are strongly recommended to be taken to strengthen one's application. The more of these courses completed, the stronger the application will be.


Required core courses for admission: (all these courses must be completed to be considered for admission).

- UCB CHEM 1A/1AL; 3A/3AL

- UCB MATH 51; 52; 53; 54

- UCB PHYSICS 7A; 7B

- UCB READING AND COMPOSITION A; B


Strongly recommended courses: (if your college offers the courses listed below and they are articulated, taking them will strengthen your application) If no articulation, students are strongly encouraged to take a course in electronics or circuits AND a course in programming.

- UCB ENGIN 7 or COMPSCI 61A

- UCB EECS 16A

- UCB COMPSCI 61B

- UCB COMPSCI C8

- UCB MAT SCI 45/45L

- UCB COMPSCI 70


Articulation subject to completion of a university course

If the above statement is indicated under any of the community college course listed below, you will be required to take an additional course at UC Berkeley in order to complete the requirement.


Consult the Bioengineering website for which courses above would best match the sample track you wish to pursue. http://bioeng.berkeley.edu/undergrad


Admission is primarily based on the completeness of the applicant's lower division preparation and the level of academic achievement reflected in the student's grade point average. The UC applicant essay also plays an important role in the selection process at UC Berkeley. The College reviews the essay for evidence of interest in the student's chosen field and a thoughtful match between the academic program and the student's academic and career objectives.


The College of Engineering requires six humanities/social science courses, two of which must be reading and composition. The only non-technical admission requirement for the College of Engineering is the coursework equivalent to UC Berkeley's Reading and Composition A and B, which must be taken for a letter grade. The College of Engineering does not recognize the Intersegmental General Education Transfer Curriculum (Cal-GETC/IGETC) and strongly discourages students from following this option due to the number of major-specific technical courses required for engineering transfer admission.


NOTE: The Reading and Composition requirements cannot be satisfied by Cal-GETC/IGETC; applicants must complete the specific courses indicated as Reading and Composition A and B equivalents to be considered for admission. Failure to complete the exact courses listed will mean the applicant will NOT be considered for admission.


The remaining four humanities/social science requirement courses are not considered for admission purposes but are required for graduation. See http://engineering.berkeley.edu/hss for the College of Engineering humanities/social science breadth requirements and courses. Courses which are three semester units or more that appear in the following categories on the "General Education/Breadth" section of assist.org may be used to satisfy two of the remaining four humanities/social science course requirements for the College of Engineering. ARTS AND LITERATURE; HISTORICAL STUDIES; INTERNATIONAL STUDIES; PHILOSOPHY AND VALUES; SOCIAL AND BEHAVIORAL SCIENCES. Additionally, courses that teach a foreign language may be used to satisfy this requirement.


SAT/ACT/A-level test scores and letters of recommendation are NOT considered for admission.


NOTE: ALL REQUIRED COURSES AND ALL STRONGLY RECOMMENDED COURSES FOR THE MAJOR MUST BE TAKEN FOR A LETTER GRADE. FOR MORE INFORMATION, PLEASE CHECK THE COLLEGE'S WEB SITE FOR THE COLLEGE OF ENGINEERING UNDERGRADUATE GUIDE.


For more information:

http://engineering.berkeley.edu/admissions/undergraduate-admissions


College of Engineering Undergraduate Guide:

http://engineering.berkeley.edu/academics/undergraduate-guide


For more information on Bioengineering:

http://bioeng.berkeley.edu


For more information on admission to UC Berkeley:

http://admissions.berkeley.edu


For more information on majors at UC Berkeley:

https://undergraduate.catalog.berkeley.edu/

Some Advanced Placement, International Baccalaureate, and A-Level exams can fulfill requirements in the College of Engineering. For details, please see https://engineering.berkeley.edu/students/undergraduate-guide/exams/.

general_texts:
PRE-ADMISSION ADVISING 

For information on how to speak to a Haas advisor, please see: 

https://haas.berkeley.edu/undergrad/admissions/events-and-advising. 


ENVISION HAAS TRANSFER OUTREACH PROGRAM 

Envision Haas is an admissions outreach program aiming to provide admissions information to California Community College transfer applicants. Each Envision Haas session includes an admissions info session and transfer student panel. 


We encourage transfer students to attend a virtual Envision Haas session for more information about Haas and to get any questions answered. 

Please visit our website for dates and registration information: 

https://haas.berkeley.edu/undergrad/admissions/events-and-advising

To be considered for admission all prerequisites must be completed by the end of the Spring term prior to starting the Spieker Undergraduate Business Program at Berkeley Haas. Although you are not required to complete prerequisites at the time of application, the admission committee prefers to see as many prerequisites as possible completed by the end of the Fall term prior to starting at Berkeley Haas.

Admission to the Spieker Undergraduate Business Program at UC Berkeley's Haas School of Business is highly competitive. 


1) Complete all prerequisite courses (see below) with a letter grade of C- or higher no more than 5 years before starting the business major. Because the admissions process is highly competitive, strong candidates for the business major will earn significantly higher grades than this minimum standard. If you plan to begin Haas in Fall 2026, prerequisites taken before Fall 2021 must be repeated. 


2) Complete at least 60 UC-transferable semester units (90 quarter units) by the end of the Spring term prior to your anticipated start at Berkeley Haas. 


A Summer 2026 course is not considered "work in progress" for the Fall 2026 selection process. 


Haas does not accept the Intersegmental General Education Transfer Curriculum (IGETC) or the California General Education Transfer Curriculum (Cal-GETC).


Students should also visit https://haas.berkeley.edu/undergrad/admissions/application-process/transfer-students/ for additional information regarding the admissions process, selection criteria, use of exam credit (AP, IB and GCE A Level), and class profile.

Step 1: Submit the online UC Application: http://www.universityofcalifornia.edu/apply 


The online application is available August 1st. The deadline for filing is November 30. 

To be considered for admission to the business major, you must select the business major as your primary major. 


Step 2: Submit the required Haas Supplemental Application by January 30.

The application will be available on the MAP@Berkeley website in early January. The Supplemental Application includes the Haas Self Reported Academic Record, an additional essay, activities & awards update, and video interview. Information submitted in the self-reported academic record will be reviewed to confirm eligibility for the major. Students who fail to submit the Haas Supplemental Application or show planned satisfaction of all requirements will be considered ineligible for admission. 


Visit our Admissions page to learn about what we look for in applicants.


Final admission decisions will be available by May 1. 


HAAS 7-COURSE BREADTH REQUIREMENT - NOT REQUIRED FOR ADMISSION 

Units earned for prerequisites may not equal the 60 semester (90 quarter) unit minimum required to transfer. If you need to take additional courses to meet the unit requirement, consider taking breadth courses. Breadth is a degree requirement and breadth coursework is not required for admission. Visit our website for additional information about breadth requirements. Haas uses the College of Letters and Science (L&S) Breadth list with exceptions: 


Business courses cannot be used for breadth. 

Haas prerequisites cannot be used for breadth. 

Microeconomics or macroeconomics cannot be used for breadth. 


To access the breadth list, go to the home page of ASSIST.org. Select a community college from the drop down menu. After selecting a community college, select University of California, Berkeley from the Agreements with Other Institutions drop down menu. (You could have chosen the university campus first and the community college second.) Click on View Agreements. Next, under View Agreements by, select: General Education/Breadth. 


The agreement will display all general education and breadth requirements for the College of Letters & Science. Please ignore quantitative reasoning and foreign language as these requirements do not apply to Haas applicants. The Seven-Course Breadth list is displayed midway through the document. 


If there are UC transferable courses offered at your school that are not included on the breadth list, please contact your school's Articulation Officer. The Articulation Officer should submit the course(s) to UC Berkeley’s Articulation Officer for review. If approved, the course(s) will be added to the articulation agreement. 


For more information on admission to UC Berkeley: 

https://admissions.berkeley.edu 


For more information on majors at UC Berkeley: 

https://undergraduate.catalog.berkeley.edu/

Your academic path at Berkeley Haas will give you the knowledge and understanding of the business landscape and the tools to succeed within it. With our highly customizable degree program (B.S. Business Administration), you will be able to make your experience relevant to your interests and goals. Regardless of the career that you choose for yourself, you will learn the skills necessary to work as part of a team, solve problems, and make an impact.


For more information about the business major: https://haas.berkeley.edu/undergrad/

prior to enrollment at UC Berkeley to ensure timely degree progress. More information on new polices is available on

Review all available majors at UC Berkeley.

PREPARATION FOR TRANSFER AT THE JUNIOR LEVEL


The lower-division prerequisites for the Celtic Studies major are usually taken at UC Berkeley upon transfer. These include two semesters of lower-division language and Celtic Studies 70 "The World of the Celts."


The elementary and intermediate first-year language sequences are started during the student’s first Fall semester at Berkeley. The required 3-semester language sequence can be completed in the two years following admission. Celtic Studies 70 is also taken the first Fall semester.


Once admitted, students who have a prior background in their proposed target language (modern Irish or Welsh) may be required to take a language proficiency test or to consult with the department language program coordinator for placement in the correct language course level.


Prerequisites for this major are not offered at California community colleges; however, students may be admitted to the Celtic Studies major without the 3 prerequisites as it is possible to complete all requirements for this major upon admission to UC Berkeley.


Prerequisites include:

Two first-year language courses in either modern Irish (Celtic Studies 15 and 85) or modern Welsh (Celtic Studies 16 and 86) to be started during the student’s first Fall semester at Berkeley. The required 3-semester language sequence can be completed in the two years following admission.


Celtic Studies 70 (The World of the Celts) to be taken the first Fall semester at Berkeley.


Once admitted, students who have a prior knowledge of a Celtic language may be required to take a language proficiency test or consult with the department language program coordinator for placement in the correct language course level. Students with prior knowledge of a Celtic language may apply for credit by examination.

The major in Celtic Studies is designed to give students both a broad understanding of the place of Celtic languages and cultures in the world and a firm grounding in one or more of the Celtic languages with an innovative linkage of language and literature-in-translation courses intended to allow students maximum flexibility in pursuing their programs in addition to cultural studies courses in mythology, folklore, historical studies, and Medieval studies.


In addition to three semesters of language study, students will be required to organize their major coursework with reference to one other methodological or disciplinary area chosen from Anthropology, History, Comparative Literature, Linguistics, Medieval Studies, History, Scandinavian, or another related language, literature, or cultural studies course.


For more information on this major:

The Program in Celtic Studies

https://celtic.berkeley.edu/

Undergraduate Student Services Advisor

issaug@berkeley.edu

(510) 642-4661

The major in Chemical Biology is offered by the College of Chemistry.


The major provides an understanding of the chemical principles of biological function by emphasizing the development of a solid background in chemistry. In addition to an introductory set of math and physics courses and a broad selection of the same chemistry courses required for the chemistry major, students pursuing the chemical biology major take general and cell biology, biochemistry, biological macromolecular synthesis, and bioinorganic chemistry. The curriculum highlights organic chemistry, quantitative thermodynamics, and kinetics, subjects necessary for understanding the logic of biological systems. The Chemical Biology major is intended for students who are interested in careers as professional chemists, or in the biological sciences including the biomedical, biotechnology, and pharmaceutical industries.


Please note that Chemical Biology is distinct from Biochemistry. Biochemistry at UC Berkeley is an emphasis within the Molecular and Cell Biology major, housed in the College of Letters and Science. For a detailed understanding of distinctions between Chemical Biology and Molecular & Cell Biology, review and compare upper-division course requirements and descriptions for both majors. 


Transfer applicants are expected to complete, at a minimum, coursework

equivalent to Berkeley's:


CHEMISTRY 1A + 1AL + 1B + 3A + 3AL + 3B + 3BL               

MATH 51 + 52 + 53                             

PHYSICS 7A or 8A 

READING & COMPOSITION A + READING & COMPOSITION B

                        

Coursework must be completed by the end of the spring term that precedes fall enrollment at Berkeley.


IGETC/Cal-GETC is not required. Students who choose to complete the entire IGETC/Cal-GETC pattern by the end of the spring term preceding fall enrollment at Berkeley may use IGETC/Cal-GETC to fulfill the Reading and Composition and Language Other Than English (LOTE) Requirements.


Lower division courses required for graduation (but not for admission) are also listed in this articulation agreement. Completion of those courses is strongly recommended in order to strengthen one's application. All major courses must be taken for a letter grade. High grades in major courses (B and A grades exclusively) are essential for applicants to be both competitive in the admissions process and to be adequately prepared to continue with junior year coursework at Berkeley.


The applicant's personal insight questions (PIQs) are important in the admissions process. The PIQs are reviewed for evidence of the student's interest in the chosen field and a thoughtful match between the intended major and academic and career objectives.


For more information on College of Chemistry policies and degree programs: 

https://chemistry.berkeley.edu/ugrad/degrees


For more information on admission to UC Berkeley:         

https://admissions.berkeley.edu


For more information on majors at UC Berkeley:              

https://undergraduate.catalog.berkeley.edu/


Additional questions about transferring to the College of Chemistry may be

addressed to:

Jahzeel Flores Morales, Director of Undergraduate Student Services

jahzeel@berkeley.edu

(510) 643-0550

BIOLOGY                  

You may also satisfy this requirement with a score/grade of:        

4 or higher on the AP Biology exam. 


MATHEMATICS                

You may also satisfy this requirement with a score/grade of:        

3 or higher on the AP Calculus AB exam satisfies MATH 51;           

3 or 4 on the AP Calculus BC exam satisfies MATH 51;              

5 on the AP Calculus BC exam satisfies MATH 51 + 52. 


LANGUAGE OTHER THAN ENGLISH (LOTE) REQUIREMENT 

3 or better on the Foreign Language AP Exam


READING AND COMPOSITION REQUIREMENT

You may also satisfy this requirement with a score/grade of: 

4 or 5 on the AP exam in English Language and Composition satisfies READING & COMPOSITION A; 

4 on the AP exam in English Literature and Composition satisfies READING & COMPOSITION A; 

5 on the AP exam in English Literature and Composition satisfies READING & COMPOSITION A + READING & COMPOSITION B. 


See ADDITIONAL REQUIREMENTS section for additional options to satisfy requirements.

Chemical Biology majors who transfer without having covered analytical chemistry are required to take CHEM 105 after transfer. 


ORGANIC CHEMISTRY

CHEM 12A + 12B (organic chemistry) are required for the Chemical Biology B.S. degree. 


Completion of Chem 3A + 3AL + 3B + 3BL, with a mean grade of B or better, will constitute satisfactory completion of Berkeley's Chem 12A + 12B.

Students not meeting this requirement may be required to take Chem 12A and/or Chem 12B at Berkeley.


PHYSICS

PHYSICS 7C is not required for the Chemical Biology major, but it is acceptable toward the 7-Unit Upper Division Chemistry and Allied Subjects Requirement. 


READING AND COMPOSITION REQUIREMENT

Coursework equivalent to Berkeley's: READING & COMPOSITION A + READING & COMPOSITION B; or 

Entire IGETC/Cal-GETC pattern completed by the end of the spring term preceding fall enrollment at Berkeley.  


You may also satisfy this requirement with a score/grade of:

4 or 5 on the AP exam in English Language and Composition satisfies READING & COMPOSITION A;

4 on the AP exam in English Literature and Composition satisfies READING & COMPOSITION A; 

5 on the AP exam in English Literature and Composition satisfies READING & COMPOSITION A + READING & COMPOSITION B. 


LANGUAGE OTHER THAN ENGLISH (LOTE) REQUIREMENT 

The LOTE may be satisfied after transfer, but it should be satisfied by the end of the student's third (junior) year.  


To satisfy this Requirement:  


Complete a course equivalent to the third year of a language other than English in high school with a grade of C- or higher,

or the second semester of a language other than English as taught at Berkeley; or 


Complete the entire IGETC/Cal-GETC pattern by the end of the spring term preceding fall enrollment at Berkeley; or 


You may satisfy this Requirement with a score/grade of: 

550 on the SAT Subject Test, Language Other Than English, if taken before May 1995; 

590 on the SAT II Subject Exam, if taken May 1995 or later; 

3 or better on the Foreign Language AP Exam; 

C or better on the GCE A-level or I/GCSE O-level Exam in a language other than English; 

1-5 on the Foreign Service Institute (FSI) or Defense Language Institute (DLI) exam; 

5 or better on the International Baccalaureate in the following exams: 


Language (other than English) acquisition: 

B Standard Level (SL)

B Higher Level (HL)


Studies in language (other than English) and literature: 

  A: literature Standard Level (SL) 

  A: literature Higher Level (HL) 

  A: language and literature Standard Level (SL) 

  A: language and literature Higher Level (HL)  


OR  


Courses that satisfy Language Other Than English requirement - See list of approved (FL-Foreign Language) courses below.

(May be taken for a letter grade or pass/no pass.)

general_texts:
The major in Chemical Engineering is offered by the College of Chemistry.


It is designed to equip the student for professional work in development, design, and operation of chemical products and processes. It prepares the student for employment in such industries as chemical, petroleum, electrochemical, biochemical, semiconductor, nuclear, aerospace, plastics, food processing, environmental control, or related industries.


Transfer applicants are expected to complete, at a minimum, coursework equivalent to Berkeley's:


CHEMISTRY 1A + 1AL + 1B

MATH 51 + 52 + 53 + 54

PHYSICS 7A + 7B

READING & COMPOSITION A


Coursework must be completed by the end of the spring term preceding fall enrollment at Berkeley.


IGETC/Cal-GETC is not required. Students who choose to complete the entire IGETC/Cal-GETC pattern by the end of the spring term preceding fall enrollment at Berkeley may use IGETC/Cal-GETC to fulfill the Reading and Composition Requirement.


Lower division courses required for graduation (but not for admission) are also listed in this articulation agreement. Completion of those courses is strongly recommended in order to strengthen one's application. All major courses must be taken for a letter grade. High grades in major courses (B and A grades exclusively) are essential for applicants to be both competitive in the admissions process and to be adequately prepared to continue with junior year coursework at Berkeley.


The applicant's Personal Insight Questions (PIQs) are important in the admissions process. The PIQs are reviewed for evidence of the student's interest in the chosen field and a thoughtful match between the intended major and academic and career objectives.


For more information on College of Chemistry policies and degree programs:

https://chemistry.berkeley.edu/ugrad/degrees


For more information on admission to UC Berkeley:

https://admissions.berkeley.edu


For more information on majors at UC Berkeley:

https://undergraduate.catalog.berkeley.edu/


Additional questions about transferring to the College of Chemistry may be

addressed to:

Jahzeel Flores Morales, Director of Undergraduate Student Services

jahzeel@berkeley.edu

(510) 643-0550

BIOLOGY

You may also satisfy this requirement with a score/grade of:

4 or higher on the AP Biology exam satisfies BIOLOGY 1A & 1AL.


MATHEMATICS

You may also satisfy this requirement with a score/grade of:

3 or higher on the AP Calculus AB exam satisfies MATH 51;

3 or 4 on the AP Calculus BC exam satisfies MATH 51;

5 on the AP Calculus BC exam satisfies MATH 51 + 52.


READING AND COMPOSITION REQUIREMENT

You may also satisfy this requirement with a score/grade of:

4 or 5 on the AP exam in English Language and Composition satisfies READING & COMPOSITION A;

4 or 5 on the AP exam in English Literature and Composition satisfies READING & COMPOSITION A.


See ADDITIONAL REQUIREMENTS section for additional options to satisfy requirements.

BIOLOGY

Biology 1A (lecture only) is required for the Chemical Engineering B.S. degree.


You may also satisfy this requirement with a score/grade of:

4 or higher on the AP Biology exam satisfies BIOLOGY 1A & 1AL.


MATHEMATICS

You may also satisfy this requirement with a score/grade of:

3 or higher on the AP Calculus AB exam satisfies MATH 51;

3 or 4 on the AP Calculus BC exam satisfies MATH 51;

5 on the AP Calculus BC exam satisfies MATH 51 + 52.


ORGANIC CHEMISTRY WITH LABORATORY

CHEM 12A (organic chemistry) is required for the Chemical Engineering B.S. degree. CHEM 12B is not required for the Chemical Engineering major, but it is acceptable in satisfaction of the science elective for the open elective program.


Transfer students are encouraged to take the organic chemistry sequence at their institution.


Completion of Chem 3A + 3AL + 3B + 3BL, with a mean grade of B or better, will constitute satisfactory completion of Berkeley's Chem 12A + 12B.

Students not meeting this requirement may be required to take Chem 12A and/or Chem 12B at Berkeley.


PHYSICS 7C is not required for the Chemical Engineering major, but it is acceptable in satisfaction of the science elective for the open elective program.


READING AND COMPOSITION REQUIREMENT

Coursework equivalent to Berkeley's: Reading & Composition A; or entire IGETC/Cal-GETC pattern completed by the end of the spring term preceding fall enrollment at Berkeley.


NOTE: You may also satisfy this requirement with a score/grade of: 4 or 5 on the AP exam in either English Language and Composition or English Literature and Composition.

general_texts:
The Bachelor of Arts (B.A.) Degree in Chemistry is offered by the College of Letters and Science (L&S). The B.A. degree, which requires more humanities and social science courses than the B.S. degree, is intended for students interested in careers in teaching, medicine, or other sciences requiring a basic understanding of chemical processes.


IMPORTANT information for students applying for admission to L&S for the fall 2026 application cycle and beyond


Completion of Essential Skills requirements (Reading & Composition, Quantitative Reasoning, and Foreign Language) or Cal-GETC/IGETC will no longer be a requirement for admission; however, completion of either is strongly recommended prior to enrollment at UC Berkeley to ensure timely degree progress. For more information see the Prospective Student website for L&S: https://ls.berkeley.edu/prospective-students.

 

By the end of the spring term preceding fall enrollment at Berkeley, you must complete: 


1) The 7-course pattern  (as found in the UC Transfer Admission Eligibility Courses Menu in ASSIST):

  • Two transferable courses in English composition;
  • One transferable course in mathematical concepts and quantitative reasoning;
  • Four transferable college courses chosen from at least two of the following subject areas:
  • arts and humanities
  • social and behavioral sciences
  • physical and biological sciences


AND


2) Major Requirements: 

Follow the guidance on preparation for this major below. 


Transfer applicants are expected to complete, at a minimum, coursework equivalent to Berkeley's:

﻿

CHEMISTRY 1A + 1AL + 1B + 3A + 3AL + 3B + 3BL

MATH 51+ 52 + 53

PHYSICS 7A


The Bachelor of Science (B.S.) Degree in Chemistry is offered by the College of Chemistry. The B.S. degree is intended for students who are primarily interested in careers as professional chemists or desire a thorough grounding in chemistry in preparation for professional or graduate school in chemistry and other disciplines. In addition, there are two concentrations available to Chemistry majors: 1) the Materials Chemistry concentration, intended for students interested in the application of basic chemical principles to the discovery, design, and characterization of materials; and 2) the Computational Chemistry concentration, intended for students interested in the use of high-performance computing, rooted in basic physical and mathematical principles, to solve problems in modern chemistry.


Transfer applicants are expected to complete, at a minimum, coursework equivalent to Berkeley's:


CHEMISTRY 1A + 1AL + 1B + 3A + 3AL + 3B + 3BL

MATH 51+ 52 + 53

PHYSICS 7A

READING & COMPOSITION A + READING & COMPOSITION B


Coursework must be completed by the end of the spring term preceding fall enrollment at Berkeley.


IGETC/Cal-GETC is not required. Students who choose to complete the entire IGETC pattern by the end of the spring term preceding fall enrollment at Berkeley may use IGETC to fulfill the Reading and Composition and Language Other Than English (LOTE) Requirements. Students who choose to complete Cal-GETC may use this certification to fulfill the Reading and Composition requirement, however Cal-GETC will not satisfy Language Other than English (LOTE). It is highly recommended that students complete this requirement with directly articulated course work as noted under the Language Other Than English (LOTE) requirement -- See list of approved (FL-Foreign Language) courses below.


Lower division courses required for graduation (but not for admission) are also listed in this articulation agreement. Completion of those courses is strongly recommended in order to strengthen one's application. All major courses must be taken for a letter grade. High grades in major courses (B and A grades exclusively) are essential for applicants to be both competitive in the admissions process and to be adequately prepared to continue with junior year coursework at Berkeley.


The applicant's personal insight questions are important in the admissions process. The answers are reviewed for evidence of the student's interest in the chosen field and a thoughtful match between the intended major and academic and career objectives.


For more information on College of Chemistry policies and degree programs:

https://chemistry.berkeley.edu/ugrad/degrees


For more information on admission to UC Berkeley:

https://admissions.berkeley.edu


For more information on majors at UC Berkeley:

https://undergraduate.catalog.berkeley.edu/


Additional questions about transferring to the College of Chemistry may be

addressed to:

Jahzeel Flores Morales, Director of Undergraduate Student Services

jahzeel@berkeley.edu

(510) 643-0550

MATHEMATICS

3 or higher on the AP Calculus AB exam satisfies MATH 51;

3 or 4 on the AP Calculus BC exam satisfies MATH 51;

5 on the AP Calculus BC exam satisfies MATH 51 + 52


LANGUAGE OTHER THAN ENGLISH (LOTE) REQUIREMENT

3 or better on the Foreign Language AP Exam


READING AND COMPOSITION REQUIREMENT

4 or 5 on the AP exam in English Language and Composition satisfies Reading and Composition A;

Chemistry majors who transfer without having covered analytical chemistry are required to take CHEM 105 after transfer.


ORGANIC CHEMISTRY

Completion of Chem 3A + 3AL + 3B + 3BL, with a mean grade of B or better, will constitute satisfactory completion of Berkeley's Chem 12A + 12B.

Students not meeting this requirement may be required to take Chem 12A and/or Chem 12B at Berkeley.


MATHEMATICS

You may also satisfy this requirement with a score/grade of:

3 or higher on the AP Calculus AB exam satisfies MATH 51;

3 or 4 on the AP Calculus BC exam satisfies MATH 51;

5 on the AP Calculus BC exam satisfies MATH 51 + 52.


PHYSICS 7C is not required for the Chemistry major, but it is acceptable toward the 12-Unit Upper Division Chemistry and Allied Subjects Requirement for the Chemistry B.S. degree.


BACHELOR OF SCIENCE (B.S.) DEGREE IN CHEMISTRY

Information on satisfying the Reading and Composition and Language Other Than English (LOTE) requirements for the Bachelor of Science (B.S.) Degree in Chemistry is listed below.


READING AND COMPOSITION REQUIREMENT

Coursework equivalent to Berkeley's: Reading and Composition A + Reading and Compostion B or

NOTE: You may also satisfy this requirement with a score/grade of:

COLLEGE ADMISSIONS REQUIREMENTS FOR TRANSFER STUDENTS 


THIS MAJOR IS OFFERED BY THE COLLEGE OF LETTERS AND SCIENCE (L&S)


IMPORTANT information for students applying for admission to L&S for the fall 2025 application cycle and beyond


Completion of Essential Skills requirements (Reading & Composition, Quantitative Reasoning, and Foreign Language) or

Cal-GETC/IGETC will no longer be a requirement for admission; however, completion of either is strongly recommended

prior to enrollment at UC Berkeley to ensure timely degree progress. More information on new polices is available on

the L&S Transfer Student Applicants website. 


By the end of the spring term preceding fall enrollment at Berkeley, you must complete: 


1) The 7-course pattern (as found in the UC Transfer Admission Eligibility Courses Menu in ASSIST):

·   Two transferable courses in English composition;

·   One transferable course in mathematical concepts and quantitative reasoning;

·   Four transferable college courses chosen from at least two of the following subject areas:

o arts and humanities

o social and behavioral sciences

o physical and biological sciences


AND


2) Major Requirements: 

Follow the guidance on preparation for this major below. 


For more information on L&S General Education requirements:


For information on courses that will satisfy L&S General Education (Essential Skills and

Seven-Course Breadth) requirements from your community college complete the following steps:

  1. Go to "Search below for articulation agreements: Major, department, and campus-specific general education agreements”
  2. Click on the down arrow to select: Academic Year, Institution: UC Berkeley, and Agreements with Other Institutions: (Your CA Community College). 
  3. Click on “View Agreements”.
  4. Under “View Agreement by” select “General Education/Breadth”. 
  5. Click on the “General Education/Breadth” radio button, then click on “View Agreement”


Learn more from the UC Berkeley Office of Undergraduate Admission and specifically about transfer admission preparation. 


Review all available majors at UC Berkeley.

The Chicano Studies major offers an interdisciplinary curriculum of academic study that critically examines the historical and contemporary experiences of people of Mexican descent in the context of American society and institutions; and studies particular aspects of Mexican history, culture and politics as they bear upon the Chicano community, past and present. Emphasis is given to the student developing a broad knowledge of the Chicano experience. thus, the major stresses the analysis of the interrelationships in the historical background, cultural patterns and artistic expression of the Chicano community in order to acquire a well-rounded, in-depth understanding of the contemporary interface between Chicanos and American society. In this connection, the major strives to incorporate various disciplines in its approach, such as political science, sociology, anthropology, history, literary criticism and art. Through the interdisciplinary nature of our curriculum, the major is aimed at preparing students for incorporation into the world of work and for a wide range of advanced graduate work and/or professional training in various fields.


Please consult with the Chicano Studies adviser regarding the use of courses taken at your community college for credit toward the major. Generally, some UC-transferable courses taken at your community college can in fact be used to meet certain components of the major requirements.


For more information contact Major Advisors:


Dewey St. Germaine

(510) 643-6420

deweystg@berkeley.edu


Laura Jimenez-Olvera

(510) 642-0243

lauraj@berkeley.edu


https://ethnicstudies.berkeley.edu/

Seven-Course Breadth) requirements from your community college complete the following steps:

  1. Go to "Search below for articulation agreements: Major, department, and campus-specific general education agreements”
  2. Click on the down arrow to select: Academic Year, Institution: UC Berkeley, and Agreements with Other Institutions: (Your CA Community College). 
  3. Click on “View Agreements”.
  4. Under “View Agreement by” select “General Education/Breadth”. 
  5. Click on the “General Education/Breadth” radio button, then click on “View Agreement”


Learn more from the UC Berkeley Office of Undergraduate Admission and specifically about transfer admission preparation. 


Review all available majors at UC Berkeley.

PREPARATION FOR TRANSFER AT THE JUNIOR LEVEL


We encourage Students to take Chinese (Mandarin) language courses if they are offered at their college. Students will receive transfer credit for language courses taken at their community college. However, all UC Berkeley students must take a placement exam for Chinese to ensure enrollment in a course at the correct level for their language skills. Because language courses vary among colleges, a student may need to repeat an introductory or intermediate-level course if necessary. The department undergraduate advisor will work with students to create a program plan to complete their major requirements by their expected graduation date, regardless of which language course is their first. 


We also offer specific courses for students who are heritage learners. These courses are designated with an X or Y suffix. X is the equivalent of A, and Y is the equivalent of B; for example, the heritage course for the first semester introductory is CHINESE 1Y and it meets the exact requirement as does CHINESE 1A.


Please note: Advanced Placement (AP) and International Baccalaureate (IB) exams will not satisfy the requirements for this major.


Prerequisites

Students are required to successfully (grade C or higher) complete one Chinese Language course at UC Berkeley and Chinese 7A or 7B before declaring the major.


More Information

The Berkeley Catalog and the department website provide more information about major requirements and course information.


Advising:

Students with questions about transferring into the major in Chinese Language are encouraged to contact our undergraduate major advisor(UMA):

Cassandra Dunn

Department Website: http://ealc.berkeley.edu/

Email: cassandrajj@berkeley.edu

Appointments: Schedule an appointment (in-person or remotely).
