general_texts:
Admission to the UC Berkeley College of Engineering is highly competitive.


Applicants to the Civil Engineering major must complete all required core UCB preparation courses in order to be eligible for admission. Only applicants who have completed 100% of these required courses will be considered for admission. Required courses 6for admission to the major must be completed by the end of the spring semester prior to fall enrollment. A summer 2026 course is not considered to be "work in progress" for the fall 2026 selection process.


If a series of courses at a community college is required (e.g., Chemistry 101 + 102 + 103 = Chemistry A and B), all the courses in the series must be completed, and must (unless otherwise indicated) be completed at the same community college. Partial completion (e.g., 2 of the 3 required courses) will result in zero credit toward the requirement(s), and the applicant will NOT be considered for admission. The only exception to the series rule is Math 54. If Math 54 is split into two different courses, one covering linear algebra and one covering differential equations, we strongly encourage applicants to take both courses at the same community college; however, the College of Engineering will accept linear algebra from one school and differential equations from a different school.


Lower division UC Berkeley courses required for graduation (but not admission) are also listed in the major agreements and are strongly recommended to be taken to strengthen one's application. The more of these courses completed, the stronger the application will be


Required core courses for admission: (all these courses must be completed to be considered for admission)

- UCB CHEM 1A

- UCB CHEM 1B or BIOLOGY 1B or CIV ENG 70 or PHYSICS 7C

- UCB MATH 51 52; 53; 54

- UCB PHYSICS 7A; 7B

- UCB READING AND COMPOSITION A; B


Strongly recommended courses: (if your college offers the courses listed below and they are articulated, taking them will strengthen your application) If no articulation exists, students are strongly encouraged to take a course in Statics AND a course in Computer Programming.

- UCB CIV ENG 11; C30; 60; 93

- UCB ENGIN 7

- UCB MEC ENG 40 or ENGIN 40

- UCB COMPSCI C8


Admission is primarily based on the completeness of the applicant's lower division preparation and the level of academic achievement reflected in the student's grade point average. The UC applicant essay also plays an important role in the selection process at UC Berkeley. The College reviews the essay for evidence of interest in the student's chosen field and a thoughtful match between the academic program and the student's academic and career objectives.


The College of Engineering requires six humanities/social science courses, two of which must be reading and composition. The only non-technical admission requirement for the College of Engineering is the coursework equivalent to UC Berkeley's Reading and Composition A and B, which must be taken for a letter grade. The College of Engineering does not recognize the Intersegmental General Education Transfer Curriculum (Cal-GETC/IGETC) and strongly discourages students from following this option due to the number of major-specific technical courses required for engineering transfer admission.


NOTE: The Reading and Composition requirements cannot be satisfied by Cal-GETC/IGETC; applicants must complete the specific courses indicated as Reading and Composition A and B equivalents to be considered for admission. Failure to complete the exact courses listed will mean the applicant will NOT be considered for admission. The remaining four humanities/social science requirement courses are not considered for admission purposes but are required for graduation. See http://engineering.berkeley.edu/hss for the College of Engineering humanities/social science breadth requirements and courses. Courses which are three semester units or more that appear in the following categories on the "General Education/Breadth" section of assist.org may be used to satisfy two of the remaining four humanities/social science course requirements for the College of Engineering. ARTS AND LITERATURE; HISTORICAL STUDIES; INTERNATIONAL STUDIES; PHILOSOPHY AND VALUES; SOCIAL AND BEHAVIORAL SCIENCES. Additionally, courses that teach a foreign language may be used to satisfy this requirement.


SAT/ACT/A-level test scores and letters of recommendation are NOT considered for admission.


NOTE: ALL REQUIRED COURSES AND ALL STRONGLY RECOMMENDED COURSES FOR THE MAJOR MUST BE TAKEN FOR A LETTER GRADE. FOR MORE INFORMATION, PLEASE CHECK THE COLLEGE'S WEB SITE FOR THE COLLEGE OF ENGINEERING UNDERGRADUATE GUIDE.


For more information:

http://engineering.berkeley.edu/admissions/undergraduate-admissions


College of Engineering Undergraduate Guide:

http://engineering.berkeley.edu/academics/undergraduate-guide


For more information on Civil Engineering:

http://www.ce.berkeley.edu


For more information on admission to UC Berkeley:

http://admissions.berkeley.edu


For more information on majors at UC Berkeley:

https://undergraduate.catalog.berkeley.edu/

Some Advanced Placement, International Baccalaureate, and A-Level exams can fulfill requirements in the College of Engineering. For details, please see https://engineering.berkeley.edu/students/undergraduate-guide/exams/.

Transfer students who select this major on their College of Letters and Science (L&S) application and are offered admission to L&S will be directly admitted into this major.

If you are interested in this major, it is very important to select this major on your application, and complete as many lower-division major requirements as possible

prior to transfer. See details on preparation for this major below.


Major Prerequisites:


Students must complete three prerequisite courses: 


1. Calculus: can be completed with Math 51, Math 10A, or Math 16A, OR a 3 or above on the AP Calculus AB or the AP Calculus BC Exam. 


2. Statistical Thinking: Can be completed with Stat 2, Stat 20, OR Compsci/Info/Stat/Data C8, OR a 3 or above on the AP Stats exam. 


3. Computer Programming: Can be completed with ENGIN 7, DATA C88C, or COMPSCI 61A.


  • A score of 3 or above on the AP Calculus AB or the AP Calculus BC exam satisfies the requirement for MATH 51 or MATH 16A for Cognitive Science.
  • A 3 or above on the AP Stats test can fulfill the requirement labeled "Statistical Thinking" above.
  • A "C" or better is required in MATH 51, MATH 10A, MATH 16A, COMPSCI 61A, ENGIN 7, DATA C88C/COMPSCI C88C, COMPSCI/INFO/STAT C8, STAT 2, STAT 20.


Major Requirements:


  • Psych C61 OR Psych C64 fulfills the lower division Neuroscience requirement for the Cognitive Science Major. 
  • In lieu of MATH 55, this requirement can be satisfied by completing COMPSCI 70 Discrete Mathematics and Probability Theory at Berkeley.
  • Students have the option to fulfill the Philosophy requirement by taking one of the listed lower division classes (PHILOS 3, 12A, 25A, 25B or AGRS 36).


For more information:

MacKenzie Moore

Cognitive Science

140 Stephens Hall

mackenziemoore@berkeley.edu

cogsci.berkeley.edu

THIS MAJOR IS OFFERED BY THE COLLEGE OF LETTERS AND SCIENCE (L&S)


IMPORTANT information for students applying for admission to L&S for the fall 2025 application cycle and beyond


Completion of Essential Skills requirements (Reading & Composition, Quantitative Reasoning, and Foreign Language) or

Cal-GETC/IGETC will no longer be a requirement for admission; however, completion of either is strongly recommended

prior to enrollment at UC Berkeley to ensure timely degree progress. More information on new polices is available on

the L&S Transfer Student Applicants website. 


By the end of the spring term preceding fall enrollment at Berkeley, you must complete: 


1) The 7-course pattern (as found in the UC Transfer Admission Eligibility Courses Menu in ASSIST):

·   Two transferable courses in English composition;

·   One transferable course in mathematical concepts and quantitative reasoning;

·   Four transferable college courses chosen from at least two of the following subject areas:

o arts and humanities

o social and behavioral sciences

o physical and biological sciences


AND


2) Major Requirements: 

Follow the guidance on preparation for this major below. 


For more information on L&S General Education requirements:


For information on courses that will satisfy L&S General Education (Essential Skills and

Seven-Course Breadth) requirements from your community college complete the following steps:

  1. Go to "Search below for articulation agreements: Major, department, and campus-specific general education agreements”
  2. Click on the down arrow to select: Academic Year, Institution: UC Berkeley, and Agreements with Other Institutions: (Your CA Community College). 
  3. Click on “View Agreements”.
  4. Under “View Agreement by” select “General Education/Breadth”. 
  5. Click on the “General Education/Breadth” radio button, then click on “View Agreement”


Learn more from the UC Berkeley Office of Undergraduate Admission and specifically about transfer admission preparation. 


Review all available majors at UC Berkeley.

The department of Comparative Literature offers a wide variety of opportunities to explore and dive into the literary arts - literature, film, theater, music - across and within culture, time, language, genre, and theme. Comparative Literature majors take classes in our department and in other language/literature departments on campus.


Students of Comparative Literature: 

- develop their ability to read literary texts responsibly and critically, including through the lenses of culture, language, and context; 

- study one language literature in depth and another selectively; 

- acquire a broader sense of literary history and of literary traditions than the study of a single literature could furnish;

- explore the connections between writing and other pursuits; 

- acquaint themselves with some of the significant writings in theory of literature; 

- prepare themselves for the methodical investigation of issues involving more than one literature, language, and/or culture. 


Students interested in Comparative Literature must work in two languages and must complete language requirements prior to beginning study in another language. Second language work could be a second native or heritage language or a language studied prior to enrollment at Cal. It is possible to complete the degree in four semesters with only some prior language experience, however students should confirm language placement both with the Comparative Literature Undergraduate Major Advisor and with their intended language department. General language guidelines for Comparative Literature can be found here. 


This document describes the major requirements. Approved course lists are published every semester, including for summer sessions, and are published/cataloged on the right hand side of this page.


Comparative Literature undergraduates also have the opportunity to serve on the editorial board of the Comparative Literature Undergraduate Journal (CLUJ), a collection of literary analysis essays, and Vagabond, a multilingual literary magazine; and they can participate in organizing the entirely student-run Undergraduate Research Symposium.


PREPARATION FOR TRANSFER AT THE JUNIOR LEVEL 

Comparative Literature intended majors should have completed Reading and Composition coursework. Additionally, students must have or pursue adequate work in at least one secondary language, sufficient to qualify to take a minimum of two upper division literature courses in that language by the time of graduation.


For more information: 

Department of Comparative Literature 

(510)207-9698

COLLEGE ADMISSION REQUIREMENTS FOR TRANSFER STUDENTS 


THIS MAJOR IS OFFERED BY THE COLLEGE OF COMPUTING, DATA SCIENCE, AND SOCIETY (CDSS) 


Completion of Essential Skills requirements (Computational Reasoning, Human and Social Dynamics of Data

and Technology, Statistical Reasoning, and Reading and Composition) and Cal-GETC/IGETC are not a

requirement for admission; however, completion of both is strongly recommended prior to enrollment at

UC Berkeley to ensure timely degree progress. If course equivalencies are not available at your community college,

you must plan to take these courses at UC Berkeley.


To understand the CDSS College Requirements, including essential skills, visit:

https://cdss.berkeley.edu/academics/college-degree-requirements-and-policies#section-el-degree-requirements-1


By the end of the spring term preceding fall enrollment at Berkeley, you must complete: 


  1. The 7-course pattern (as found in the UC Transfer Admission Eligibility Courses Menu in ASSIST):
  2. Two transferable courses in English composition;
  3. One transferable course in mathematical concepts and quantitative reasoning;
  4. Four transferable college courses chosen from at least two of the following subject areas:
  5. arts and humanities
  6. social and behavioral sciences
  7. physical and biological sciences


AND 


All required courses as noted by your intended major below. 

Only applicants who have completed 100% of all items above will be considered for admission.

Additional completion of highly recommended courses will serve to strengthen the application. 


For more information on admission to UC Berkeley: 

https://admissions.berkeley.edu 


For specific information on transfer admission to UC Berkeley:

https://admissions.berkeley.edu/apply-to-berkeley/transfer-students/transfer-requirements/ 


For more information on majors at UC Berkeley: 

https://undergraduate.catalog.berkeley.edu/

Admission to the Computer Science major in the College of Computing, Data Science, and Society (CDSS) at UC Berkeley is highly competitive.

It is important that applicants choose a major carefully, as junior transfers will not be allowed to change their major to Computer Science after the application deadline.


At Berkeley, we construe computer science broadly to include the theory of computation, the design and analysis of algorithms, the architecture and logic design of

computers, programming languages, compilers, operating systems, scientific computation, computer graphics, databases, artificial intelligence and natural language

processing. Our goal is to prepare students both for a possible research career and long-term technical leadership in industry. We must therefore look beyond today's

technology and give students the big ideas and the learning skills that will prepare them to teach themselves about tomorrow's technology. 


Visit the following websites for more information: 

https://eecs.berkeley.edu/resources/undergrads/cs 


https://eecs.berkeley.edu/resources/undergrads/cs/transfer-prereqs/faq-4/


https://cdss.berkeley.edu/academics/undergraduate-education


General contact information: 

349 Soda Hall, UC Berkeley

cs-advising@cs.berkeley.edu 

(510) 664-4436

Required Courses for Admission


  • MATH 51, MATH 52


  • MATH 54 or EECS 16A or MATH 56 


  • Computer Science does not require full equivalence to Math 54 and will accept just the Linear Algebra course of an articulated Math 54-equivalent series.


Highly Recommended Courses for Admission


  • COMPSCI 61A, COMPSCI 61B, COMPSCI 61C 
  • If the community college course is followed by the note ‘Must complete an additional university course after transfer to satisfy this requirement,’ then, to fully complete this requirement, you will need to take the corresponding course (COMPSCI 47A, 47B, or 47C) at UC Berkeley after you enroll, in addition to completing the community college course.


  • Data structures--even if not officially comparable to Berkeley's COMPSCI 61B; and 


  • Java (preferred) or C++ 


  • COMPSCI 70 - COMPSCI 70 is offered during the Berkeley Summer session or Concurrent Enrollment.


  • The entire Computer Science 61 series is also offered during the Berkeley Summer session. The department recommends that, when possible, students take one of these courses during the summer session prior to transfer.

Acceptable exam credit:


  • MATH 51 (Calculus I) can be satisfied with at least a “3” on the AP AB or BC Calculus exam, at least a “5” on the IB Math Higher Level, or at least a "B" on A-Level Math 


  • MATH 52 (Calculus II) can be satisfied with a “5” on the AP BC Calculus exam or at least a "B" on A-Level Further Math

The Rausser College of Natural Resources (RCNR) admits students directly into one of its nine undergraduate majors as selected by the applicant at the time of application. Because Rausser College does not admit transfer students as undeclared, each individual major has a distinct set of transfer courses required as major preparation before the applicant is minimally eligible for admission.  


Resources for RCNR transfer applicants: 

  • UC Berkeley Office of Undergraduate Admissions Minimum Requirements for Transfer Admission
  • Rausser College of Natural Resources Transfer Applicants page - includes transfer admission guidelines specific to each Rausser College major, as well as additional information on how to submit a competitive application for your intended major 
  • Rausser College Major Requirements and Sample Degree Plans
  • Rausser College Advising Staff

ABOUT THE CONSERVATION & RESOURCE STUDIES MAJOR


The Conservation and Resource Studies (CRS) major is a self-designed interdisciplinary program for students interested in environmental issues and areas of interaction among natural resources, population, energy, technology, societal institutions, and cultural values. Students draw on the course offerings of the entire campus and appropriate community resources in the development of individual programs of study. The major’s orientation is toward flexibility and an individualized educational approach to understanding the structure and dynamic functions of complex environmental systems within our society and biosphere. It encourages interaction among students, faculty, and community. The major’s offerings are designed to help each student formulate an area of interest, but are not in any way meant to limit the range of options available.


For additional information, please contact the Conservation & Resource Studies advisor at crs.emf.ugrad@berkeley.edu.

Please Note: Applicants are expected to complete all required coursework by the end of the spring term prior to admission. Majors may allow one course pending in the summer term prior to admission if the major has more than five required courses and at least five courses of the required coursework have been completed; in this case, if a requirement includes both a lecture and lab, the lecture and lab together are treated as one course. Majors which require five or fewer required courses to transfer will not allow required coursework to be completed in the summer prior to admission. Please see the Rausser College of Natural Resources Transfer Applicants page for individual requirements by major.


Conservation & Resource Studies applicants have five or fewer required courses to complete prior to transfer and will not be allowed to complete a required course in the summer prior to admission.



To ensure full articulation of transfer coursework: if a series of courses at a community college is required (e.g., Chemistry 101 + 102 + 103 = CHEM 1A/1AL + CHEM 1B at UC Berkeley), all of the courses in the series must be completed, and must (unless otherwise indicated) be completed at the same community college. Partial completion of the series (e.g., two of the three required courses) may result in no credit toward the requirement(s), and splitting a series of courses between different community colleges is not guaranteed to satisfy the requirement. Courses taken out of series will be evaluated by college faculty during the transfer admissions process. If you have questions about the articulation of a series for your intended major, please email crs.emf.ugrad@berkeley.edu.


Minimum Admissions Requirements in Conservation & Resource Studies:


Equivalent of: 

  • READING & COMPOSITION A + READING & COMPOSTION B - satisfied by full UC IGETC, or may be satisfied with AP/IB/A-Level exam credit
  • BIOLOGY 1A or BIOLOGY 1B or BIOLOGY 11 - may be satisfied with AP/IB/A-Level exam credit
  • MATH 16A or MATH 51 or STAT 2 - may be satisfied with AP/IB/A-Level exam credit



Highly Recommended (but not required) Prior to Transfer

  • Transferable Social & Behavioral Sciences or International Studies breadth course - satisfied by full UC IGETC
  • Transferable Physical Science breadth course - satisfied by full UC IGETC
  • Transferable Arts & Literature, Historical Studies, or Philosophy & Values breadth course - satisfied by full UC IGETC
  • Geography, environmental biology or ecology, chemistry or physics for upper division preparation depending on Area of Interest, environmental justice/law/policy

Seven-Course Breadth) requirements from your community college complete the following steps:

  2. Click on the down arrow to select: Academic Year, Institution: UC Berkeley, and Agreements with Other Institutions: (Your CA Community College). 
  3. Click on “View Agreements”.

  5. Click on the “General Education/Breadth” radio button, then click on “View Agreement”

Review all available majors at UC Berkeley.

PREPARATION FOR TRANSFER AT THE JUNIOR LEVEL


No audition is required for admission into the College or the major.


No audition is required before enrolling in dance courses. Students with modern and contemporary dance technique training may begin dancing at an intermediate or advanced level.

It is recommended that Dance majors enroll in a technique course every semester.

The following lower division Dance and Performance Studies courses are required for the major:


  • 40 Beginning Modern Dance Technique or 14 Performance Workshop
  • 60 Introduction to Technical Theater and Production
  • 26 Introduction to Performance Studies
  • 52AC Dance in American Cultures or 25AC The Drama of American Cultures


NOTES:

  • A transferable modern dance technique course comparable to THEATER 40 may be used to satisfy a major requirement.
  • Once admitted to Berkeley, a student should arrange an individual advising session with the department to discuss the possible applicability of prior course work as well as future program planning.
  • Courses comparable to DANCE & PERFORMANCE STUDIES 25AC, 52AC, and 26 are generally not available at the community college and must be taken at Berkeley.
  • THEATER 25AC/52AC may not be fulfilled by any other American Cultures (AC) course.
  • AP and IB courses do not fulfill m AP and IB courses do not fulfill major prerequisites.

Within the Dance and Performance Studies curriculum, we engage with performance on physical, intellectual, and aesthetic levels. The practical focus of the program is on the performance and choreography of contemporary dance and dance theater. Of equal importance is the study of theater and dance theory, history, culture, and literature. The dance training and academic courses offered by our department are rigorous and geared toward the student who is interested in learning about dance and performance from multiple perspectives. As either a major or minor in Dance and Performance Studies, you will study with faculty known nationally and internationally for their scholarly research and creative work. Many of our graduates have careers in professional dance companies. Other students have gone on to graduate study in a wide variety of arts-related fields and have developed careers in universities, non-profits, and professional fields in health care, education, and business.


The opportunities in our department are many and varied. They include regular student-led performances, an annual dance concert where students perform in faculty and guest artist repertory pieces, the option to participate in an honors thesis/project, and exposure to a diverse range of exciting lectures, speakers, guest artists, and performances.


For more information:

Laxmi Kumaran

Undergraduate Academic Advisor

Department of Theater, Dance, and Performance Studies

15-B Dwinelle Hall (Level C)

laxmk@berkeley.edu

tdps.berkeley.edu

and Technology, Statistical Reasoning, and Reading and Composition) and Cal-GETC/IGETC are not a

  1. The 7-course pattern (as found in the UC Transfer Admission Eligibility Courses Menu in ASSIST):

  4. Four transferable college courses chosen from at least two of the following subject areas:
  5. arts and humanities
  6. social and behavioral sciences
  7. physical and biological sciences


AND

Only applicants who have completed 100% of all items above will be considered for admission.

Additional completion of highly recommended courses will serve to strengthen the application. 


For more information on admission to UC Berkeley: 

https://admissions.berkeley.edu 


For specific information on transfer admission to UC Berkeley:

https://admissions.berkeley.edu/apply-to-berkeley/transfer-students/transfer-requirements/ 


For more information on majors at UC Berkeley: 

https://undergraduate.catalog.berkeley.edu/

Acceptable exam credit:


  • AP/IB exam scores are only accepted for lower division math requirements for the Data Science major in accordance with Math Department guidelines. 

﻿

  • Data Science does not accept exam credit to meet any other lower division requirements (ie lower division Domain Emphasis)

DATA SCIENCE is a new field of study that combines computational and inferential reasoning to draw conclusions based

on data about some aspect of the real world. Data scientists come from all walks of life, all areas of study, and all

backgrounds. They share an appreciation for the practical use of mathematical and scientific thinking and the power of

computing to understand and solve problems for business, research, and societal impact. 


The Data Science Major will equip students to draw sound conclusions from data in context, using knowledge of

statistical inference, computational processes, data management strategies, domain knowledge, and theory. Students

will learn to carry out analyses of data through the full cycle of the investigative process in scientific and practical

contexts. Students will gain understanding of the human and ethical implications of data analysis and integrate that

knowledge in designing and carrying out their work. 


We strongly encourage you to visit our website for prospective transfer students (link listed below) to learn more about

preparing for a major in Data Science at UC Berkeley. Also, please reach out to us via the email address below if you have

﻿specific questions about your academic path into data science. 


﻿For more information on this major: 

ds-advising@berkeley.edu 

https://data.berkeley.edu/information-prospective-transfer-students

All coursework towards the major must be taken for a grade.


Required for the Major and for Admission to the Major

  • MATH 51 & 52 - Calculus I & II 
  • MATH 56 - Linear Algebra -or- MATH 54 - Linear Algebra and Differential Equations 

Data Science does not require full equivalence to Math 54 and will accept just the Linear Algebra

course of an articulated Math 54-equivalent series.


Required for the Major and Highly Recommended to be completed prior to Admission

  • ﻿DATA/COMPSCI/INFO/STAT/C8 - Foundations of Data Science 
  • COMPSCI 61A - The Structure and Interpretation of Computer Programs (preferred) -or- ENGIN 7 - Introduction to Computer Programming for Scientists and Engineers 
  • COMPSCI 61B - Data Structures 

If you see "Must complete an additional university course after transfer to satisfy this requirement" below the community college course, then in addition to completing the community college course,

you must complete COMPSCI 47B after enrollment at UC Berkeley. 


Data C8 and COMPSCI 61A are found at only a few California community colleges. Please visit this page to see the specific community colleges offering equivalents to Data C8 and COMPSCI 61A.

Data Science transfer students are expected to enroll in these classes during their first semester at Berkeley if not completed prior to transfer.


Not Required for the Major but Highly Recommended

  • MATH 53 - Calculus III
  • If you can’t complete all of the courses listed above, completion of additional courses in computer science/programming (especially Python), statistics and mathematics can strengthen your application.

PREPARATION FOR TRANSFER AT THEJUNIOR LEVEL


The Dutch Studies student is admitted to the major after having satisfied the language requirement (two semesters of college level Dutch -- Dutch 1 and Dutch 2, or comparable courses).

This can be done either by taking the elementary language courses or by passing a proficiency exam. Because the program is both specialized and broad, using a many-sided approach

to the subject, it is recommended that students have a strong preparation in a related discipline, so that the group major in Dutch Studies may constitute the focal point to a larger area of

interest. Suggested related fields of concentration are Comparative Literature, German, Spanish and Portuguese, History, History of Art, African-American Studies, Linguistics, South and

Southeast Asian Studies. We encourage Dutch Studies students to do part of their study in the Netherlands or Flanders and to make use of the existing exchange programs with Dutch

universities or grants for Dutch language summer courses.


AP or IB do not satisfy any major requirements.

The group major in Dutch Studies is designed to present a balanced curriculum of the language, literature, history and culture of the Netherlands,

the Dutch-speaking part of Belgium (Flanders), the Dutch-speaking Caribbean and former colonies of the Netherlands and Belgium in the Americas,

Asia and Africa. Classes are relatively small, facilitating interaction among students and instructor.


For more information:

Dutch Studies Program

Maxwell Moloney

(510) 642-7445

fax: (510) 642-3243

germanua@berkeley.edu

Transfer students who select this major on their College of Letters and Science (L&S) application and are offered admission to L&S will be directly admitted into this major. If you are interested in this major, it is very important to select this major on your application, and complete as many lower-division major requirements as possible prior to transfer. See details on preparation for this major below.


The Department of Earth and Planetary Science (EPS) offers six undergraduate specializations leading to a B.A. degree in one of the following specializations :

- Atmospheric Science;

- Environmental Earth Science;

- Geology;

- Geophysics;

- Marine Science; and

- Planetary Science.


The degree provides quantitative studies of the earth and is an excellent program toward further studies in graduate school or for active roles in environmental decision making, teaching in high schools, and for job opportunities requiring a basic understanding of natural sciences.


All specializations require Chemistry 1A & 1AL and EPS 50


Atmospheric Science, Geophysics, and Planetary Science:

  • Math 51
  • Math 52
  • Math 53
  • Math 54
  • Physics 7A
  • Physics 7B
  • Physics 7C


Geology:

  • Math 51
  • Math 52
  • Physics 7A
  • Physics 7B


Marine Science:

  • Math 51 or Math 16A or Math 10A
  • Math 52 or Math 16B or Math 10B
  • Biology 1B
  • Physics 8A or 7A
  • Physics 8B or 7B
  • EPS 82


Environmental Earth Science:

  • Math 51 or Math 16A or Math 10A
  • Math 52 or Math 16B or Math 10B
  • Biology 1B
  • Physics 8A or 7A
  • Physics 8B or 7B


For more information:

Anna Atkinson, Undergraduate Major Advisor

Department of Earth and Planetary Science

epsua@berkeley.edu

https://eps.berkeley.edu

The Department of Earth and Planetary Science accepts the following AP/IB exam scores and A-Level grades as course equivalencies for EPS specializations:


AP Calc AB – score of 3, 4, 5 for Math 51

AP Calc BC – score of 3 or 4 for Math 51; score of 5 for Math 52

AP Chem – score of 3, 4 or 5 meets Chem 1A and 1AL; 4 or 5 meets Chem 3A

AP Bio – score of 4 or 5 for Biology 1A and 1B

IB Math Higher Level (grades 5, 6 or 7) - Math 51 Equivalency

A-Level Math (grade of "B" or better - Math 51 Equivalency

A-Level Further Math (grade of "B" or better) - Math 51 & Math 52 Equivalency


Please note that each college/department may have different score requirements.

COLLEGE ADMISSIONS REQUIREMENTS FOR TRANSFER STUDENTS 


THIS MAJOR IS OFFERED BY THE COLLEGE OF LETTERS AND SCIENCE (L&S)


IMPORTANT information for students applying for admission to L&S for the fall 2025 application cycle and beyond


Completion of Essential Skills requirements (Reading & Composition, Quantitative Reasoning, and Foreign Language) or

Cal-GETC/IGETC will no longer be a requirement for admission; however, completion of either is strongly recommended

prior to enrollment at UC Berkeley to ensure timely degree progress. More information on new polices is available on

the L&S Transfer Student Applicants website. 


By the end of the spring term preceding fall enrollment at Berkeley, you must complete: 


1) The 7-course pattern (as found in the UC Transfer Admission Eligibility Courses Menu in ASSIST):

·   Two transferable courses in English composition;

·   One transferable course in mathematical concepts and quantitative reasoning;

·   Four transferable college courses chosen from at least two of the following subject areas:

o arts and humanities

o social and behavioral sciences

o physical and biological sciences


AND


2) Major Requirements: 

Follow the guidance on preparation for this major below. 


For more information on L&S General Education requirements:


For information on courses that will satisfy L&S General Education (Essential Skills and

Seven-Course Breadth) requirements from your community college complete the following steps:

  1. Go to "Search below for articulation agreements: Major, department, and campus-specific general education agreements”
  2. Click on the down arrow to select: Academic Year, Institution: UC Berkeley, and Agreements with Other Institutions: (Your CA Community College). 
  3. Click on “View Agreements”.
  4. Under “View Agreement by” select “General Education/Breadth”. 
  5. Click on the “General Education/Breadth” radio button, then click on “View Agreement”


Learn more from the UC Berkeley Office of Undergraduate Admission and specifically about transfer admission preparation. 


Review all available majors at UC Berkeley.

East Asian Humanities Major Articulation Information



The East Asian Humanities major is a comparative study of East Asian cultures. The curriculum seeks to prepare students for cross-regional comparative work, emphasizing cultural and literary analysis, media studies, and interdisciplinary humanities.


The major offers a high degree of flexibility, allowing students to draw coursework from two or more national traditions in East Asia (China, Japan, and South Korea, among others) and covering both the modern and classical periods. Students must complete 8 courses (or 40 units), and while we recommend acquiring a reading knowledge of at least one foreign language, the major can be entirely completed through English-taught courses.


Coursework for requirements can be completed upon transfer to UC Berkeley. Students intending the major should enroll in at least one of the following classes in their first semester, along with upper-division courses from the list provided on our website or the Berkeley Catalog.


  • BUDDSTD/EALANG C 50 Introduction to Buddhism
  • Chinese 7A Introduction to Modern Chinese Literature and Culture
  • Chinese 7B Introduction to Pre-modern Chinese Literature and Culture
  • Japanese 7A Introduction to Modern Japanese Literature and Culture
  • Japanese 7B Introduction to Modern Pre-modern Literature and Culture
  • Korean 7A Introduction to Modern Korean Literature and Culture
  • Korean 7B Introduction to Pre-modern Chinese Literature and Culture


Advising:

Students with questions about transferring into the major in East Asian Humanities are encouraged to contact our undergraduate major advisor(UMA):

Cassandra Dunn

Department Website: http://ealc.berkeley.edu/

Email: cassandrajj@berkeley.edu

Appointments: Schedule an appointment (in-person or remotely).

  1. Go to "Search below for articulation agreements: Major, department, and campus-specific general education agreements”

  3. Click on “View Agreements”.
  4. Under “View Agreement by” select “General Education/Breadth”. 
  5. Click on the “General Education/Breadth” radio button, then click on “View Agreement”


Learn more from the UC Berkeley Office of Undergraduate Admission and specifically about transfer admission preparation. 


Review all available majors at UC Berkeley.

PREPARATION FOR TRANSFER AT THE JUNIOR LEVEL


Courses related to East Asian philosophy, religion, and culture are recommended and may be transferable for credit toward major requirements upon consultation with the undergraduate major advisor (UMA).


We encourage Students to take Chinese, Japanese, or Tibetan language courses if they are offered at their college. Students will receive transfer credit for language courses taken at their community college. However, all UC Berkeley students must take a placement exam for Chinese or Japanese (there are no placement exams for Tibetan) to ensure enrollment in a course at the correct level for their language skills. Because language courses vary among colleges, a student may need to repeat an introductory or intermediate-level course if necessary. The department undergraduate advisor will work with students to create a program plan to complete their major requirements by their expected graduation date, regardless of which language course is their first.


Please note: Advanced Placement (AP) and International Baccalaureate (IB) exams will not satisfy the requirements for this major.


Prerequisites

Students are required to successfully (grade C or higher) complete one language course at UC Berkeley and one course from List A (see the Berkeley Guide or department website) before declaring the major.


More Information

The Berkeley Catalog and the department website provide more information about major requirements and course information.


Advising:

Students with questions about transferring into the major in East Asian Languages and Cultures are encouraged to contact our undergraduate major advisor:

Cassandra Dunn

Department Website: http://ealc.berkeley.edu/

Email: cassandrajj@berkeley.edu

  2. Click on the down arrow to select: Academic Year, Institution: UC Berkeley, and Agreements with Other Institutions: (Your CA Community College). 
  3. Click on “View Agreements”.
  4. Under “View Agreement by” select “General Education/Breadth”. 
  5. Click on the “General Education/Breadth” radio button, then click on “View Agreement”


Learn more from the UC Berkeley Office of Undergraduate Admission and specifically about transfer admission preparation. 


Review all available majors at UC Berkeley.

• Required lower-division requirements 
  • Math 1A or Math 16A
  • Math 1B or Math 16B
  • Econ 1 or Econ 2
  • Strongly recommended lower-division requirements
  • Stat 20, Stat 21

• Advanced Placement Examinations (AP Credit)
  • Math AB - scores of 3, 4 or 5 are equivalent to Math 16A or Math 1A.
  • Math BC - scores of 3 or 4 are equivalent to Math 16A or Math 1A; a score of 5 is equivalent to Math 1B and fulfills the Economics calculus prerequisite.
  • Economics Micro/Macro - scores of 4 or 5 on both exams are equivalent to Economics 1 or Economics 2.
  • GCE Advanced Level Examinations (A Level Credit)
  • Mathematics - score of A, B, or C is equivalent to Math 1A and 1B and fulfills the Economics calculus prerequisite.
  • Economics Micro/Macro - score of A, B, or C is equivalent to Econ 1 and fulfills the Introductory Economics prerequisite. Students may enroll in upper division economics coursework beginning in the second semester of their freshman year.
  • International Baccalaureate Higher Level Examinations (IB Credit)
  • Mathematics - score of 5, 6, or 7 fulfills the Economics calculus prerequisite.
  • Mathematics: Analysis & Approaches - score of 5, 6, or 7 fulfills MATH 1A or MATH 16A.
  • Mathematics: Analysis & Approaches - score of 7 fulfills MATH 1A and MATH 1B.
  • ﻿Mathematics: Applications & Interpretation - score of 5, 6, or 7 fulfills MATH 16A.
  • Economics Micro/Macro - score of 5, 6, or 7 is equivalent to Econ 1 and fulfills the Introductory Economics prerequisite.

WHY STUDY ECONOMICS?


Have you ever thought, “what can I do with a degree in Economics?”


Economics can be broadly defined as the study of human behaviors aimed at finding solutions to help improve peoples' lives. A

degree in economics doesn't have to be about finance, banking, business, or government, . . . it can be useful to all individuals

and can lead to many interesting and fulfilling career choices.


  • Visit our website for more information: https://econ.berkeley.edu/undergraduate/admissions
  • General contact information:
  • Location: 539 Evans Hall, UC Berkeley
  • Email: ugrad@econ.berkeley.edu
  • Phone number: N/A

general_texts:
The Rausser College of Natural Resources (RCNR) admits students directly into one of its nine undergraduate majors as selected by the applicant at the time of application. Because Rausser College does not admit transfer students as undeclared, each individual major has a distinct set of transfer courses required as major preparation before the applicant is minimally eligible for admission.  


Resources for RCNR transfer applicants: 

  • UC Berkeley Office of Undergraduate Admissions Minimum Requirements for Transfer Admission
  • Rausser College of Natural Resources Transfer Applicants page - includes transfer admission guidelines specific to each Rausser College major, as well as additional information on how to submit a competitive application for your intended major 
  • Rausser College Major Requirements and Sample Degree Plans
  • Rausser College Advising Staff

ABOUT THE ECOSYSTEM MANAGEMENT & FORESTRY MAJOR


Ecosystem Management & Forestry focuses on the conservation and restoration of the earth's natural resources through hands-on study of the ecology, stewardship, and management of forest, woodland, and grassland ecosystems. The program offers an accredited specialization in Forestry and Natural Resource Management.


For additional information, please contact the Ecosystem Management & Forestry advisor at crs.emf.ugrad@berkeley.edu.

Please Note: Applicants are expected to complete all required coursework by the end of the spring term prior to admission. Majors may allow one course pending in the summer term prior to admission if the major has more than five required courses and at least five courses of the required coursework have been completed; in this case, if a requirement includes both a lecture and lab, the lecture and lab together are treated as one course. Majors which require five or fewer required courses to transfer will not allow required coursework to be completed in the summer prior to admission. Please see the Rausser College of Natural Resources Transfer Applicants page for individual requirements by major.


Ecosystem Management & Forestry applicants may have the opportunity to complete a single required course in the summer term prior to admission. If a requirement includes both a lecture and lab, the lecture and lab together are treated as one course.



To ensure full articulation of transfer coursework: if a series of courses at a community college is required (e.g., Chemistry 101 + 102 + 103 = CHEM 1A/1AL + CHEM 1B at UC Berkeley), all of the courses in the series must be completed, and must (unless otherwise indicated) be completed at the same community college. Partial completion of the series (e.g., two of the three required courses) may result in no credit toward the requirement(s), and splitting a series of courses between different community colleges is not guaranteed to satisfy the requirement. Courses taken out of series will be evaluated by college faculty during the transfer admissions process. If you have questions about the articulation of a series for your intended major, please email crs.emf.ugrad@berkeley.edu.


Minimum Admissions Requirements in Ecosystem Management & Forestry:


Equivalent of: 

  • READING & COMPOSITION A + READING & COMPOSTION B - satisfied by full UC IGETC, or may be satisfied with AP/IB/A-Level exam credit
  • CHEM 1A and CHEM 1AL - may also be satisfied by AP/IB/A-Level exam credit
  • BIOLOGY 1B - may also be satisfied by AP/IB/A-Level exam credit
  • MATH 16A and MATH 16B; or MATH 51 and MATH 52 - may also be satisfied by AP/IB/A-Level exam credit



Highly Recommended (but not required) Prior to Transfer

  • ESPM Environmental Science and ESPM Social Science core courses
  • EPS 50, GEOG 1, or GEOG 40 
  • ECON 1 or ECON 2 (micro-economics and macro-economics)
  • Introductory statistics, environmental science, and geographic information systems (GIS) courses

general_texts:
The Educational Sciences major is offered by the Berkeley School of Education (BSE). The Educational Sciences major explores the field of education via academic inquiry and direct engagement with schools, families, and local and global communities. Through multidisciplinary training and participatory practices in school-based and community contexts, students will come to understand learning inside and outside of official institutions and will learn how to critically analyze current issues in education. The role of digital technologies in a networked world, and their capacity to elide educational time and space, will be an object of study. 


There are no lower division major requirements available for articulation.

Educational Sciences is offered through the Berkeley School of Education. However, transfer students who are interested in declaring the Educational Sciences major must initially apply to the College of Letters & Science, with Educational Sciences listed as their intended major. After students have completed one term at UC Berkeley, and have met the eligibility requirements for declaring the Educational Sciences major, they may declare this major. 


IMPORTANT information for students applying for admission to L&S for the fall 2025 application cycle and beyond


Completion of Essential Skills requirements (Reading & Composition, Quantitative Reasoning, and Foreign Language) or


Cal-GETC/IGETC will no longer be a requirement for admission; however, completion of either is strongly recommended prior

to enrollment at UC Berkeley to ensure timely degree progress. For more information see the see the New Policies for Transfer

Student Applicants website for L&S: https://ls.berkeley.edu/prospective-students/new-policies-transfer-student-applicants


By the end of the spring term preceding fall enrollment at Berkeley, you must complete: 

The 7-course pattern (as found in the UC Transfer Admission Eligibility Courses Menu in ASSIST):

  • Two transferable courses in English composition;
  • One transferable course in mathematical concepts and quantitative reasoning;
  • Four transferable college courses chosen from at least two of the following subject areas:
  • arts and humanities

general_titles: college of Engineering Junior Transfer Admission Requirements
general_texts:
Admission to the UC Berkeley College of Engineering is highly competitive.


This is a new major at UC Berkeley starting Fall 2025. Applicants to the Electrical and and Computer Engineering major must complete all required core UCB preparation courses in order to be eligible for admission. Only applicants who have completed 100% of these required courses will be considered for admission. Required courses for admission to the major must be completed by the end of the spring semester prior to fall enrollment. A summer 2026 course is not considered to be "work in progress" for the fall 2026 selection process.


If a series of courses at a community college is required (e.g., Chemistry 101 + 102 + 103 = Chemistry A and B), all the courses in the series must be completed, and must (unless otherwise indicated) be completed at the same community college. Partial completion (e.g., 2 of the 3 required courses) will result in zero credit toward the requirement(s), and the applicant will NOT be considered for admission. The only exception to the series rule is Math 54. If Math 54 is split into two different courses, one covering linear algebra and one covering differential equations, we strongly encourage applicants to take both courses at the same community college; however, the College of Engineering will accept linear algebra from one school and differential equations from a different school.


Lower division UC Berkeley courses required for graduation (but not admission) are also listed in the major agreements and are strongly recommended to be taken to strengthen one's application. The more of these courses completed, the stronger the application will be.


Required core courses for admission: (all these courses must be completed to be considered for admission)

- UCB MATH 51; 52; 53; 54

- UCB PHYSICS 7A; 7B

- UCB READING AND COMPOSITION A; B

- One from UCB ASTRON 7A or 7B or BIOLOGY 1A/1AL or BIOLOGY 1B or CHEM 1A/1AL or CHEM 1B or CHEM 3A/3AL or CHEM 3B/3BL or MCELLBI 32/32L or PHYSICS 7C


Strongly recommended courses: (if your college offers the courses listed below and they are articulated, taking them will strengthen your application) If no articulation, students are encouraged to take an introductory course in electronics or circuits AND courses in Java, C++ and Data Structures.

- UCB COMPSCI 61A; 61B; 61C; 70

- UCB EECS 16A; 16B


Articulation subject to completion of a university course

If the above statement is indicated under any of the community college courses listed below, you will be required to take an additional course at UC Berkeley in order to complete the requirement.


Admission is primarily based on the completeness of the applicant's lower division preparation and the level of academic achievement reflected in the student's grade point average. The UC applicant essay also plays an important role in the selection process at UC Berkeley. The College reviews the essay for evidence of interest in the student's chosen field and a thoughtful match between the academic program and the student's academic and career objectives.


The College of Engineering requires six humanities/social science courses, two of which must be reading and composition. The only non-technical admission requirement for the College of Engineering is the coursework equivalent to UC Berkeley's Reading and Composition requirement, which must be taken for a letter grade. The College of Engineering does not recognize the Intersegmental General Education Transfer Curriculum (Cal-GETC/IGETC) and strongly discourages students from following this option due to the number of major-specific technical courses required for engineering transfer admission.


NOTE: The Reading and Composition requirements cannot be satisfied by Cal-GETC/IGETC; applicants must complete the specific courses indicated as Reading and Composition A and B equivalents to be considered for admission. Failure to complete the exact courses listed will mean the applicant will NOT be considered for admission.


The remaining four humanities/social science requirement courses are not considered for admission purposes but are required for graduation. See http://engineering.berkeley.edu/hss for the College of Engineering humanities/social science breadth requirements and courses. Courses which are three semester units or more that appear in the following categories on the "General Education/Breadth" section of assist.org may be used to satisfy two of the remaining four humanities/social science course requirements for the College of Engineering. ARTS AND LITERATURE; HISTORICAL STUDIES; INTERNATIONAL STUDIES; PHILOSOPHY AND VALUES; SOCIAL AND BEHAVIORIAL SCIENCES. Additionally, courses that teach a foreign language may be used to satisfy this requirement.


SAT/ACT/A-level test scores and letters of recommendation are NOT considered for admission.


NOTE: ALL REQUIRED COURSES AND ALL STRONGLY RECOMMENDED COURSES FOR THE MAJOR MUST BE TAKEN FOR A LETTER GRADE. FOR MORE INFORMATION, PLEASE CHECK THE COLLEGE'S WEB SITE FOR THE COLLEGE OF ENGINEERING UNDERGRADUATE GUIDE.


For more information:

http://engineering.berkeley.edu/admissions/undergraduate-admissions


College of Engineering Undergraduate Guide:

http://engineering.berkeley.edu/academics/undergraduate-guide


For more information on Electrical & Computer Engineering:

https://engineering.berkeley.edu/students/undergraduate-guide/degree-requirements/major-programs/electrical-computer-engineering/


For more information on admission to UC Berkeley:

http://admissions.berkeley.edu


For more information on majors at UC Berkeley:

https://undergraduate.catalog.berkeley.edu/

Some Advanced Placement, International Baccalaureate, and A-Level exams can fulfill requirements in the College of Engineering. For details, please see https://engineering.berkeley.edu/students/undergraduate-guide/exams/.

If Math 54 is split into two different courses, one covering linear algebra and one covering differential equations, we strongly encourage applicants to take both courses at the same community college; however, the College of Engineering will accept linear algebra from one school and differential equations from a different school.


Lower division UC Berkeley courses required for graduation (but not admission) are also listed in the major agreements and are strongly recommended to be taken to strengthen one's application. The more of these courses completed, the stronger the application will be.


Required core courses for admission: (all these courses must be completed to be considered for admission)

- UCB CHEM 1A/1AL

- UCB MATH 51; 52; 53; 54

- UCB PHYSICS 7A; 7B

- UCB READING COMPOSITION A; B

- One course from: CHEM 1B; CHEM 3A/3AL or PHYSICS 7C


Strongly recommended courses: (if your college offers the courses listed below and they are articulated, taking them will strengthen your application)

- UCB COMPSCI 61A or ENGIN 7

- UCB MEC ENG 40 or ENGIN 40

- UCB MATH 55

- One from: COMPSCI 61B; EECS 16A; EECS 16B; MAT SCI 45/45L; CIV ENG 11 or CIV ENG 70; MEC ENG C85/CIV ENG C30


Articulation subject to completion of a university course

If the above statement is indicated under any of the community college course listed below, you will be required to take an additional course at UC Berkeley in order to complete the requirement.


Admission is primarily based on the completeness of the applicant's lower division preparation and the level of academic achievement reflected in the student's grade point average. The UC applicant essay also plays an important role in the selection process at UC Berkeley. The College reviews the essay for evidence of interest in the student's chosen field and a thoughtful match between the academic program and the student's academic and career objectives.


The College of Engineering requires six humanities/social science courses, two of which must be reading and composition. The only non-technical admission requirement for the College of Engineering is the coursework equivalent to UC Berkeley's Reading and Composition A and B, which must be taken for a letter grade. The College of Engineering does not recognize the Intersegmental General Education Transfer Curriculum (Cal-GETC/IGETC) and strongly discourages students from following this option due to the number of major-specific technical courses required for engineering transfer admission.


NOTE: The Reading and Composition requirements cannot be satisfied by Cal-GETC/IGETC; applicants must complete the specific courses indicated as Reading and Composition A and B equivalents to be considered for admission. Failure to complete the exact courses listed will mean the applicant will NOT be considered for admission.


The remaining four humanities/social science requirement courses are not considered for admission purposes but are required for graduation. See http://engineering.berkeley.edu/hss for the College of Engineering humanities/social science breadth requirements and courses. Courses which are three semester units or more that appear in the following categories on the "General Education/Breadth" section of assist.org may be used to satisfy two of the remaining four humanities/social science course requirements for the College of Engineering. ARTS AND LITERATURE; HISTORICAL STUDIES; INTERNATIONAL STUDIES; PHILOSOPHY AND VALUES; SOCIAL AND BEHAVIORAL SCIENCES. Additionally, courses that teach a foreign language may be used to satisfy this requirement.


SAT/ACT/A-level test scores and letters of recommendation are NOT considered for admission.

general_texts:
COLLEGE ADMISSIONS REQUIREMENTS FOR TRANSFER STUDENTS 


THIS MAJOR IS OFFERED BY THE COLLEGE OF LETTERS AND SCIENCE (L&S)


IMPORTANT information for students applying for admission to L&S for the fall 2025 application cycle and beyond


Completion of Essential Skills requirements (Reading & Composition, Quantitative Reasoning, and Foreign Language) or

Cal-GETC/IGETC will no longer be a requirement for admission; however, completion of either is strongly recommended

prior to enrollment at UC Berkeley to ensure timely degree progress. More information on new polices is available on

the L&S Transfer Student Applicants website. 


By the end of the spring term preceding fall enrollment at Berkeley, you must complete: 


1) The 7-course pattern (as found in the UC Transfer Admission Eligibility Courses Menu in ASSIST):

·   Two transferable courses in English composition;

·   One transferable course in mathematical concepts and quantitative reasoning;

·   Four transferable college courses chosen from at least two of the following subject areas:

o arts and humanities

o social and behavioral sciences

o physical and biological sciences


AND


2) Major Requirements: 

Follow the guidance on preparation for this major below. 


For more information on L&S General Education requirements:


For information on courses that will satisfy L&S General Education (Essential Skills and

Seven-Course Breadth) requirements from your community college complete the following steps:

  1. Go to "Search below for articulation agreements: Major, department, and campus-specific general education agreements”
  2. Click on the down arrow to select: Academic Year, Institution: UC Berkeley, and Agreements with Other Institutions: (Your CA Community College). 
  3. Click on “View Agreements”.
  4. Under “View Agreement by” select “General Education/Breadth”. 
  5. Click on the “General Education/Breadth” radio button, then click on “View Agreement”


Learn more from the UC Berkeley Office of Undergraduate Admission and specifically about transfer admission preparation. 


Review all available majors at UC Berkeley.

To prepare for the English Major, complete UC-transferable courses in literary analysis and the history of literature written in English. These do not include basic composition and technical writing classes. If your course-work has not been approved on Assist for articulation with the Berkeley requirements listed below, retain syllabi and reading lists for evaluation by the department. You do not have to complete all lower division courses at your Community College (CC). The more transferable classes you take at your CC, the more progress you will have made in the English major upon starting at Cal.


English 45A - Literature in English: Through Milton

English 45B - Literature in English: The Late-17th through the Mid-19th Century

English 45C - Literature in English: The Mid-19th through the Mid-20th Century

English 17 - Shakespeare

English 90 - Practices of Literary Study


Notes:


The following classes must be taken for a letter grade: English 45A, 45B, 45C, Shakespeare, English 90.

Students should complete as many lower division major requirements (Engl 45A, 45B, 45C, Engl 17, and

Engl 90 equivalents) as possible before transferring to UC Berkeley as an English major. To see requirements

for the major after you transfer, please see our website.


For more information on the major:

See our website: https://english.berkeley.edu/major-requirements 

Contact: english_advising@berkeley.edu or call (510) 642-3467

general_texts:
The Rausser College of Natural Resources (RCNR) admits students directly into one of its nine undergraduate majors as selected by the applicant at the time of application. Because Rausser College does not admit transfer students as undeclared, each individual major has a distinct set of transfer courses required as major preparation before the applicant is minimally eligible for admission.  


Resources for RCNR transfer applicants: 

  • UC Berkeley Office of Undergraduate Admissions Minimum Requirements for Transfer Admission
  • Rausser College of Natural Resources Transfer Applicants page - includes transfer admission guidelines specific to each Rausser College major, as well as additional information on how to submit a competitive application for your intended major 
  • Rausser College Major Requirements and Sample Degree Plans
  • Rausser College Advising Staff

ABOUT THE ENVIRONMENTAL ECONOMICS & POLICY MAJOR


This major offers an opportunity to explore aspects of economic and political institutions that affect the development and management of natural resources and the environment. The program takes a problem-solving approach to issues involving renewable and fixed natural resources, and it is based on a foundation in micro-economic theory and the economics of resources and the environment. 


For additional information, please contact the Environmental Economics & Policy advisor at eep.ugrad@berkeley.edu.

Please Note: Applicants are expected to complete all required coursework by the end of the spring term prior to admission. Majors may allow one course pending in the summer term prior to admission if the major has more than five required courses and at least five courses of the required coursework have been completed; in this case, if a requirement includes both a lecture and lab, the lecture and lab together are treated as one course. Majors which require five or fewer required courses to transfer will not allow required coursework to be completed in the summer prior to admission. Please see the Rausser College of Natural Resources Transfer Applicants page for individual requirements by major.


Environmental Economics & Policy applicants have five or fewer required courses to complete prior to transfer and will not be allowed to complete a required course in the summer prior to admission.



To ensure full articulation of transfer coursework: if a series of courses at a community college is required (e.g., Chemistry 101 + 102 + 103 = CHEM 1A/1AL + CHEM 1B at UC Berkeley), all of the courses in the series must be completed, and must (unless otherwise indicated) be completed at the same community college. Partial completion of the series (e.g., two of the three required courses) may result in no credit toward the requirement(s), and splitting a series of courses between different community colleges is not guaranteed to satisfy the requirement. Courses taken out of series will be evaluated by college faculty during the transfer admissions process. If you have questions about the articulation of a series for your intended major, please email eep.ugrad@berkeley.edu.


Minimum Admissions Requirements in Environmental Economics & Policy:


Equivalent of: 

  • READING & COMPOSITION A + READING & COMPOSTION B - satisfied by full UC IGETC, or may be satisfied with AP/IB/A-Level exam credit
  • ENVECON 1, ECON 1, ECON 2, or ECON 3 - may also be satisfied by AP/IB/A-Level exam credit
  • MATH 16A and MATH 16B; or MATH 51 and MATH 52 - may also be satisfied by AP/IB/A-Level exam credit



Highly Recommended (but not required) Prior to Transfer

  • 7-course breadth coursework or full UC IGETC

general_texts:
The Rausser College of Natural Resources (RCNR) admits students directly into one of its nine undergraduate majors as selected by the applicant at the time of application. Because Rausser College does not admit transfer students as undeclared, each individual major has a distinct set of transfer courses required as major preparation before the applicant is minimally eligible for admission.  


Resources for RCNR transfer applicants: 

  • UC Berkeley Office of Undergraduate Admissions Minimum Requirements for Transfer Admission
  • Rausser College of Natural Resources Transfer Applicants page - includes transfer admission guidelines specific to each Rausser College major, as well as additional information on how to submit a competitive application for your intended major 
  • Rausser College Major Requirements and Sample Degree Plans
  • Rausser College Advising Staff

ABOUT THE ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES MAJOR


The major emphasizes basic science in a rigorous curriculum drawn from a variety of departments including biology, chemistry, mathematics, physics, economics and environmental science. In the junior and senior years, students take electives in their area of interest, as well as courses in statistics, research methodology, and environmental modeling to prepare for the senior research thesis seminar. In the research seminar, each student designs and conducts a research project of his or her own choosing. This year-long course is the capstone of the major. The experience is extremely helpful for students as they prepare for environmental careers or graduate/professional school.


For additional information, please contact the Environmental Sciences advisor at envsci.ugrad@berkeley.edu.

Please Note: Applicants are expected to complete all required coursework by the end of the spring term prior to admission. Majors may allow one course pending in the summer term prior to admission if the major has more than five required courses and at least five courses of the required coursework have been completed; in this case, if a requirement includes both a lecture and lab, the lecture and lab together are treated as one course. Majors which require five or fewer required courses to transfer will not allow required coursework to be completed in the summer prior to admission. Please see the Rausser College of Natural Resources Transfer Applicants page for individual requirements by major.


Environmental Sciences applicants may have the opportunity to complete a single required course in the summer term prior to admission. If a requirement includes both a lecture and lab, the lecture and lab together are treated as one course.



To ensure full articulation of transfer coursework: if a series of courses at a community college is required (e.g., Chemistry 101 + 102 + 103 = CHEM 1A/1AL + CHEM 1B at UC Berkeley), all of the courses in the series must be completed, and must (unless otherwise indicated) be completed at the same community college. Partial completion of the series (e.g., two of the three required courses) may result in no credit toward the requirement(s), and splitting a series of courses between different community colleges is not guaranteed to satisfy the requirement. Courses taken out of series will be evaluated by college faculty during the transfer admissions process. If you have questions about the articulation of a series for your intended major, please email envsci.ugrad@berkeley.edu.


Minimum Admissions Requirements in Environmental Sciences:

Please note that the required chemistry sequence and biology coursework for Environmental Sciences may vary based on the concentration you are pursuing in the major. You can review the chemistry requirements for each Environmental Sciences concentration on this major snapshot.


Equivalent of: 

  • READING & COMPOSITION A + READING & COMPOSTION B - may also be satisfied by full UC IGETC, or may be satisfied with AP/IB/A-Level exam credit
  • CHEM 1A and CHEM 1AL - may also be satisfied by AP/IB/A-Level exam credit
  • CHEM 1B; or CHEM 3A and CHEM 3AL
  • BIOLOGY 1A and BIOLOGY 1AL and BIOLOGY 1B; or BIOLOGY 11, BIOLOGY 11L, and BIOLOGY 1B - Only BIOLOGY 1B may also be satisfied by AP/IB/A-Level exam credit
  • MATH 16A and MATH 16B; or MATH 51 and MATH 52 - may also be satisfied by AP/IB/A-Level exam credit



Highly Recommended (but not required) Prior to Transfer

  • Introductory environmental science classes if offered by your institutions
  • Micro-economics; macroeconomics is not required by the major
  • PHYSICS 8A or PHYSICS 7A
  • ESPM Social Science core - satisfied by full UC IGETC
  • ESPM Environmental Science core
  • Breadth course in Social & Behavioral Sciences or International Studies; and breadth course in Arts & Literature, Historical Studies or Philosophy & Values - satisfied by full UC IGETC

COLLEGE ADMISSIONS REQUIREMENTS FOR TRANSFER STUDENTS 


THIS MAJOR IS OFFERED BY THE COLLEGE OF LETTERS AND SCIENCE (L&S)


IMPORTANT information for students applying for admission to L&S for the fall 2025 application cycle and beyond


Completion of Essential Skills requirements (Reading & Composition, Quantitative Reasoning, and Foreign Language) or

Cal-GETC/IGETC will no longer be a requirement for admission; however, completion of either is strongly recommended

prior to enrollment at UC Berkeley to ensure timely degree progress. More information on new polices is available on

the L&S Transfer Student Applicants website. 


By the end of the spring term preceding fall enrollment at Berkeley, you must complete: 


1) The 7-course pattern (as found in the UC Transfer Admission Eligibility Courses Menu in ASSIST):

·   Two transferable courses in English composition;

·   One transferable course in mathematical concepts and quantitative reasoning;

·   Four transferable college courses chosen from at least two of the following subject areas:

o arts and humanities

o social and behavioral sciences

o physical and biological sciences


AND


2) Major Requirements: 

Follow the guidance on preparation for this major below. 


For more information on L&S General Education requirements:


For information on courses that will satisfy L&S General Education (Essential Skills and

Seven-Course Breadth) requirements from your community college complete the following steps:

  1. Go to "Search below for articulation agreements: Major, department, and campus-specific general education agreements”
  2. Click on the down arrow to select: Academic Year, Institution: UC Berkeley, and Agreements with Other Institutions: (Your CA Community College). 
  3. Click on “View Agreements”.
  4. Under “View Agreement by” select “General Education/Breadth”. 
  5. Click on the “General Education/Breadth” radio button, then click on “View Agreement”


Learn more from the UC Berkeley Office of Undergraduate Admission and specifically about transfer admission preparation. 


Review all available majors at UC Berkeley.

The group major in Ethnic Studies provides a core curriculum designed to develop a comparative and multidisciplinary understanding of the experiences and communities of African Americans, Asian Americans, Chicano/Latinos, and Native Americans.


Students majoring in Ethnic Studies study the history, culture, politics, and sociology of Third World communities in the United States within the general context of American society and institutions. Thus, they pursue knowledge vital for a critical understanding of contemporary society and for social changes to improve the lives and communities of racial minorities. Ethnic studies majors also prepare themselves for advanced graduate study in either academic or professional fields.


Lower division requirements for the Ethnic Studies major:


ETH STD 11AC - Introduction to Ethnic Studies

Two electives from:

- African American Studies

- Asian American Studies

- Chicano Studies

- Ethnic Studies

- Gender and Women’s Studies

- LGBT Studies

- Native American Studies


For more information contact Major Advisors:


Dewey St. Germaine

(510) 643-6420

deweystg@berkeley.edu


Laura Jimenez-Olvera

(510) 642-0243

lauraj@berkeley.edu

For more information on L&S General Education requirements:


For information on courses that will satisfy L&S General Education (Essential Skills and

Seven-Course Breadth) requirements from your community college complete the following steps:

  1. Go to "Search below for articulation agreements: Major, department, and campus-specific general education agreements”
  2. Click on the down arrow to select: Academic Year, Institution: UC Berkeley, and Agreements with Other Institutions: (Your CA Community College). 
  3. Click on “View Agreements”.
  4. Under “View Agreement by” select “General Education/Breadth”. 
  5. Click on the “General Education/Breadth” radio button, then click on “View Agreement”


Learn more from the UC Berkeley Office of Undergraduate Admission and specifically about transfer admission preparation. 


Review all available majors at UC Berkeley.

PREPARATION FOR TRANSFER AT THE JUNIOR LEVEL


In order to declare the Film & Media major, students must receive a grade of C or higher in either:


  • Film 10 - Film History & Form, or
  • Film 20 - Film & Media Theory


It is recommended students take one, or both, of these classes in their first semester. It is also possible to petition to waive out of these requirements with work already completed elsewhere. If you successfully waive out of either Film 10 or Film 20, you will be immediately eligible to declare the Film & Media major. Contact the UCB Film & Media Undergraduate Advisor for more information.

The group major in Film & Media has been designed to place the history and theory of film into the larger context of humanistic studies. Emphasis is placed on developing students' analytical and critical faculties. Courses are offered in the history of film, the history of film theory, genres, and auteurs. Also offered are numerous elective courses related to the general study of film. A recent update of the Film & Media curriculum has also substantially expanded Production course offerings, both writing-based and practical production.


Berkeley offers an innovative, interdisciplinary undergraduate program leading to a BA in Film & Media. This rich and diverse program offers rigorous engagement with the entire culture of moving-images in the larger context of humanistic studies, teaching students to think historically, theoretically, and analytically about a wide range of cinematic and para-cinematic forms. At the same time, it encourages students to look at moving-images from the vantage point of other disciplines. The major has expanded recently as well, giving more consideration to practical production, writing-based courses, and expanding the curriculum to cover more New Media topics.


For more information:

Undergraduate Advisor

filmmediaugadvising@berkeley.edu

(510) 642-3522

https://filmmedia.berkeley.edu/

Review all available majors at UC Berkeley.

PREPARATION FOR TRANSFER AT THE JUNIOR LEVEL


Students interested in the French major or minor at UC Berkeley should complete as much French coursework as possible at the community-college level. Two years of college-level French, or its equivalent, is highly recommended.


All transfer students should consult the Placement Guidelines on the French Department website at https://french.berkeley.edu/undergraduate/placement-guidelines to determine the best level for initial enrollment in French at UC Berkeley. This major may require at least one additional semester of French language study at UC Berkeley (French 3 and/or French 4) before enrollment can be approved for 3rd year/Upper Division French courses. French 102 is the first course in the major and requires completion of French 1-4 or its equivalent, native fluency, or satisfactory completion of the department placement exam.


Once accepted at UC Berkeley, students should refer to placement information below AND consult with the UC Berkeley Undergraduate Major Adviser in French regarding course planning (frendept@berkeley.edu). 


Students who have…                                                                                                                                              Place initially in…


passing grade in 1st semester or 2nd quarter college French                                                                       French 2


passing grade in FR2 at UCB or 2nd/3rd semester or 3rd/4th quarter college* French                      French 3


passing grade in FR3 at UCB or 4th semester or 5th quarter college* French                                        French 4


passing grade in FR4 at UCB or 3rd year college** French                                                                              French 102 


*If you are unsure of your ability to take French 3 or 4, contact the Second Year Coordinator, Vesna Rodic (vrodic@berkeley.edu).


**Students who have taken 3rd year college French will need to take a placement test to confirm enrollment in French 102. Contact Vesna Rodic (vrodic@berkeley.edu).


Please note:

  • French 1-4 are not open to heritage and native speakers of French; heritage and native speakers should contact the Undergraduate Major Advisor for upper division placement.
  • In the first week of class, students will be screened for appropriate placement, and instructors may make recommendations for alternate placement.
  • Students unsure about their placement even given the guidelines below should consider attending the first days of class in TWO levels to self-assess for comfort, fluency, and skill.
  • There is no lower division placement exam. However, if you have circumstances in which you believe you would place out of French 4 (i.e. AP of 5 + a year of schooling abroad, two years of schooling in a Francophone country), please contact Vesna Rodic for a placement test.
  • No auditing is permitted in lower division French courses.
  • Attendance is MANDATORY in the first two weeks of all lower division language classes and French 102. Students who do not attend class every day in the first week will be dropped from the class and any coursework not turned in on time during that period will not be counted.
  • If you wish to add a French language course or change into a different section, attend the course even if it is listed as full; there is a lot of movement in the first weeks of class, particularly in language classes.



For more information:

Undergraduate Advising, Department of French

(510) 982-6181

frendept@berkeley.edu

http://french.berkeley.edu
