Fall 2026 Admission For this Major:

Transfer students who select this major on their College of Letters and Science (L&S) application and are offered admission to L&S will be directly admitted into this major. If you are interested in this major, it is very important to select this major on your application, and complete as many lower-division major requirements as possible prior to transfer.

See details on preparation for this major below.


Gender & Women's Studies (GWS) offers interdisciplinary perspectives on the study of women and gender, focusing on power relations in the production of knowledge and in practices of everyday life. The curriculum considers gender in the context of cultural processes, historical movements, and social transformations as well as creative practices and innovations. Close attention is paid to links between gender and sexuality, racialization, ethnicity, class, nationality and globalization.


To prepare for the GWS major, take courses on women and gender, if available. Transfer students must complete two of the three gateway courses GWS 10 (Introduction to Gender & Women's Studies), GWS 20 (Introduction to Feminist Theory), or LGBT 20AC (Alternative Sexual Identities and Communities in Contemporary American Society) and have a 2.0 GPA.


For more information:

Gender and Women's Studies

Undergraduate Advisor

(510) 642-8513


https://gws.berkeley.edu/

The Rausser College of Natural Resources (RCNR) admits students directly into one of its nine undergraduate majors as selected by the applicant at the time of application.   • Rausser College Major Requirements and Sample Degree Plans
  • Rausser College Advising Staff

ABOUT THE GENETICS & PLANT BIOLOGY MAJOR


Genetics and Plant Biology (GPB) combines traditional plant sciences (physiology, biochemistry, morphology) with more recent biological disciplines (molecular genetics and genomics) to study the role of plants in the global environment. The discipline emphasizes the study of plants from the sub-molecular levels to the organismal level. Relevant applications include biotechnology, bioenergy, agriculture, biomedical, food science, bioinformatics, and genetic counseling.  


For additional information, please contact the Genetics & Plant Biology advisor at pmb.ugrad@berkeley.edu.

Please Note: Applicants are expected to complete all required coursework by the end of the spring term prior to admission. Majors may allow one course pending in the summer term prior to admission if the major has more than five required courses and at least five courses of the required coursework have been completed; in this case, if a requirement includes both a lecture and lab, the lecture and lab together are treated as one course. Majors which require five or fewer required courses to transfer will not allow required coursework to be completed in the summer prior to admission. Please see the Rausser College of Natural Resources Transfer Applicants page for individual requirements by major.


Genetics & Plant Biology applicants may have the opportunity to complete a single required course in the summer term prior to admission. If a requirement includes both a lecture and lab, the lecture and lab together are treated as one course.



To ensure full articulation of transfer coursework: if a series of courses at a community college is required (e.g., Chemistry 101 + 102 + 103 = CHEM 1A/1AL + CHEM 1B at UC Berkeley), all of the courses in the series must be completed, and must (unless otherwise indicated) be completed at the same community college. Partial completion of the series (e.g., two of the three required courses) may result in no credit toward the requirement(s), and splitting a series of courses between different community colleges is not guaranteed to satisfy the requirement. Courses taken out of series will be evaluated by college faculty during the transfer admissions process. If you have questions about the articulation of a series for your intended major, please email pmb.ugrad@berkeley.edu.


Minimum Admissions Requirements in Genetics & Plant Biology:


Equivalent of: 

  • READING & COMPOSITION A + READING & COMPOSTION B - satisfied by full UC IGETC, or may be satisfied with AP/IB/A-Level exam credit
  • CHEM 1A and CHEM 1AL - may also be satisfied by AP/IB/A-Level exam credit
  • CHEM 3A and CHEM 3AL
  • CHEM 3B and CHEM 3BL
  • BIOLOGY 1A and BIOLOGY 1AL
  • BIOLOGY 1B
  • MATH 16A and MATH 16B; or MATH 51 and MATH 52; or MATH 10A and MATH 10B - may also be satisfied by AP/IB/A-Level exam credit


Highly Recommended (but not required) Prior to Transfer

  • STAT 2, STAT 20, or DATA C8 - may also be satisfied by AP/IB/A-Level exam credit
  • PHYSICS 8A - students pursuing a pre-health curriculum may also be required to complete the second half of physics (PHYSICS 8B at Berkeley) which is not required by the Microbial Biology major
  • 15 units of breadth coursework in the social sciences and humanities - satisfied by full UC IGETC, or may be satisfied with AP/IB/A-Level exam credit

○ See details on preparation for this major below.


LOWER DIVISION REQUIREMENTS FOR GEOGRAPHY MAJORS


REQUIRED FOR ADMISSION

Complete one course from any two of the following areas:

PHYSICAL GEOGRAPHY

WORLD GEOGRAPHY

REGIONAL GEOGRAPHY


The major requires a student take three lower division courses,

one from any two areas must be completed to be considered for admission :


PHYSICAL GEOGRAPHY

GEOG 40 (Introduction to Earth System Science) or

ESPM 15 (Introduction to Environmental Sciences) or

GEOG N1 (Global Environmental Change)

Complete a course approved for the Physical Geography requirement listed below.

This covers physical geography basics.


WORLD GEOGRAPHY

GEOG 20 (Globalization) or

GEOG C32 (Introduction to Global Studies) or

GEOG N4 (World Peoples and Cultural Environments)

Complete a course approved for the World Geography requirement listed below.

This covers world geography.


REGIONAL GEOGRAPHY

GEOG 10AC (Worldlings: Regions, Peoples, and States) or

GEOG 50AC (California) or

GEOG C55 (Introduction to Central Asia) or

GEOG 70AC (The Urban Experience) or

GEOG 72AC (The Bay Area) or

Complete a course approved for the Regional Geography requirement listed below.

This represents regional geographies.


AP Exams do not satisfy any major requirements for Geography;

IBHL Geography exam with a passing score of 5, 6, or 7 can be used to satisfy GEOG 20.


Courses other than those listed below may be acceptable.

Transfer students who have taken introductory courses elsewhere should consult with the departmental undergraduate advisor at Berkeley to avoid repeating lower division work.


For more information about the major:

https://geography.berkeley.edu/

Global Studies majors must demonstrate proficiency in a modern language other than English by the last semester of their senior year. This language must be connected, in either the past or the present, to the student’s geographic region of specialization. Proficiency is equivalent to the ability achieved in four college-level semesters (or two years). Language courses taken in high school do not satisfy this requirement. See below for details on how to fulfill the foreign language requirement.


Note: languages accepted by the College of Letters & Science are not automatically accepted by the Global Studies major. Please check with an adviser for eligible languages.


How to fulfill the foreign language requirement:


There are a variety of ways to fulfill the four-semester language requirement for Global Studies, depending on the individual and his or her background and ability.


Advanced Placement (AP) or International Baccalaureate (IB) test: An AP score of 5 or an International Baccalaureate (IB) score of 7 will complete this requirement. An AP score of 4 should generally place a student into the fourth-semester college level course. A score of 3 will place a student into the third-semester college level course. Documentation of AP scores must be provided.


Coursework: Any combination of college courses, summer programs, or college-level study abroad programs can satisfy the language requirement. At a minimum, students must complete the fourth semester (i.e., the second semester of intermediate level) of a language with a grade of C- or better in order to fulfill the requirement. The first, second, and third semester courses may be taken on a Pass/No Pass basis.


Language courses need not be taken at UCB. Courses taken at a community college or any accredited school or university may be acceptable. Transcripts must be submitted and evaluated by an adviser. A one-semester upper division course taken abroad in the target language may satisfy the foreign language requirement, depending on the school and program followed. For more information, see an adviser concerning language study abroad.


High school completion in a non-English language and Proficiency Tests: Students with native, advanced background or those who were educated in a non-English language through the completion of high school or the equivalent may wish to satisfy this requirement with that experience. This requires a language proficiency exam. Moreover, it limits the geographic focus within global studies, because it must be connected to language. This is not especially recommended, as it limits what students within the major can study.


Chinese, Japanese, and Korean proficiency exams are administered by East Asian Languages and Cultures (EALC) on the Tuesday before instruction starts every semester. Check the EALC website at http://ealc.berkeley.edu/programs/undergraduate/proficiency-exams. Results of the exam will indicate the level of the foreign language that students are eligible to register for. In order to waive the language requirement, test results must show that the student has completed the equivalent of four semesters of language studies (end of intermediate level) or higher.


Note: EALC waitlists all students that register for language courses regardless of when registration takes place, and the department scheduler adjusts student enrollment based on the results of the placement exam during the first week of instruction.


Students planning to take a proficiency exam in a non-Asian language in order to waive the language requirement should consult with an IAS adviser. Proficiency tests may be taken once per semester.

For more information:

https://globalstudies.berkeley.edu/degree-programs/major-programs/global-studies/

PREPARATION FOR TRANSFER AT THE JUNIOR LEVEL


Students will gain competence in both ancient Greek and Latin and have the opportunity to read literary, philosophical, and historiographical texts in their original form.


To satisfy Greek 1 + Greek 2 or Latin 1 + Latin 2, students may enroll in the summer workshops at Berkeley: Greek 15 and Latin 15.


Prior Language Experience

After matriculating to Berkeley, students who have studied Latin may sign up to take a placement diagnostic to determine the appropriate course to begin the study of Latin at Berkeley. There is no diagnostic for Greek placement. Please consult with the instructor of the Greek course you think is appropriate for your experience.


Students who score 5 in AP Latin may be placed out of Elementary Latin and have that requirement waived.


After enrolling at UC Berkeley, UCB AGRS R44 (Classics of the Ancient Mediterranean World) may be substituted for either AGRS 10A or AGRS 10B.


Prerequisites

Students are required to successfully (grade C or higher) complete one Greek or Latin course at UC Berkeley before declaring the major.


More Information

The Berkeley Catalog and the department website provide more information about major requirements and course information.


Advising:

Students with questions about transferring into the major in Greek & Latin are encouraged to contact our undergraduate major advisor(UMA):

Cassandra Dunn

Department Website: https://dagrs.berkeley.edu/

Email: cassandrajj@berkeley.edu

Appointments: Schedule an appointment (in-person or remotely).

A score of 4 or 5 on the AP Art History exam may satisfy one lower division survey requirement.

PREPARATION FOR TRANSFER AT THE JUNIOR LEVEL


Transfer students should see the department's undergraduate adviser to receive approval of transfer credit for history of art courses taken elsewhere.


Major Requirements:

A. Three History of Art Courses (9-12 units) Additional requirement: These three courses must include one course in Western art and one course in non-Western art.

B. One Art Practice/Materials Course (2-4 units)


See the History of Art’s website https://arthistory.berkeley.edu/programs/undergraduate/major-requirements/ for more information.

Transfer students who select this major on their College of Letters and Science (L&S) application and are offered admission to L&S will be directly admitted into this major. If you are interested in this major, it is very important to select this major on your application, and complete as many lower-division major requirements as possible prior to transfer. See details on preparation for this major below.


The History of Art major is designed to give students solid grounding in the many artistic traditions that comprise historical and contemporary visuality. Further it prepares students to do independent research, to evaluate evidence (visual and textual), and to create coherent sustained arguments. In a series of increasingly focused courses, the major provides a format for students to learn how to analyze and interpret visual and material evidence from specific cultural settings and historical circumstances. Major requirements are designed to maximize exposure to different traditions, while allowing enough flexibility for individual students to develop and pursue their own particular areas of interest and a coherent area of focus.


For more information:

Major Advisor, History of Art Department

(510) 643-7290

https://arthistory.berkeley.edu/undergraduate/major-requirements

general_texts:
Admission to the UC Berkeley College of Engineering is highly competitive.


Applicants to the Industrial Engineering and Operations Research major must complete all required core UCB preparation courses in order to be eligible for admission. Only applicants who have completed 100% of these required courses will be considered for admission. Required courses for admission to the major must be completed by the end of the spring semester prior to fall enrollment. A summer 2026 course is not considered to be "work in progress" for the fall 2026 selection process.


If a series of courses at a community college is required (e.g., Chemistry 101 + 102 + 103=Chemistry A and B), all the courses in the series must be completed, and must (unless otherwise indicated) be completed at the same community college. Partial completion (e.g., 2 of the 3 required courses) will result in zero credit toward the requirement(s), and the applicant will NOT be considered for admission. The only exception to the series rule is Math 54. If Math 54 is split into two different courses, one covering linear algebra and one covering differential equations, we strongly encourage applicants to take both courses at the same community college; however, the College of Engineering will accept linear algebra from one school and differential equations from a different school.


Lower division UC Berkeley courses required for graduation (but not admission) are also listed in the major agreements and are strongly recommended to be taken to strengthen one's application. The more of these courses completed, the stronger the application will be.


Required core courses for admission: (all these courses must be completed to be considered for admission)

- UCB CHEM 1A/1AL or BIOLOGY 1A/1AL or BIOLOGY 1B

- UCB MATH 51; 52; 53; 54

- UCB PHYSICS 7A; 7B

- UCB READING COMPOSITION A; B

- UCB COMPSCI 61A, COMPSCI C8, or other programming courses


Strongly recommended courses: (if your college offers the courses listed below and they are articulated, taking them will strengthen your application) If no articulation exists, students are strongly encouraged to take an introductory course in electronics or circuits AND a course in Computer Programming


- UCB ENGIN 7

- Nine units from UCB CIV ENG 11; CIV ENG C30 or MEC ENG C85; CIV ENG 60; CIV ENG 70; EECS 16A; EECS 16B; ENGIN 26; ENGIN 29; MAT SCI 45/45L; MEC ENG 40


Articulation subject to completion of a university course

If the above statement is indicated under any of the community college course listed below, you will be required to take an additional course at UC Berkeley in order to complete the requirement.


Admission is primarily based on the completeness of the applicant's lower division preparation and the level of academic achievement reflected in the student's grade point average. The UC applicant essay also plays an important role in the selection process at UC Berkeley. The College reviews the essay for evidence of interest in the student's chosen field and a thoughtful match between the academic program and the student's academic and career objectives.


The College of Engineering requires six humanities/social science courses, two of which must be reading and composition. The only non-technical admission requirement for the College of Engineering is the coursework equivalent to UC Berkeley's Reading and Composition A and B, which must be taken for a letter grade. The College of Engineering does not recognize the Intersegmental General Education Transfer Curriculum (Cal-GETC/IGETC) and strongly discourages students from following this option due to the number of major-specific technical courses required for engineering transfer admission.


NOTE: The Reading and Composition requirements cannot be satisfied by Cal-GETC/IGETC; applicants must complete the specific courses indicated as Reading and Composition A and B equivalents to be considered for admission. Failure to complete the exact courses listed will mean the applicant will NOT be considered for admission.


The remaining four humanities/social science requirement courses are not considered for admission purposes but are required for graduation. See http://engineering.berkeley.edu/hss for the College of Engineering humanities/social science breadth requirements and courses. Courses which are three semester units or more that appear in the following categories on the "General Education/Breadth" section of assist.org may be used to satisfy two of the remaining four humanities/social science course requirements for the College of Engineering. ARTS AND LITERATURE; HISTORICALSTUDIES; INTERNATIONAL STUDIES; PHILOSOPHY AND VALUES; SOCIAL AND BEHAVIORAL SCIENCES. Additionally, courses that teach a foreign language may be used to satisfy this requirement.


SAT/ACT/A-level test scores and letters of recommendation are NOT considered for admission.


NOTE: ALL REQUIRED COURSES AND ALL STRONGLY RECOMMENDED COURSES FOR THE MAJOR MUST BE TAKEN FOR A LETTER GRADE. FOR MORE INFORMATION, PLEASE CHECK THE COLLEGE'S WEB SITE FOR THE COLLEGE OF ENGINEERING UNDERGRADUATE GUIDE.


For more information:

http://engineering.berkeley.edu/admissions/undergraduate-admissions


College of Engineering Undergraduate Guide:

http://engineering.berkeley.edu/academics/undergraduate-guide


For more information on Industrial Engineering & Operations Research:

http://www.ieor.berkeley.edu


For more information on admission to UC Berkeley:

http://admissions.berkeley.edu


For more information on majors at UC Berkeley:

https://undergraduate.catalog.berkeley.edu/

Some Advanced Placement, International Baccalaureate, and A-Level exams can fulfill requirements in the College of Engineering. For details, please see https://engineering.berkeley.edu/students/undergraduate-guide/exams/.

Seven-Course Breadth) requirements from your community college complete the following steps:

  2. Click on the down arrow to select: Academic Year, Institution: UC Berkeley, and Agreements with Other Institutions: (Your CA Community College). 
  3. Click on “View Agreements”.
  4. Under “View Agreement by” select “General Education/Breadth”. 
  5. Click on the “General Education/Breadth” radio button, then click on “View Agreement”


Learn more from the UC Berkeley Office of Undergraduate Admission and specifically about transfer admission preparation. 


Review all available majors at UC Berkeley.

Fall 2026 Admission for this Major:

Transfer students who select this major on their College of Letters and Science (L&S) application and are offered admission to L&S will be directly admitted into this major. If you are interested in this major, it is very important to select this major on your application, and complete as many lower-division major requirements as possible prior to transfer. See details on preparation for this major below.


- Select two from the following lists: A,B,C. Only one course can count from each list. Required for admission.

- Math List A: MATH 16A, MATH 51, MATH 53, MATH 54, MATH 55. Only one of MATH 16A or MATH 51 can be used for the major.

- Math List B: MATH 16B, MATH 52, MATH 53, MATH 54, MATH 55. Only one of MATH 16B or MATH 52 can be used for the major.

- Math List C: STAT 2, STAT 20, DATA C8.

- Biology 1A and 1AL. Required for admission.

- Biology 1B. Required for admission.

- Chem 1A and 1AL. Strongly Recommended for admission, required for graduation. For students pursuing health careers, it's recommended to have already completed a year of organic chemistry with lab prior to starting at UC Berkeley.

- Physics 8A or 7A. Strongly Recommended for admission, required for graduation.

  • Retain all syllabi (including which reference materials and textbooks were used, methods of assessment, learning objectives, and lecture/topic schedules). Unarticulated courses and series must be reviewed by the respective Berkeley department – a course description is insufficient for review. Students must initiate the review process by contacting Integrative Biology academic advisors after admission. 
  • A 2.0 combined major GPA is required. All major requirements must be taken for a letter grade. 
  • Split series articulations not taken on the same campus are not accepted, even from within the same system. Split series must be reviewed independently. 
  • Students are encouraged to take INTEGBI 77A or 77B their first semester for an introduction to the department’s faculty, research, and courses. It’s also a good opportunity to meet students with similar interests and build community.
Exam credit is not accepted in lieu of required or recommended courses for this major.

Integrative Biology spans hierarchical levels from molecules to ecosystems, incorporating many diverse disciplines to unravel the complexity of biology. The department embraces discovery-based approaches to student learning, encouraging independent research and scientific community engagement. Students in Integrative Biology choose specialized upper division courses, with help from academic advisors, that match their interests. Course variety includes field-based organismal biology and evolution, quantitative and population genetics and genomics, animal behavior, paleontology, anatomy, and physiology. Integrative Biology’s focus on comparative biology and evolution provides a lens for understanding our interconnected living world. 


For more information about the full major requirements, sample plans, and student opportunities, visit us at: 

Web: https://ib.berkeley.edu/undergrad 

Email: ibusso@berkeley.edu 

Office: 3060 Valley Life Sciences Building 

Phone: 510-643-8895

Seven-Course Breadth) requirements from your community college complete the following steps:

PREPARATION FOR TRANSFER APPLICANTS


Transfer applicants should become familiar with the Interdisciplinary Studies Field (ISF) major as early as possible in their academic careers. To do this, review the ISF major requirements on the web site below.

Because each student takes a unique set of courses, it is important for students who have been admitted to the College of Letters and Science as prospective ISF majors to contact an ISF adviser to determine the most effective individual program.


Lower division prerequisites to this major consist of two courses:

One "Disciplines" course and one "World Regions" course.


For more information:

Michelle Herrera, Undergraduate Major Advisor

We encourage Students to take Japanese language courses if they are offered at their college. Students will receive transfer credit for language courses taken at their community college. Because language courses vary among colleges, a student may need to repeat an introductory or intermediate-level course if necessary. prior to enrollment at UC Berkeley to ensure timely degree progress. More information on new polices is available on

1) The 7-course pattern (as found in the UC Transfer Admission Eligibility Courses Menu in ASSIST):

·   Two transferable courses in English composition;

·   One transferable course in mathematical concepts and quantitative reasoning;

·   Four transferable college courses chosen from at least two of the following subject areas:

o arts and humanities

o social and behavioral sciences

o physical and biological sciences


AND


2) Major Requirements: 

Follow the guidance on preparation for this major below. 


For more information on L&S General Education requirements:


For information on courses that will satisfy L&S General Education (Essential Skills and

Seven-Course Breadth) requirements from your community college complete the following steps:

  1. Go to "Search below for articulation agreements: Major, department, and campus-specific general education agreements”
  2. Click on the down arrow to select: Academic Year, Institution: UC Berkeley, and Agreements with Other Institutions: (Your CA Community College). 
  3. Click on “View Agreements”.
  4. Under “View Agreement by” select “General Education/Breadth”. 
  5. Click on the “General Education/Breadth” radio button, then click on “View Agreement”


Learn more from the UC Berkeley Office of Undergraduate Admission and specifically about transfer admission preparation. 


Review all available majors at UC Berkeley.

PREPARATION FOR TRANSFER AT THE JUNIOR LEVEL


We encourage Students to take Korean language courses if they are offered at their college. Students will receive transfer credit for language courses taken at their community college. However, all UC Berkeley students must take a placement exam for Korean to ensure enrollment in a course at the correct level for their language skills. Because language courses vary among colleges, a student may need to repeat an introductory or intermediate-level course if necessary. The department undergraduate advisor will work with students to create a program plan to complete their major requirements by their expected graduation date, regardless of which language course is their first. 


We also offer specific courses for students who are heritage learners. These courses are designated with an X or Y suffix. X is the equivalent of A, and Y is the equivalent of B; for example, the heritage course for the first semester introductory is KOREAN 1X and it meets the exact requirement as does KOREAN 1A.


Please note: Advanced Placement (AP) and International Baccalaureate (IB) exams will not satisfy the requirements for this major.


Prerequisites

Students are required to successfully (grade C or higher) complete one Korean Language course at UC Berkeley and Korean 7A or 7B before declaring the major.


More Information

The Berkeley Catalog and the department website provide more information about major requirements and course information.


Advising:

Students with questions about transferring into the major in Chinese Language are encouraged to contact our undergraduate major advisor(UMA):

Cassandra Dunn

Department Website: https://ealc.berkeley.edu/

Email: cassandrajj@berkeley.edu

Appointments: Schedule an appointment (in-person or remotely).

All courses required for admission, including General Education/Breadth requirements, must be taken for a letter grade.


Course work must be completed by the end of the spring term that precedes fall enrollment at Berkeley.


Students may use Advanced Placement (AP), A-Level Exams, and International Baccalaureate (IB) coursework to satisfy certain requirements. View our CED Advising website for more information on High School Exam Credit 


The College of Environmental Design (CED) will accept Cal-GETC/IGETC or Reading and Composition plus 7-Course Breadth to satisfy the General Education Requirements.


Cal-GETC/IGETC certification will fulfill some, but not all, of the lower division admissions requirements for the College of Environmental Design. Students must still complete all of the Lower-Division Major Requirements listed above.


IMPORTANT: Students applying to the College of Environmental Design should select breadth courses from the following lists with these caveats:


1. No more than two CED courses (Architecture, Landscape Architecture, Environmental Design, Urban Studies, and City and Regional Planning) may be used to fulfill CED's breadth requirements.


2. No more than two courses offered by the same department may be used towards the seven breadth requirements.


7 COURSE BREADTH REQUIREMENT


Take one course from each of the following seven areas:


ARTS AND LITERATURE: Courses that involve significant engagement with arts, literature, or language (excluding language instruction or the acquisition of technical skills), either through practical engagement with works of art or through the creation of art. (see approved course list below)


BIOLOGICAL SCIENCE: Take one of the following courses: ANTHRO 1, BIOLOGY 1B, ESPM 2, ESPM 6, ESPM C10, ESPM 40, ESPM 42, INTEGBI C32, LD ARCH 12, PLANTBI 40 (see approved course list below)


HISTORICAL STUDIES: Most courses in the department of History, and other courses that deal primarily with the human events, institutions, and activities of the past. (see approved course list below)


INTERNATIONAL STUDIES: An in depth education of political, cultural, artistic and/or socio-economic life centered on both a country or region other than the United States and in the contemporary period. (see approved course list below)


PHILOSOPHY AND VALUES: Most courses in the department of Philosophy, plus courses with a major focus on religion, ethics, legal values, or leading philosophical figures. (see approved course list below)


PHYSICAL SCIENCE: Take one of the following: CHEM 1A, EPS 3, EPS 7, EPS 10, EPS 20, EPS C20, EPS 50, EPS 80, EPS 81, PHYSICS 7A or PHYSICS 8A (see approved course list below)


SOCIAL AND BEHAVIORAL SCIENCES: Many courses in the departments of Economics, Legal Studies, Political Science, Sociology, Social Welfare, and many courses in anthropology, geography, and psychology. A variety of courses from other disciplines and some advanced language courses with a significant linguistic component are also acceptable. (see approved course list below)

This major is offered by the College of Environmental Design (CED).


The undergraduate curriculum in Landscape Architecture centers upon creative and ecologically tuned design and introduces students to the breadth of knowledge common to the profession. At the heart of the undergraduate curriculum are three upper division studio courses that students take at UC Berkeley. The core studios ensure that undergraduate students benefit from the department's full range of interests and expertise.


The undergraduate studio experience rests upon a foundation of professional courses in four key areas:


(1) design skills and methods, including the lower division design courses, landscape architecture history, and computer methods;

(2) ecological analysis, with courses in ecology and geography;

(3) planting design (two courses supplemented with an integrative biology requirement); and

(4) topographic design.


The undergraduate program leads to the B.A. degree in Landscape Architecture and provides the necessary education for students interested in either entry-level professional practice, graduate work in Landscape Architecture or further studies in a related environmental design field. The B.A. degree is certified by the State of California and counts as part of the education/experience requirement of the U.N.E. licensing exam. For more information regarding licensing or career options, visit the website of the American Society of Landscape Architects at http://www.asla.org.


MINIMUM ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS FOR ADMISSION


For information about admission to the Landscape Architecture major in the College of Environmental Design, see CED's prospective student website: http://ced.berkeley.edu/admissions/undergraduate/transfer-applicants/


-The personal insight question section on the UC application is important in the selection process at Berkeley. The College reviews the personal insight questions for evidence of the student's interest in the chosen field and a thoughtful match between the academic program and the student's academic and career objectives.


-A minimum 3.0 overall UC transferable grade-point average is required for admission consideration.


-All courses required for admission, including breadth requirements, must be taken for a letter grade


-For a competitive application, coursework should be completed by the end of the spring term that precedes fall enrollment at UC Berkeley.


-As a community college transfer applicant you must complete, at a minimum, course work identified on assist.org as comparable to the following UC Berkeley courses:


LOWER-DIVISION MAJOR REQUIREMENTS

  1. Environmental Design 1
  2. Landscape Architecture 1 
  3. If your college does not offer courses articulated with Landscape Architecture 1 the requirement can be satisfied with Architecture 11A 
  4. If you are satisfying the requirement with Architecture 11A completing Architecture 11B in addition will be value added and strengthen your application for admission.
  5. Biological Science: ANTHRO 1, BIOLOGY 1B, ESPM 2, ESPM 6, ESPM C10, ESPM 40, ESPM 42, INTEGBI C32, LD ARCH 12, PLANTBI 40 (this course will also fulfill CED's Biological Science breadth requirement)
  6. Physical Science: CHEM 1A, EPS 3, EPS 7, EPS 10, EPS 20, EPS C20, EPS 50, EPS 80, EPS 81, PHYSICS 7A or PHYSICS 8A (this course will also fulfill CED’s Physical Science breadth requirement)
  7. Additional courses that can count for either Biological Science or Physical Science (not both): EPS 82, ESPM 15, GEOG 40


Courses required for the Landscape Architecture major’s LOWER-DIVISION MAJOR REQUIREMENTS may also be used to complete the General Education requirement for admission, this includes CED Breadth or Cal-GETC/IGETC. For questions about Cal-GETC/IGETC certification, check with your community college counselor for more information.


GENERAL EDUCATION/BREADTH REQUIREMENTS

READING AND COMPOSITION (R&C)

Reading and Composition A

Reading and Composition B


SEVEN-COURSE BREADTH

Arts & Literature

Biological Science (ANTHRO 1, BIOLOGY 1B, ESPM 2, ESPM 6, ESPM C10, ESPM 40, ESPM 42, INTEGBI C32, LD ARCH 12, PLANTBI 40 (this course will also fulfill the lower-division major requirement)

Historical Studies

International Studies

Philosophy and Values

Physical Science (CHEM 1A, EPS 3, EPS 7, EPS 10, EPS 20, EPS C20, EPS 50, EPS 80, EPS 81, PHYSICS 7A or PHYSICS 8A will also fulfill the lower-division major requirement) Either Biological Science or Physical Science (EPS 82, ESPM 15, GEOG 40 will also fulfill the lower-division major requirement)

Social and Behavioral Sciences


You must fulfill all of the required Lower-Division Major and General Education/Breadth Requirements outlined above to be considered for admission.


If you are using Cal-GETC/IGETC to fulfill CED's College Requirements, you must have full UC certification. Partial certification will not complete the requirements. Be sure to check with your community college about the procedures involved in certification of Cal-GETC/IGETC. The University will require the official certification by the July 1 deadline.


If you will not complete Cal-GETC/IGETC certification, you must follow exactly the articulation agreements between your school and the CED Landscape Architecture major as described on this ASSIST.org website.


Regardless of how you complete the General Education/Breadth Requirements, you must also complete the Lower-Division Major Requirements with articulated courses outlined on ASSIST.org.


Highly recommended but not required: Knowledge of Adobe Suite and Rhinoceros.


For more information on applying to CED:

College of Environmental Design

Office of Undergraduate Advising

250 Bauer Wurster Hall

ced.berkeley.edu/ced/students/undergraduate-advisingcedadvising@berkeley.edu


CED Prospective student website:

https://ced.berkeley.edu/admissions/undergraduate-admissions/transfer-eligibility-requirements


For more information on admission to UC Berkeley:

https://admissions.berkeley.edu/


For more information on majors at UC Berkeley:

https://undergraduate.catalog.berkeley.edu/

All courses required for admission must be taken for a letter grade.


For a competitive application all requirements should be completed by the spring term that precedes fall enrollment. If your college does not offer courses articulated with ENV DES 1, you should find another school that does, or consider a plan to take the course in the summer that precedes fall enrollment at Berkeley. See the CED prospective student website for a list of colleges that offer articulated Environmental Design courses: https://ced.berkeley.edu/admissions/undergraduate-admissions/articulation.


Before applying, you may also wish to look into taking the mandatory Lower-Division Major Requirements at UC Berkeley during the summer (see http://summer.berkeley.edu) or via University Extension Concurrent Enrollment if class space is available (see https://extension.berkeley.edu/static/studentservices/concurrent/).


Some students are able to take one or more of the Lower-Division Major Requirements at UC Berkeley via the Intersegmental Cross-Enrollment program, which allows students who meet certain eligibility criteria AND are enrolled at a California community college to enroll in a maximum of one course per academic term at UC Berkeley on a space-available basis, paying community college fees. (See https://registrar.berkeley.edu/registration/visitor-and-exchange-programs/).


Finally, if it is impossible for you to attend a school that offers courses articulated with the mandatory Lower-Division Major Requirements, you may submit comparable courses for evaluation using the "Evaluation of Transfer Coursework: Prospective Students" form under Transfer Credit Evaluation & Curriculum Petition on this page: https://ced.berkeley.edu/advising/forms-documents

PREPARATION FOR TRANSFER AT THE JUNIOR LEVEL


Students will gain competence in Latin and have the opportunity to read literary, philosophical, and historiographical texts in their original form.


To satisfy Latin 1 + Latin 2, students may enroll in the summer workshops at Berkeley: Greek 15 and Latin 15.


Prior Language Experience

After matriculating to Berkeley, students who have studied Latin may sign up to take a placement diagnostic to determine the appropriate course to begin the study of Latin at Berkeley. Students who score 5 in AP Latin may be placed out of Elementary Latin and have that requirement waived.


After enrolling at UC Berkeley, UCB AGRS R44 (Classics of the Ancient Mediterranean World) may be substituted for either AGRS 10A or AGRS 10B.


Please note: Students preparing for graduate study related to Ancient Graeco-Roman Studies (Classics) are encouraged to major in Greek & Latin to ensure complete preparation.


Prerequisites

Students are required to successfully (grade C or higher) complete one Latin course at UC Berkeley before declaring the major.


More Information

The Berkeley Catalog and the department website provide more information about major requirements and course information.


Advising:

Students with questions about transferring into the major in Latin are encouraged to contact our undergraduate major advisor(UMA):

Cassandra Dunn

Department Website: https://dagrs.berkeley.edu/

Email: cassandrajj@berkeley.edu

Appointments: Schedule an appointment (in-person or remotely).

Each course must be taken for a letter grade.


  1. Statistics

  3. Philosophy- a course in logic or ethics is strongly preferred.
  4. History


AP Exam Information

  • Statistics AP exam: a score of 3 or higher will satisfy the Statistics prerequisite.
  • Micro-Economics AP exam (not the Macro exam): a score of 3 or higher will satisfy the Social/Behavioral Sciences prerequisite.
  • U.S. Govt. & Politics AP exam: a score of 3 or higher will satisfy the Social/Behavioral Sciences prequisite.
  • European History AP exam: a score of 3 or higher will satisfy the prerequisite.
  • U.S. History AP exam: a score of 3 or higher will satisfy the prerequisite.

The undergraduate major in Linguistics introduces students to the traditions and techniques of research into the structure, functions, and histories of languages. Since the study of language draws from and contributes to many other fields of study, students choosing the Linguistics major are strongly urged to achieve a more than superficial acquaintance with some related but independent field: cognitive science, anthropology, mathematics, computer science or philosophy.


PREPARATION FOR TRANSFER AT THE JUNIOR LEVEL


Students interested in the major are advised to take introductory courses in language and linguistics.


There are no lower division prerequisites for the Linguistics major.


For more information:

Undergraduate Major Advisor

general_texts:
Admission to the UC Berkeley College of Engineering is highly competitive.


Applicants to the Materials Science and Engineering major must complete all required core UCB preparation courses in order to be eligible for admission. Only applicants who have completed 100% of these required courses will be considered for admission. Required courses for admission to the major must be completed by the end of the spring semester prior to fall enrollment. A summer 2026 course is not considered to be "work in progress" for the fall 2026 selection process.


If a series of courses at a community college is required (e.g., Chemistry 101 + 102 + 103=Chemistry A and B), all the courses in the series must be completed, and must (unless otherwise indicated) be completed at the same community college. Partial completion (e.g., 2 of the 3 required courses) will result in zero credit toward the requirement(s), and the applicant will NOT be considered for admission. The only exception to the series rule is Math 54. If Math 54 is split into two different courses, one covering linear algebra and one covering differential equations, we strongly encourage applicants to take both courses at the same community college; however, the College of Engineering will accept linear algebra from one school and differential equations from a different school. Lower division UC Berkeley courses required for graduation (but not admission) are also listed in the major agreements and are strongly recommended to be taken to strengthen one's application. The more of these courses completed, the stronger the application will be.


Required core courses for admission: (all these courses must be completed to be considered for admission)

- UCB CHEM 1A/1AL; 1B

- UCB MATH 51; 52; 53; 54

- UCB PHYSICS 7A; 7B; 7C

- UCB READING COMPOSITION A; B


Strongly recommended courses: (if your college offers the courses listed below and they are articulated, taking them will strengthen your application) If no articulation, students are strongly encouraged to take a course in statics AND a course in Computer Programming.

- UCB ENGIN 7

- UCB MAT SCI 45/45L

- UCB MEC ENG C85/CIV ENG C30

- UCB ENGIN 40

- UCB COMPSCI C8


Admission is primarily based on the completeness of the applicant's lower division preparation and the level of academic achievement reflected in the student's grade point average. The UC applicant essay also plays an important role in the selection process at UC Berkeley. The College reviews the essay for evidence of interest in the student's chosen field and a thoughtful match between the academic program and the student's academic and career objectives.


The College of Engineering requires six humanities/social science courses, two of which must be reading and composition. The only non-technical admission requirement for the College of Engineering is the coursework equivalent to UC Berkeley's Reading and Composition A and B, which must be taken for a letter grade. The College of Engineering does not recognize the Intersegmental General Education Transfer Curriculum (Cal-GETC/IGETC) and strongly discourages students from following this option due to the number of major-specific technical courses required for engineering transfer admission.


NOTE: The Reading and Composition requirements cannot be satisfied by Cal-GETC/IGETC; applicants must complete the specific courses indicated as Reading and Composition A and B equivalents to be considered for admission. Failure to complete the exact courses listed will mean the applicant will NOT be considered for admission. The remaining four humanities/social science requirement courses are not considered for admission purposes but are required for graduation. See http://engineering.berkeley.edu/hss for the College of Engineering humanities/social science breadth requirements and courses. Courses which are three semester units or more that appear in the following categories on the "General Education/Breadth" section of assist.org may be used to satisfy two of the remaining four humanities/social science course requirements for the College of Engineering. ARTS AND LITERATURE; HISTORICAL STUDIES; INTERNATIONAL STUDIES PHILOSOPHY AND VALUES; SOCIAL AND BEHAVIORAL SCIENCES. Additionally, courses that teach a foreign language may be used to satisfy this requirement.


SAT/ACT/A-level test scores and letters of recommendation are NOT considered for admission.


NOTE: ALL REQUIRED COURSES AND ALL STRONGLY RECOMMENDED COURSES FOR THE MAJOR MUST BE TAKEN FOR A LETTER GRADE. FOR MORE INFORMATION, PLEASE CHECK THE COLLEGE'S WEB SITE FOR THE COLLEGE OF ENGINEERING UNDERGRADUATE GUIDE.


For more information:

http://engineering.berkeley.edu/admissions/undergraduate-admissions


College of Engineering Undergraduate Guide:

http://engineering.berkeley.edu/academics/undergraduate-guide


For more information on Materials Science & Engineering:

http://www.mse.berkeley.edu


For more information on admission to UC Berkeley:

http://admissions.berkeley.edu


For more information on majors at UC Berkeley:

https://undergraduate.catalog.berkeley.edu/

Some Advanced Placement, International Baccalaureate, and A-Level exams can fulfill requirements in the College of Engineering. For details, please see https://engineering.berkeley.edu/students/undergraduate-guide/exams/.

Admission to the UC Berkeley College of Engineering is highly competitive.


Applicants to the Mechanical Engineering major must complete all required core UCB preparation courses in order to be eligible for admission. Only applicants who have completed 100% of these required courses will be considered for admission. Required courses for admission to the major must be completed by the end of the spring semester prior to fall enrollment. A summer 2026 course is not considered to be "work in progress" for the fall 2026 selection process.


If a series of courses at a community college is required (e.g., Chemistry 101 + 102 + 103=Chemistry A and B), all the courses in the series must be completed, and must (unless otherwise indicated) be completed at the same community college. Partial completion (e.g., 2 of the 3 required courses) will result in zero credit toward the requirement(s), and the applicant will NOT be considered for admission. The only exception to the series rule is Math 54. If Math 54 is split into two different courses, one covering linear algebra and one covering differential equations, we strongly encourage applicants to take both courses at the same community college; however, the College of Engineering will accept linear algebra from one school and differential equations from a different school. Admission is primarily based on the completeness of the applicant's lower division preparation and the level of academic achievement reflected in the student's grade point average. The College of Engineering requires six humanities/social science courses, two of which must be reading and composition. Seven-Course Breadth) requirements from your community college complete the following steps:

  2. Click on the down arrow to select: Academic Year, Institution: UC Berkeley, and Agreements with Other Institutions: (Your CA Community College). 
  3. Click on “View Agreements”.
  4. Under “View Agreement by” select “General Education/Breadth”. 
  5. Click on the “General Education/Breadth” radio button, then click on “View Agreement”


Learn more from the UC Berkeley Office of Undergraduate Admission and specifically about transfer admission preparation. 


Review all available majors at UC Berkeley.
Exam credits, including AP scores, cannot be used to satisfy the major prerequisites.
ONE COURSE FROM EACH OF THE FOLLOWING FOUR GROUPS:

The Media Studies major integrates perspectives from liberal arts, social sciences, and humanities and offers an interdisciplinary framework to understand the essential role that media plays in economic, social, political, and cultural life. It weds traditions from communication, history, anthropology, sociology, political science, and more with critical theories and cultural studies to analyze the role and meaning of media in our societies. Our emphasis in this major is historical and theoretical, examining media systems, institutions, technologies, policies, and practices. We offer students the analytical tools available to investigate media—old and new, local and global—across the diverse media landscape. The Media Studies major offers three areas of concentration: Digital Studies, Global Cultural Studies, or Media Law and Policy.


Declaring the Media Studies Major


Admission to UC Berkeley with the stated intent to major in Media Studies does not guarantee acceptance into the major. A major declaration is required after arrival at Berkeley. To be eligible to declare the major, students must 1) complete all four prerequisites; 2) have a C or better in each of the four prerequisites; and 3) have a GPA of 2.0 in the prerequisites and any course that applies to the major course requirements. All courses for the major, including prerequisites, must be taken for a letter grade.


Media Studies 10 must be completed at UC Berkeley. Any Media Studies 10 transfer course equivalents completed after summer 2020 will not satisfy the Media Studies 10 requirement. Media Studies 10 is often offered in the summer at UC Berkeley. Summer courses are open to students from other schools. Transfer students are not expected to take Media Studies 10 before applying to UC Berkeley.


Exam (i.e. AP/IB) credit cannot be used to satisfy any major requirements. Students must take courses to satisfy major requirements.


For more information about the Media Studies major, visit the Media Studies website. We encourage students to read it in its entirety. 


Declaring the major as early as possible will better ensure that students can graduate on time.


For more information:

https://mediastudies.ugis.berkeley.edu/


Laura Demir, Student Academic Advisor

mediastudies_advising@berkeley.edu


Chelsea Prieto, Student Academic Advisor

mediastudies_advising@berkeley.edu


Josh Jackson, Assistant Director and Faculty Advisor

joshjackson@berkeley.edu

general_texts:
The Rausser College of Natural Resources (RCNR) admits students directly into one of its nine undergraduate majors as selected by the applicant at the time of application. Because Rausser College does not admit transfer students as undeclared, each individual major has a distinct set of transfer courses required as major preparation before the applicant is minimally eligible for admission.  


Resources for RCNR transfer applicants: 

  • UC Berkeley Office of Undergraduate Admissions Minimum Requirements for Transfer Admission
  • Rausser College of Natural Resources Transfer Applicants page - includes transfer admission guidelines specific to each Rausser College major, as well as additional information on how to submit a competitive application for your intended major 
  • Rausser College Major Requirements and Sample Degree Plans
  • Rausser College Advising Staff

ABOUT THE MICROBIAL BIOLOGY MAJOR


Microbial Biology (MB) is a pivotal field of study because small life forms such as microbes, viruses, and fungi make up the majority of planetary biomass, and constitute key branches of the Tree of Life. Microbes play fundamental roles in maintaining biosphere health: they degrade environmental pollutants; they supply essential nutrients and chemicals directly to multi-cellular organisms, and they engage in numerous beneficial symbioses with higher organisms. Infectious diseases regulate populations of plants and animals, and outbreaks recur in human societies globally.


For additional information, please contact the Microbial Biology advisor at pmb.ugrad@berkeley.edu.

Please Note: Applicants are expected to complete all required coursework by the end of the spring term prior to admission. Majors may allow one course pending in the summer term prior to admission if the major has more than five required courses and at least five courses of the required coursework have been completed; in this case, if a requirement includes both a lecture and lab, the lecture and lab together are treated as one course. Majors which require five or fewer required courses to transfer will not allow required coursework to be completed in the summer prior to admission. Please see the Rausser College of Natural Resources Transfer Applicants page for individual requirements by major.


Microbial Biology applicants may have the opportunity to complete a single required course in the summer term prior to admission. If a requirement includes both a lecture and lab, the lecture and lab together are treated as one course.



To ensure full articulation of transfer coursework: if a series of courses at a community college is required (e.g., Chemistry 101 + 102 + 103 = CHEM 1A/1AL + CHEM 1B at UC Berkeley), all of the courses in the series must be completed, and must (unless otherwise indicated) be completed at the same community college. Partial completion of the series (e.g., two of the three required courses) may result in no credit toward the requirement(s), and splitting a series of courses between different community colleges is not guaranteed to satisfy the requirement. Courses taken out of series will be evaluated by college faculty during the transfer admissions process. If you have questions about the articulation of a series for your intended major, please email pmb.ugrad@berkeley.edu.


Minimum Admissions Requirements in Microbial Biology


Equivalent of: 

  • READING & COMPOSITION A + READING & COMPOSTION B - satisfied by full UC IGETC, or may be satisfied with AP/IB/A-Level exam credit
  • CHEM 1A and CHEM 1AL - may also be satisfied by AP/IB/A-Level exam credit
  • CHEM 3A and CHEM 3AL
  • CHEM 3B and CHEM 3BL
  • BIOLOGY 1A and BIOLOGY 1AL
  • BIOLOGY 1B
  • MATH 16A and MATH 16B; or MATH 51 and MATH 52; or MATH 10A and MATH 10B - may also be satisfied by AP/IB/A-Level exam credit



Highly Recommended (but not required) Prior to Transfer

  • STAT 2, STAT 20, or DATA C8 - may also be satisfied by AP/IB/A-Level exam credit
  • PHYSICS 8A - students pursuing a pre-health curriculum may also be required to complete the second half of physics (PHYSICS 8B at Berkeley) which is not required by the Microbial Biology major
  • 15 units of breadth coursework in the social sciences and humanities - satisfied by full UC IGETC, or may be satisfied with AP/IB/A-Level exam credit

COLLEGE ADMISSIONS REQUIREMENTS FOR TRANSFER STUDENTS 


THIS MAJOR IS OFFERED BY THE COLLEGE OF LETTERS AND SCIENCE (L&S)


IMPORTANT information for students applying for admission to L&S for the fall 2025 application cycle and beyond


Completion of Essential Skills requirements (Reading & Composition, Quantitative Reasoning, and Foreign Language) or

Cal-GETC/IGETC will no longer be a requirement for admission; however, completion of either is strongly recommended

prior to enrollment at UC Berkeley to ensure timely degree progress. More information on new polices is available on

the L&S Transfer Student Applicants website. 


By the end of the spring term preceding fall enrollment at Berkeley, you must complete: 


1) The 7-course pattern (as found in the UC Transfer Admission Eligibility Courses Menu in ASSIST):

·   Two transferable courses in English composition;

·   One transferable course in mathematical concepts and quantitative reasoning;

·   Four transferable college courses chosen from at least two of the following subject areas:

o arts and humanities

o social and behavioral sciences

o physical and biological sciences


AND


2) Major Requirements: 

Follow the guidance on preparation for this major below. 


For more information on L&S General Education requirements:


For information on courses that will satisfy L&S General Education (Essential Skills and

Seven-Course Breadth) requirements from your community college complete the following steps:

  1. Go to "Search below for articulation agreements: Major, department, and campus-specific general education agreements”
  2. Click on the down arrow to select: Academic Year, Institution: UC Berkeley, and Agreements with Other Institutions: (Your CA Community College). 
  3. Click on “View Agreements”.
  4. Under “View Agreement by” select “General Education/Breadth”. 
  5. Click on the “General Education/Breadth” radio button, then click on “View Agreement”


Learn more from the UC Berkeley Office of Undergraduate Admission and specifically about transfer admission preparation. 


Review all available majors at UC Berkeley.

In February 2021, UC Berkeley approved the department to change its name to Middle Eastern Languages and Cultures (formerly Near Eastern Studies) and the undergraduate degree to Middle Eastern Languages and Cultures, BA. The new major will commence in fall 2021.


The Middle Eastern Languages and Cultures (MELC) major is the study of the languages, literature, history, and cultures of the Middle East from antiquity to modern times. MELC offers language programs in Arabic, Hebrew, Persian, and Turkish, and in the ancient languages of Egyptian, Sumerian, Akkadian, and Aramaic. Students can explore the interconnected worlds of ancient Egypt, Mesopotamia, and their neighbors, as well as the modern literature and diverse cultures of the modern Middle East. The major also offers study in pre-modern and modern Jewish, Christian, and Islamic traditions. The program offers students the opportunity to participate in a discovery experience that is innovative, collaborative, transdisciplinary, and features digital research.


Languages & Literature


The major in Middle Eastern Language and Cultures offers two specializations: 1) Languages and Literature and 2) Middle Eastern Worlds. Students in the Languages and Literature specialization can pursue a concentration in the modern languages of:·


  • Arabic
  • Hebrew
  • Persian


Middle Eastern Worlds


The Middle Eastern World's specialization is the study of the material, intellectual, and religious histories and cultures of the region from ancient to modern times. Students can pursue a concentration in:·


  • Ancient Middle Eastern Worlds
  • Modern Middle Eastern Worlds


PREPARATION FOR TRANSFER AT THE JUNIOR LEVEL


The Middle Eastern Languages and Cultures (MELC) major requires two lower division courses MELC 10 and MELC 11 and 7 upper division courses in Middle Eastern language and/or culture/history.


Lower-Division Requirements


The major requires MELC 10 (Ancient Egypt & Mesopotamia) and MELC 11 (Intro to the Modern Middle East). MELC 10 and MELC 11 are offered every fall and spring semester respectively.


Lower division requirements if you plan to concentrate in Arabic, Hebrew, or Persian


  • Arabic: Elementary Arabic (Arabic 1A-1B) and Intermediate Arabic (Arabic 20A-20B)
  • Hebrew: Elementary Hebrew (Hebrew 1A-1B) and Intermediate Hebrew (Hebrew 20A-20B)
  • Persian: Elementary Persian (Persian 1A-1B) and Intermediate Persian (Persian 20A-20B)


Upper-Division Courses


Students are required to take 7 upper division courses. Students may take courses from the MELC department or from other departments in the university. All courses for the major must be approved by the faculty major advisor. Please see the Berkeley Academic Guide for more information about the MELC major.


Minors


Minors are also available in Middle Eastern Languages and Cultures (MELC), Arabic, Hebrew, Persian, and in Turkish. The minor requires 5 upper division courses.


For more information:

Rania Shah, Undergraduate Major Advisor Department of Middle Eastern Languages and Cultures

rania.shah@berkeley.edu

(510) 642-3758

https://melc.berkeley.edu/

THIS MAJOR IS OFFERED BY THE COLLEGE OF LETTERS AND SCIENCE (L&S)

prior to enrollment at UC Berkeley to ensure timely degree progress. More information on new polices is available on

1) The 7-course pattern (as found in the UC Transfer Admission Eligibility Courses Menu in ASSIST):

·   Four transferable college courses chosen from at least two of the following subject areas:

o arts and humanities

o physical and biological sciences


AND


2) Major Requirements: 

Follow the guidance on preparation for this major below. 


For more information on L&S General Education requirements:


For information on courses that will satisfy L&S General Education (Essential Skills and

Seven-Course Breadth) requirements from your community college complete the following steps:

  1. Go to "Search below for articulation agreements: Major, department, and campus-specific general education agreements”
  2. Click on the down arrow to select: Academic Year, Institution: UC Berkeley, and Agreements with Other Institutions: (Your CA Community College). 
  3. Click on “View Agreements”.
  4. Under “View Agreement by” select “General Education/Breadth”. 
  5. Click on the “General Education/Breadth” radio button, then click on “View Agreement”


Learn more from the UC Berkeley Office of Undergraduate Admission and specifically about transfer admission preparation. 


Review all available majors at UC Berkeley.

Fall 2026 Admission for this Major:

Transfer students who select this major on their College of Letters and Science (L&S) application and are offered admission to L&S will be directly admitted into this major. If you are interested in this major, it is very important to select this major on your application, and complete as many lower-division major requirements as possible prior to transfer. See details on preparation for this major below.


MINIMUM ADMISSION REQUIREMENTS


You must complete all lower-division requirements, with the exception of physics, before transfer. Complete the equivalent of:


BIOLOGY 1A, BIOLOGY 1AL, + BIOLOGY 1B


CHEMISTRY 1A & CHEMISTRY 1AL

(If interested in track 2 of the Biochemistry & Molecular Biology emphasis, Biological Chemistry, you must also complete the equivalent of CHEMISTRY 1B)


CHEMISTRY 3A, 3AL, 3B, + 3BL


Any two equivalent courses of MATH 51 + MATH 52 + MATH 53 + MATH 54 + MATH 55


NOTE: For students who have Calculus test credit, please note that the MCB major does NOT accept test credit to waive math requirements. If you are able to place out of Math 51, you may substitute Math 51 with an equivalent course to Stats 2, Stats 20, or Stats W21 to count towards the MCB major


Although it is not required for admission, we strongly recommend that you complete one year of calculus-based physics with lab prior to transfer because it may be difficult to enroll in these courses at Berkeley.


Complete the equivalent of:


PHYSICS 8A + PHYSICS 8B or

PHYSICS 7A + PHYSICS 7B

Note: PHYSICS 7C is OPTIONAL for this major


AP/IB information for the major in Molecular and Cell Biology for transfer students:

-Score of 4 or 5 on AP Chemistry satisfies CHEMISTRY 1A/1AL

-Score of 4 or 5 on AP Biology satisfies BIOLOGY 1A/1AL + BIOLOGY 1B

-Score of 5, 6, or 7 on IB Chemistry satisfies Chemistry 1A/1AL

-Score of 5, 6, or 7 on IB Biology satisfies Biology 1B only


The Molecular and Cell Biology Undergraduate Office discourages the use of AP, IB, or A-Level credit to waive lower-division courses. Lack of such coursework at the college level could result in poor performance in upper-division MCB courses. In addition, many health-related graduate and professional programs will not accept AP/IB scores in lieu of coursework completed at a college or university.


The Molecular and Cell Biology major has five emphases. The lower-division requirements are the same for all major emphases except Track 2 of Biochemistry & Molecular Biology (Biological Chemistry) which additionally requires CHEMISTRY 1B.


1. Biochemistry, Biophysics & Structural Biology

Track 1 - Biochemistry & Molecular Biology

Track 2 - Biological Chemistry


2. Cell Biology, Development & Physiology

Track 1 - Cell & Systems Biology

Track 2 - Medical Biology & Physiology


3. Genetics, Genomics, Evolution, & Development

Track 1 - Genetics, Genomics, & Development

Track 2 - Developmental Genetics


4. Immunology & Molecular Medicine

Track 1 - Immunology

Track 2 - Infectious Diseases

Track 3: Immunology & Molecular Medicine


5. Molecular Therapeutics

Track 1 - Molecular Therapeutics

Track 2 - Therapeutics and Disease


For more information on the major in Molecular and Cell Biology:

http://mcb.berkeley.edu/undergrad/

NOTE: For students who have Calculus test credit, please note that the MCB major does NOT accept test credit to waive math requirements. If you are able to place out of Math 51, you may substitute Math 51 with an equivalent course to Stats 2, Stats 20, or Stats W21 to count towards the MCB major


AP/IB information for the major in Molecular and Cell Biology for transfer students:

-Score of 4 or 5 on AP Chemistry satisfies CHEMISTRY 1A/1AL

-Score of 4 or 5 on AP Biology satisfies BIOLOGY 1A/1AL + BIOLOGY 1B

-Score of 5, 6, or 7 on IB Chemistry satisfies Chemistry 1A/1AL

-Score of 5, 6, or 7 on IB Biology satisfies Biology 1B only


The Molecular and Cell Biology Undergraduate Office discourages the use of AP, IB, or A-Level credit to waive lower-division courses. Lack of such coursework at the college level could result in poor performance in upper-division MCB courses. In addition, many health-related graduate and professional programs will not accept AP/IB scores in lieu of coursework completed at a college or university.

general_texts:
The Rausser College of Natural Resources (RCNR) admits students directly into one of its nine undergraduate majors as selected by the applicant at the time of application. Because Rausser College does not admit transfer students as undeclared, each individual major has a distinct set of transfer courses required as major preparation before the applicant is minimally eligible for admission.  


Resources for RCNR transfer applicants: 

  • UC Berkeley Office of Undergraduate Admissions Minimum Requirements for Transfer Admission
  • Rausser College of Natural Resources Transfer Applicants page - includes transfer admission guidelines specific to each Rausser College major, as well as additional information on how to submit a competitive application for your intended major 
  • Rausser College Major Requirements and Sample Degree Plans
  • Rausser College Advising Staff

Please Note: Applicants are expected to complete all required coursework by the end of the spring term prior to admission. Majors may allow one course pending in the summer term prior to admission if the major has more than five required courses and at least five courses of the required coursework have been completed; in this case, if a requirement includes both a lecture and lab, the lecture and lab together are treated as one course. Majors which require five or fewer required courses to transfer will not allow required coursework to be completed in the summer prior to admission. Please see the Rausser College of Natural Resources Transfer Applicants page for individual requirements by major.


Molecular Environmental Biology applicants may have the opportunity to complete a single required course in the summer term prior to admission. If a requirement includes both a lecture and lab, the lecture and lab together are treated as one course.



To ensure full articulation of transfer coursework: if a series of courses at a community college is required (e.g., Chemistry 101 + 102 + 103 = CHEM 1A/1AL + CHEM 1B at UC Berkeley), all of the courses in the series must be completed, and must (unless otherwise indicated) be completed at the same community college. Partial completion of the series (e.g., two of the three required courses) may result in no credit toward the requirement(s), and splitting a series of courses between different community colleges is not guaranteed to satisfy the requirement. Courses taken out of series will be evaluated by college faculty during the transfer admissions process. If you have questions about the articulation of a series for your intended major, please email meb.ugrad@berkeley.edu.


Minimum Admissions Requirements in Molecular Environmental Biology:


Equivalent of: 

  • READING & COMPOSITION A + READING & COMPOSTION B - satisfied by full UC IGETC, or may be satisfied with AP/IB/A-Level exam credit
  • CHEM 1A and CHEM 1AL - may also be satisfied by AP/IB/A-Level exam credit
  • CHEM 3A and CHEM 3AL
  • CHEM 3B and CHEM 3BL
  • BIOLOGY 1A and BIOLOGY 1AL
  • BIOLOGY 1B - may also be satisfied by AP/IB/A-Level exam credit
  • MATH 16A or MATH 51 or MATH 10A; and MATH 52, MATH 16B, MATH 10B, or STAT 2 or STAT C or STAT 20 - may also be satisfied by AP/IB/A-Level exam credit



Highly Recommended (but not required) Prior to Transfer

  • ESPM Environmental Science and ESPM Social Science core courses if offered by your campus - satisfied by full UC IGETC
  • PHYSICS 8A - students pursuing a pre-health curriculum may also be required to complete the second half of physics (PHYSICS 8B at Berkeley) which is not required by the Molecular Environmental Biology major
  • Breadth course in Social & Behavioral Sciences or International Studies; and breadth course in Arts & Literature, Historical Studies or Philosophy & Values - satisfied by full UC IGETC

ABOUT THE MOLECULAR ENVIRONMENTAL BIOLOGY MAJOR


The Molecular Environmental Biology (MEB) major is designed to train students in the organization and function of biological organisms and their integration into the environment. MEB graduates acquire a broad foundation across a breadth of biological core areas, which gives them especially valuable scientific training. The MEB degree prepares students well for graduate education in a biological area, or for careers related to biology and the environment, as well as the spectrum of health and medicine careers.


For additional information, please contact the Molecular Environmental Biology advisor at meb.ugrad@berkeley.edu.

COLLEGE ADMISSIONS REQUIREMENTS FOR TRANSFER STUDENTS 


THIS MAJOR IS OFFERED BY THE COLLEGE OF LETTERS AND SCIENCE (L&S)


IMPORTANT information for students applying for admission to L&S for the fall 2025 application cycle and beyond


Completion of Essential Skills requirements (Reading & Composition, Quantitative Reasoning, and Foreign Language) or

Cal-GETC/IGETC will no longer be a requirement for admission; however, completion of either is strongly recommended

prior to enrollment at UC Berkeley to ensure timely degree progress. More information on new polices is available on

the L&S Transfer Student Applicants website. 


By the end of the spring term preceding fall enrollment at Berkeley, you must complete: 


1) The 7-course pattern (as found in the UC Transfer Admission Eligibility Courses Menu in ASSIST):

·   Two transferable courses in English composition;

·   One transferable course in mathematical concepts and quantitative reasoning;

·   Four transferable college courses chosen from at least two of the following subject areas:

o arts and humanities

o social and behavioral sciences

o physical and biological sciences


AND


2) Major Requirements: 

Follow the guidance on preparation for this major below. 


For more information on L&S General Education requirements:


For information on courses that will satisfy L&S General Education (Essential Skills and

Seven-Course Breadth) requirements from your community college complete the following steps:

  1. Go to "Search below for articulation agreements: Major, department, and campus-specific general education agreements”
  2. Click on the down arrow to select: Academic Year, Institution: UC Berkeley, and Agreements with Other Institutions: (Your CA Community College). 
  3. Click on “View Agreements”.
  4. Under “View Agreement by” select “General Education/Breadth”. 
  5. Click on the “General Education/Breadth” radio button, then click on “View Agreement”


Learn more from the UC Berkeley Office of Undergraduate Admission and specifically about transfer admission preparation. 


Review all available majors at UC Berkeley.

Fall 2026 Admission for this Major

Transfer students who select this major on their College of Letters and Science (L&S) application and are offered admission to L&S will be directly admitted into this major. If you are interested in this major, it is very important to select this major on your application. See details on preparation for this major below.


PREPARATION FOR TRANSFER AT THE JUNIOR LEVEL 


There are no lower division major requirements available for articulation.


Transfer students interested in the major are advised to take introductory courses in Music at their community college.


The lower division requirements listed below must be completed at Berkeley after transfer.


Lower Division Requirements at Berkeley


  • History of Music: Music 70
  • Introduction to Ethnomusicology: Music 80
  • Making Music: Music 90


UC Berkeley Catalog/courses/music/


In addition to the above course preparation, we urge transferees to review the music major program at https://music.berkeley.edu/academics/undergraduate-studies/major-requirements to inform themselves about the music program, student learning goals, and the specific skills and knowledge that they will be expected to demonstrate upon entering music study here.


  • There is no audition to join the Music major, but auditions and placement exams may be required for individual performance and theory courses (MUS 140-series, MUS 150-series, and MUS 160-series). 
  • The Advanced Harmony Placement Exam is optional, required only for students who plan to take elective harmony courses (Music 151A-B-C-D) and who have previously studied four-part chorale-style writing.


For more information: 

Department of Music

(510) 642-2678

musicadvising@berkeley.edu

https://music.berkeley.edu

The Native American Studies Program exists to broaden the understanding of students interested in the history, culture, and contemporary situations of Native Americans in the United States.


The curriculum has been structured to provide courses that deal with both historical and cultural analysis of Native American cultures and contemporary legal and social institutions that affect Native American life. The program not only stresses sound academic preparation in the classroom but also allows students the flexibility to take part in community-oriented education through field work or studies directed towards community situations and problems.


AP scores do not satisfy any major requirements.
