general_texts:
Admission to the UC Berkeley College of Engineering is highly competitive.


Applicants to the Nuclear Engineering major must complete all required core UCB preparation courses in order to be eligible for admission. Only applicants who have completed 100% of these required courses will be considered for admission. Required courses for admission to the major must be completed by the end of the spring semester prior to fall enrollment. A summer 2026 course is not considered to be "work in progress" for the fall 2026 selection process.


If a series of courses at a community college is required (e.g., Chemistry 101 + 102 + 103=Chemistry A and B), all the courses in the series must be completed, and must (unless otherwise indicated) be completed at the same community college. Partial completion (e.g., 2 of the 3 required courses) will result in zero credit toward the requirement(s), and the applicant will NOT be considered for admission. The only exception to the series rule is Math 54. If Math 54 is split into two different courses, one covering linear algebra and one covering differential equations, we strongly encourage applicants to take both courses at the same community college; however, the College of Engineering will accept linear algebra from one school and differential equations from a different school.


Lower division UC Berkeley courses required for graduation (but not admission) are also listed in the major agreements and are strongly recommended to be taken to strengthen one's application. The more of these courses completed, the stronger the application will be.


Required core courses for admission: (all these courses must be completed to be considered for admission)

- UCB CHEM 1A/1AL

- UCB MATH 51; 52; 53; 54

- UCB PHYSICS 7A; 7B; 7C

- UCB READING COMPOSITION A; B


Select one from the following:

- UCB ASTRON 7A

- UCB BIOLOGY 1A/1AL; 1B

- UCB CHEM 1B; 3A/3AL

- UCB MCELLBI 32/32L

- UCB STAT 20


Strongly recommended courses: (if your college offers the courses listed below and they are articulated, taking them will strengthen your application)

- UCB ENGIN 40

- UCB EECS 16A

- UCB ENGIN 7

- UCB MAT SCI 45/45L


Articulation subject to completion of a university course

If the above statement is indicated under any of the community college course listed below, you will be required to take an additional course at UC Berkeley in order to complete the requirement. Admission is primarily based on the completeness of the applicant's lower division preparation and the level of academic achievement reflected in the student's grade point average. The UC applicant essay also plays an important role in the selection process at UC Berkeley. The College reviews the essay for evidence of interest in the student's chosen field and a thoughtful match between the academic program and the student's academic and career objectives.


The College of Engineering requires six humanities/social science courses, two of which must be reading and composition. The only non-technical admission requirement for the College of Engineering is the coursework equivalent to UC Berkeley's Reading and Composition A and B, which must be taken for a letter grade. The College of Engineering does not recognize the Intersegmental General Education Transfer Curriculum (Cal-GETC/IGETC) and strongly discourages students from following this option due to the number of major-specific technical courses required for engineering transfer admission.


NOTE: The Reading and Composition requirements cannot be satisfied by Cal-GETC/IGETC; applicants must complete the specific courses indicated as Reading and Composition A and B equivalents to be considered for admission. Failure to complete the exact courses listed will mean the applicant will NOT be considered for admission. The remaining four humanities/social science requirement courses are not considered for admission purposes but are required for graduation. See http://engineering.berkeley.edu/hss for the College of Engineering humanities/social science breadth requirements and courses. Courses which are three semester units or more that appear in the following categories on the "General Education/Breadth" section of assist.org may be used to satisfy two of the remaining four humanities/social science course requirements for the College of Engineering. ARTS AND LITERATURE; HISTORICAL STUDIES; INTERNATIONAL STUDIES; PHILOSOPHY AND VALUES; SOCIAL AND BEHAVIORAL SCIENCES. Additionally, courses that teach a foreign language may be used to satisfy this requirement.


SAT/ACT/A-level test scores and letters of recommendation are NOT considered for admission.


NOTE: ALL REQUIRED COURSES AND ALL STRONGLY RECOMMENDED COURSES FOR THE MAJOR MUST BE TAKEN FOR A LETTER GRADE. FOR MORE INFORMATION, PLEASE CHECK THE COLLEGE'S WEB SITE FOR THE COLLEGE OF ENGINEERING UNDERGRADUATE GUIDE.


For more information:

http://engineering.berkeley.edu/admissions/undergraduate-admissions


College of Engineering Undergraduate Guide:

http://engineering.berkeley.edu/academics/undergraduate-guide


For more information on Nuclear Engineering:

http://www.nuc.berkeley.edu


For more information on admission to UC Berkeley:

http://admissions.berkeley.edu


For more information on majors at UC Berkeley:

https://undergraduate.catalog.berkeley.edu/

Some Advanced Placement, International Baccalaureate, and A-Level exams can fulfill requirements in the College of Engineering. For details, please see https://engineering.berkeley.edu/students/undergraduate-guide/exams/.

The Rausser College of Natural Resources (RCNR) admits students directly into one of its nine undergraduate majors as selected by the applicant at the time of application. Resources for RCNR transfer applicants: 

  • UC Berkeley Office of Undergraduate Admissions Minimum Requirements for Transfer Admission
  • Rausser College of Natural Resources Transfer Applicants page - includes transfer admission guidelines specific to each Rausser College major, as well as additional information on how to submit a competitive application for your intended major 
  • Rausser College Major Requirements and Sample Degree Plans
  • Rausser College Advising Staff

ABOUT THE NUTRITION & METABOLIC BIOLOGY MAJOR


The Nutrition & Metabolic Biology major at UC Berkeley provides a strong foundation in the biological and chemical sciences. Students are educated in the experimental biology of metabolic regulation, the impact of genetics on use of dietary constituents, and the interaction among genetics, health/chronic disease and dietary chemicals. This program prepares students to perform research into the relationship between diet and vertebrate development and well-being mechanistically, and/or for health professional careers.


For additional information, please contact the Nutritional Sciences advisor at nst.ugrad@berkeley.edu.

Please Note: Applicants are expected to complete all required coursework by the end of the spring term prior to admission. Majors may allow one course pending in the summer term prior to admission if the major has more than five required courses and at least five courses of the required coursework have been completed; in this case, if a requirement includes both a lecture and lab, the lecture and lab together are treated as one course. Majors which require five or fewer required courses to transfer will not allow required coursework to be completed in the summer prior to admission. Please see the Rausser College of Natural Resources Transfer Applicants page for individual requirements by major.


Nutrition & Metabolic Biology applicants may have the opportunity to complete a single required course in the summer term prior to admission. If a requirement includes both a lecture and lab, the lecture and lab together are treated as one course.



To ensure full articulation of transfer coursework: if a series of courses at a community college is required (e.g., Chemistry 101 + 102 + 103 = CHEM 1A/1AL + CHEM 1B at UC Berkeley), all of the courses in the series must be completed, and must (unless otherwise indicated) be completed at the same community college. Partial completion of the series (e.g., two of the three required courses) may result in no credit toward the requirement(s), and splitting a series of courses between different community colleges is not guaranteed to satisfy the requirement. Courses taken out of series will be evaluated by college faculty during the transfer admissions process. If you have questions about the articulation of a series for your intended major, please email nst.ugrad@berkeley.edu.


Minimum Admissions Requirements in Nutrition & Metabolic Biology:


Equivalent of: 

  • READING & COMPOSITION A + READING & COMPOSTION B - satisfied by full UC IGETC, or may be satisfied with AP/IB/A-Level exam credit
  • NUSCTX 10
  • CHEM 1A and CHEM 1AL - may also be satisfied by AP/IB/A-Level exam credit
  • CHEM 3A and CHEM 3AL
  • CHEM 3B and CHEM 3BL
  • BIOLOGY 1A and BIOLOGY 1AL
  • MCELLBI 32 and MCELLBI 32L
  • MATH 16A and MATH 16B; or MATH 51 and MATH 52 - may also be satisfied by AP/IB/A-Level exam credit
  • STAT 2 - may also be satisfied by AP/IB/A-Level exam credit



Highly Recommended (but not required) Prior to Transfer

  • PHYSICS 8A - students pursuing a pre-health curriculum may also be required to complete the second half of physics (PHYSICS 8B at Berkeley), which is not required by the Nutrition & Metabolic Biology major
  • 14 units of breadth coursework in the social sciences, humanities, or foreign languages - satisfied by full UC IGETC, or may be satisfied with AP/IB/A-Level exam credit

  3. Click on “View Agreements”.
  4. Under “View Agreement by” select “General Education/Breadth”. 
  5. Click on the “General Education/Breadth” radio button, then click on “View Agreement”


Learn more from the UC Berkeley Office of Undergraduate Admission and specifically about transfer admission preparation. 


Review all available majors at UC Berkeley.

Our undergraduate program aims to provide a broad and solid background in fundamental physics through introductory course work, and then to engage all our majors who are interested in current research with some of the top research groups worldwide. We believe a Physics degree represents strong training for a broad range of careers. Approximately half of our recent graduates have continued to graduate school in Physics and related fields; others have taken jobs in high tech industries or as management consultants, and still others have entered medical school or law school. We aim to help our majors develop strong mathematical and analytical skills, good laboratory skills, effective written and oral communication skills, and of course a solid understanding of the fundamental laws that govern the universe.


Learn more about UC Berkeley physics on our website:

https://physics.berkeley.edu/academics/undergraduate-degree/the-major-and-minor-program


For more information:

Location: UC Berkeley Department of Physics, Physics Building, Berkeley, CA 94720-7300

Email: physics-student-services@lists.berkeley.edu

Required lower-division requirements for transfer students:

  • Math 51, Math 52, Math 53, Math 54
  • Physics 7A, 7B, and 7C


MATHEMATICS

Must complete math courses prior to transferring.


  • Physics major transfer students are expected to have completed all physics and mathematics program prerequisites. Physics 89 (Introduction to Mathematical Physics) at UC Berkeley is strongly recommended during the summer prior to first semester at UCB or post-admission during the first semester at UCB. Students who have not completed Math 54 prior to admission as transfer students will be required to complete Physics 89 instead of Math 54 at UC Berkeley.


  • Those not familiar with the Python programming language are urged to take Physics 77, Data Science 8 or the equivalent.


  • If your course work has not been approved for articulation with the Berkeley equivalent requirements listed above, retain syllabi and reading lists for evaluation by the department and proactively contact a Berkeley physics advisor upon enrollment to check how the missing courses will impact academic planning.


  • For the Physics 7-series equivalent courses, if the entire series is not completed at the same community college, it will be the student’s responsibility to learn the missing topics via Physics 49 once at UC Berkeley. This will ensure adequate foundation for upper division courses. Contact your physics major advisor at UC Berkeley for more information and guidance, once accepted to the program.


  • Once enrolled in UC Berkeley, we recommend that students enroll in the Berkeley Pre-Core Transfer Summer Program in the summer before their first semester at UC Berkeley in order to be better prepared to take on the academic rigor of the physics major by building technical skills and a community of support and resources.
The Physics Department at UC Berkeley does not accept AP or IB Physics exams for satisfying requirements.

Completion of Essential Skills requirements (Reading & Composition, Quantitative Reasoning, and Foreign Language) or

Cal-GETC/IGETC will no longer be a requirement for admission; however, completion of either is strongly recommended

prior to enrollment at UC Berkeley to ensure timely degree progress. More information on new polices is available on

the L&S Transfer Student Applicants website. 


By the end of the spring term preceding fall enrollment at Berkeley, you must complete: 


1) The 7-course pattern (as found in the UC Transfer Admission Eligibility Courses Menu in ASSIST):

·   Two transferable courses in English composition;

·   One transferable course in mathematical concepts and quantitative reasoning;

·   Four transferable college courses chosen from at least two of the following subject areas:

o arts and humanities

o social and behavioral sciences

o physical and biological sciences


AND


2) Major Requirements: 

Follow the guidance on preparation for this major below. 


For more information on L&S General Education requirements:


For information on courses that will satisfy L&S General Education (Essential Skills and

Seven-Course Breadth) requirements from your community college complete the following steps:

  1. Go to "Search below for articulation agreements: Major, department, and campus-specific general education agreements”
  2. Click on the down arrow to select: Academic Year, Institution: UC Berkeley, and Agreements with Other Institutions: (Your CA Community College). 
  3. Click on “View Agreements”.
  4. Under “View Agreement by” select “General Education/Breadth”. 
  5. Click on the “General Education/Breadth” radio button, then click on “View Agreement”


Learn more from the UC Berkeley Office of Undergraduate Admission and specifically about transfer admission preparation. 


Review all available majors at UC Berkeley.

Political Economy Major Requirements


- Completion of GLOBAL 45/POLECON C45 with a grade of B- or better and ECON 1 or 2 with a grade of C or better are required to declare the PE major. NOTE: Berkeley's ECON 1 and 2 cover macro-economics and micro-economics. GLOBAL 45/POLECON C45 is offered during the summer, fall, and spring semesters on the Berkeley campus only.


- All PE majors must be able to demonstrate proficiency in a modern language other than English equivalent to four college- level semesters (or two years). There are several ways to fulfill the language requirement:


Advanced Placement exam: A score of 5 on the AP Language (not Literature) exam.


Proficiency test: Proficiency tests are available to students with native language proficiency in many, but not all, languages. Students who intend to fulfill the language requirement by passing a proficiency test should speak with a PE advisor as soon as possible to ensure that proficiency tests are offered in their language.


Students with native, advanced background or those who were educated in a non-English language through the completion of high school or the equivalent may wish to satisfy this requirement with that experience. This requires a language proficiency exam.


Course-work: Students who cannot fulfill the language requirement using one of the above methods should take as many semesters of foreign language as possible before transferring. NOTE: High school language course credit does not satisfy the foreign language requirement.


Advanced Placement (AP) exams can satisfy the following requirements for the PE major:

- Economics AP: a score of 4 or 5 on BOTH the Macro AND Micro exams satisfies UCB ECON 1.

- Statistics AP: a score of 3 satisfies the Statistics requirement for the PE major.

- Foreign Language (not Literature) AP: a score of 5 satisfies the four-semester foreign language requirement.


After Enrolling at UC Berkeley


- must have a cumulative UC Berkeley GPA of 2.7 or higher


AND


- must have completed GLOBAL 45/POLECON C45 with a grade of B- or higher on the 1st attempt


﻿Students who do not earn a B- or higher in GLOBAL 45/POLECON C45 in their 1st attempt will not be eligible to declare the Political Economy major, regardless of the semester in which GLOBAL 45/POLECON C45 was taken.

Political Economy (PE) examines the relationship between politics and economics in modern societies and focuses on problems of both domestic and international policy. Based on the assumption that political-economic relationships are affected by any number of factors, such as society, culture, geography, and demographics, the curriculum is both multi- and interdisciplinary in scope. The focus of the major is on contemporary issues, although a strong historical perspective is also emphasized. Students may also study planning and problem solving, environmental issues, resource distribution, and the challenges of institutional adaptation, and changing political systems.


The major is designed to provide a broad-based liberal arts background, as well as the intellectual skills appropriate for careers in either the public or private sector. Additionally, the major offers an excellent background for students planning postgraduate careers in social science disciplines and professional schools.


Some of the questions addressed in the major include:

-the tension between rising consumer demand and the need to minimize resource depletion and pollution;

-the different priorities served by capitalist, socialist, and traditionalist varieties of political economy;

-the different priorities served by democratic and authoritarian political systems;

-how international interdependence may undermine the efforts of national governments to cope with unemployment, inflation, trade and payment deficits, health, housing and welfare problems, and other societal issues.

-the importance of organizational structures for policy-making in both the public and private sector.


For more information:

https://politicaleconomy.berkeley.edu/courses-of-study/the-political-economy-major/

Review all available majors at UC Berkeley.

PREPARATION FOR TRANSFER AT THE JUNIOR LEVEL


Admission to UC Berkeley with the stated intent to major in Psychology does not guarantee acceptance into the major. A departmental application is required and prerequisites must be met. Completion of Cal-GETC/IGETC certification does not correspond to the completion of the lower-division prerequisites required by the Psychology major.


Psychology Major Declaration Requirements for Transfer Students:


Please read the following carefully as the application requirements

for Psychology have changed for all students, effective Summer 2024 onwards.


1. Minimum of 2.0 Grade Point Average in the lower-division prerequisite courses. 


2. Of the five prerequisites, at least four must be satisfied with letter-graded courses taken at the college level. One may be satisfied with an AP or IBHL exam as indicated below.


3. Transfer students must apply to the major no later than the close of the application window of their second semester at UC Berkeley. Major declaration information and forms are available on the UC Berkeley Psychology website.


4. Most transfer students complete the majority of their lower-division prerequisite courses prior to Berkeley. However, transfer students may fulfill the remaining prerequisites during their first semester at UC Berkeley.


5. Students must enroll in Psych 101 "Research and Data Analysis in Psychology" during their first semester at UC Berkeley to be eligible to declare the major before their second semester. This class is an upper division course specific to the Psychology major at UC Berkeley and is different from other Psychology research method courses you may have previously taken.


Psychology 1

The Psychology 1 requirement may also be satisfied by a score of 4 or better on the AP Psychology exam or a score of 5 or better on the IBHL exam.


BIOLOGICAL SCIENCE: One course

If enrollment in a lab is optional, the lab is not required for this major.


The Biological Science requirement may be satisfied by a score of 4 or 5 in the AP Biology exam or a score of 5 or better on the IBHL exam.


SOCIAL SCIENCE: One course

The Social Science requirement may be satisfied by a score of 4 or 5 on the AP US Government or Comparative Government exam.


QUANTITATIVE: One course

The Psychology major does not accept AP or IBHL credits to fulfill any of the Quantitative requirements.


PSYCHOLOGY RESEARCH & DATA: One course at UC Berkeley

Psych 101 (Research and Data Analysis) must be taken at UC Berkeley the summer before or during the first semester.


NOTE: Different options may be available for satisfying certain requirements. Consult with the advisor in the Psychology department.


For more information:

For more information regarding applying to the major during your first semester at UC Berkeley, please see http://psychology.berkeley.edu or contact an undergraduate adviser at psychsso@berkeley.edu.

Review all available majors at UC Berkeley.

Public health seeks to improve human health through the development and application of knowledge that prevents disease, protects the public from harm, and promotes health throughout the state, the nation, and the world. Students in the Public Health, Bachelor of Arts major will develop and apply knowledge from multiple disciplines for the promotion and protection of the health of the human population. Some areas of study that students have focused on are: Biostatistics, Community Health & Human Development, Environmental Health Sciences, Epidemiology, Health Policy & Management, Infectious Diseases, Nutrition, and Maternal, Child, and Adolescent Health.

Admission to UC Berkeley with the stated intent to major in Public Health does not guarantee acceptance into the major. A departmental application is required and prerequisites must be met. 


Public Health Major Declaration Requirements for Transfer Students:


  1. Transfer students must apply by the end of their first term in attendance at UC Berkeley. Students may only apply to the major once, no exceptions. The application will require unofficial transcripts, essays, a prerequisite GPA calculation form, and a resume. Admissions requirements and application instructions: Undergraduate Admissions
  2. Transfer students must complete all of the lower division prerequisites (mathematics, biology, and social sciences). A minimum grade of "C-" is required for any of the prerequisites.
  3. It is crucial that all students applying to the public health major have a BACK UP MAJOR since admission into the Public Health major is not guaranteed.
  4. In your first year, it is strongly encouraged to enroll in Data C8: Foundations of Data Science. This course is a major requirement, not a prerequisite for the major, however, it will help prepare you for other major course requirements. This is a very technical course, so please plan accordingly. 


Most transfer students complete the majority of their lower-division prerequisite courses prior to UC Berkeley. However, transfer students may fulfill the remaining requirements during their first semester at UC Berkeley. If you have completed all your prerequisites the Spring before you start your first semester at UC Berkeley, you may be eligible to apply in the May application cycle. 


For more information about applying to the major during your first semester at UC Berkeley, read more about the Undergraduate Admissions at Public Health Undergraduate Program or contact an undergraduate advisor at sphug@berkeley.edu.


Did you know that we also offer a Global Public Health Summer Minor? There is no application for the summer minor but there is a declaration and completion form. The GPH Summer Minor consists of 5 courses that can be taken within one or two consecutive summers.


BIOLOGICAL SCIENCE REQUIREMENT 

Seven units from the following Biology classes: BIOLOGY 1A (3); BIOLOGY 1B (4); MCELLBI 32 (3); MCELLBI 38 (3); MCELLBI 50 (4); MCELLBI 55 (3); NEU C61 (3); NUSCTX 10 (3). A minimum grade of "C-" is required. You cannot split any class series.


Lab units do not count towards the seven unit requirement. For example, BIOLOGY 1AL is not required for the major but is usually required with the BIOLOGY 1A lecture. The lab will not be counted for prerequisite units for the public health major. 


You must complete all courses in a series at the same school. Unless the course equivalents are separately specified, do not assume that a sequence can be divided. If a series of courses at a community college is required (e.g., BIOL 101 and 102 and 103 = BIOLOGY 1A & 1AL), all the courses in the series must be completed, and must be completed at the same community college. 


MATHEMATICS REQUIREMENT* 

A part 1 and part 2 from the following. A minimum grade of "C-" is required. Students could potentially mix and match courses but course restrictions may apply.

  • Part 1: Math 51 or Math 1A, Math 10A, Math 16A
  • Part 2: Math 52 or Math 1B, Math 10B, Math 16B


SOCIAL SCIENCES REQUIREMENT* 

Three courses from at least two of the following areas: SOCIOLOGY, ECONOMICS, ANTHROPOLOGY, POLITICAL SCIENCE and PSYCHOLOGY. You cannot split any class series. 


Please note that credit may NOT be earned with both SOCIOL 1 + SOCIOL 3AC; or PSYCH 1 + PSYCH 2; or ECON 1 + ECON 2 + ECON C3. 


LOWER DIVISION REQUIREMENTS

DATA/COMPSCI/INFO/STAT/C8 - Foundations of Data Science 

This is a major requirement, not a prerequisite however it is best to take this course earlier. 


*Advanced Placement (AP) Exam and International Baccalaureate (IB) Exam scores can be used to fulfill Math and Social Sciences requirements. We do not accept AP Exam or IB Exam scores for the Biological Science requirement. More information can be found on our website: Undergraduate Admissions


Berkeley Public Health Undergraduate Program

Berkeley Public Health Undergraduate Admissions Requirements and Instructions

Berkeley Public Health Undergraduate Advising

• Completion of Berkeley's Rhetoric 10 or Rhetoric 20 with a grade of C or better is required to declare the major in Rhetoric.


  • Both Rhetoric 10 and Rhetoric 20 must be taken on campus at UC Berkeley, as equivalent courses are generally not available elsewhere.


  • Students should plan to take one of the two in their first semester at Cal, based on their entry term.


  • While pure Rhetoric courses aren't available at many institutions, and students are unable to meet major requirements before arriving at Cal, there may be courses available that can prepare you for the UC Berkeley Rhetoric major. Courses offered in other departments such as Philosophy, Comparative Literature and English sometimes cover Rhetoric relevant or adjacent topics, and can better prepare you for Rhetoric course offerings at Cal. Feel free to check in with the UCB Rhetoric Undergraduate Advisor for more insight into this.

For more information:

Undergraduate Advisor

rhetoricugadvising@berkeley.edu

510-642-3522

PREPARATION FOR TRANSFER AT THE JUNIOR LEVEL


Prerequisites for this major are not offered at California community colleges; however, students will be admitted to the Scandinavian major without the 2-course elementary language prerequisites and the cultural studies prerequisites Scandinavian 60 and 75 as it is possible to complete all requirements for this major upon admission to UC Berkeley. A choice of one of five concentrations is available: Old Norse Studies, Danish, Finnish, Norwegian, or Swedish language and culture.


The relevant lower-division language prerequisites are applied to one of the five Scandinavian major concentrations upon transfer.


The two cultural studies prerequisites are taken upon entry:

Scandinavian 75 (Nordic Culture and Values) in the Fall Semester and

Scandinavian 60 (Heroic Legends of the North) in the Spring Semester.


The elementary first-year language sequences, noted below, are started during the student's first Fall semester at Berkeley. The required 4-semester language sequence is completed in the two years following admission.


Once admitted, students who have a prior background in their proposed target language (Finnish, Danish, Icelandic, Norwegian, or Swedish) will be required to take a language proficiency test and consult with the department language program coordinator for placement in the correct language course level. The use of Latin 1 and 2 for the Old Norse concentration is also assessed upon admission.


For more information:

Scandinavian Undergraduate Student Services Advisor

(510) 642-4661

issaug@berkeley.edu

https://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/

PREPARATION FOR TRANSFER AT THE JUNIOR LEVEL


As East European and Eurasian languages are not offered at California community colleges, the elementary first-year language sequences are started during the student's first Fall semester at Berkeley for the following: Armenian 1A-1B (Introductory Armenian), Bosnian/Croatian/Serbian 27A-B (Introductory BCS), Czech 26A-B (Introductory Czech), Hungarian 1A-B (Introductory Hungarian), Polish 25A-B (Introductory Polish), and Ukrainian 1A-B (Introductory Ukrainian). The required 4-semester language sequence is therefore completed in the two years following admission.

In 2024-25, Hungarian, Polish, and Ukrainian language courses in the Slavic Department are available for Intersegmental Cross-enrollment, for students enrolled at any California Community College. Courses are taught via synchronous online instruction. Student eligibility, enrollment requisites, and instructor approval may apply.


For more information: https://registrar.berkeley.edu/registration/visitor-and-exchange-programs/

Contact: special_programs@berkeley.edu.


Once admitted, students who have a prior background in their proposed target language (Armenian, BCS, Czech, Hungarian, Polish, or Ukrainian) may be required to take a language proficiency test or to consult with the relevant department language program coordinator for placement in the correct language course level. Students who participated in UC Berkeley Slavic Department language courses prior to admission to UC Berkeley may not have to take a proficiency test.


Lower-division Russian language courses (equivalent of Russian 1, 2, 3 and 4) must be completed prior to transfer for the Russian Language and Literature track; for the Russian Culture emphasis (the track in Russian/East European/Eurasian Cultures), the equivalent of Russian 1 and 2 is preferred, but otherwise Russian 1, 2, 3, and 4 can be taken upon transfer. Once admitted, students who have a prior background in Russian may be required to take a language proficiency test or to consult with the relevant department language program coordinator for placement in the correct language course level.


See the Slavic Department's language placement webpage for more information: https://slavic.berkeley.edu/undergraduate/take-class/language-placement


For more information:


Undergraduate Student Services Advisor, Slavic Languages and Literatures


(510) 642 4661


issaug@berkeley.edu


http://slavic.berkeley.edu/

MAJOR TRACK IN RUSSIAN/EAST EUROPEAN/EURASIAN CULTURES


The major track in Russian/East European/Eurasian Cultures integrates the study of languages and cultures of a large area: Russia, Eastern/Central Europe and Eurasia. While all majors will be exposed to the knowledge of the whole area, this track allows each student to focus either on one specific cultural region or to combine different regions in their studies (e.g. Russian culture, the cultures of Russia and Caucasus; Balkan cultures; Central European cultures).


Each student's program of study must be designed in consultation with and approved by the Major Adviser and will include a language emphasis in one language area as designated below. As East European and Eurasian languages are not offered at California community colleges, the elementary first-year language sequences are started during the student's first fall semester at Berkeley: Armenian 1A-B, BCS 27A-B, Polish 25A-B, Czech 26A-B, Hungarian 1A-1B, or Ukrainian 1A-B. For students emphasizing Russian language for this track, if your community college offers Russian 1 and 2 (Elementary Russian), plan to take it in preparation for transfer; if it is unavailable, you will still be able to complete Russian 1, 2, 3, and 4 once admitted. In summary, the required 4-semester language sequences can be completed in the two years following admission.


Once admitted, students who have a prior background in their proposed target language (Armenian, BCS, Czech, Hungarian, Polish, Russian, or Ukrainian) will be required to take a language proficiency test or to consult with the relevant department language program coordinator for placement in the correct language course level and credit toward relevant lower-division language courses will be applied to the specific set of major requirements.

Introduction to Russian, East European and Eurasian Cultures (SLAVIC 50), which is a prerequisite for this major and is not offered at community colleges, is taken upon admission to Berkeley.

COLLEGE ADMISSIONS REQUIREMENTS FOR TRANSFER STUDENTS 


THIS MAJOR IS OFFERED BY THE COLLEGE OF LETTERS AND SCIENCE (L&S)


IMPORTANT information for students applying for admission to L&S for the fall 2025 application cycle and beyond


Completion of Essential Skills requirements (Reading & Composition, Quantitative Reasoning, and Foreign Language) or

Cal-GETC/IGETC will no longer be a requirement for admission; however, completion of either is strongly recommended

prior to enrollment at UC Berkeley to ensure timely degree progress. More information on new polices is available on

the L&S Transfer Student Applicants website. 


By the end of the spring term preceding fall enrollment at Berkeley, you must complete: 


1) The 7-course pattern (as found in the UC Transfer Admission Eligibility Courses Menu in ASSIST):

·   Two transferable courses in English composition;

·   One transferable course in mathematical concepts and quantitative reasoning;

·   Four transferable college courses chosen from at least two of the following subject areas:

o arts and humanities

o social and behavioral sciences

o physical and biological sciences


AND


2) Major Requirements: 

Follow the guidance on preparation for this major below. 


For more information on L&S General Education requirements:


For information on courses that will satisfy L&S General Education (Essential Skills and

Seven-Course Breadth) requirements from your community college complete the following steps:

  1. Go to "Search below for articulation agreements: Major, department, and campus-specific general education agreements”
  2. Click on the down arrow to select: Academic Year, Institution: UC Berkeley, and Agreements with Other Institutions: (Your CA Community College). 
  3. Click on “View Agreements”.
  4. Under “View Agreement by” select “General Education/Breadth”. 
  5. Click on the “General Education/Breadth” radio button, then click on “View Agreement”


Learn more from the UC Berkeley Office of Undergraduate Admission and specifically about transfer admission preparation. 


Review all available majors at UC Berkeley.

Social Welfare is a high-demand major.


The five prerequisites must be completed with a minimum letter grade of C prior to enrollment of the first semester at Berkeley.

This applies to courses taken at Berkeley or equivalent courses taken at other institutions.


Note: Prerequisites completed prior to Spring 2006 will count with a C- or P grade.


  • Required Lower-division requirements:
  • Psychology 1, or 2
  • Stats 2, 20, or 21, Soc 5, Poli Sci 3 or any course that satisfies the College of Letters and Science Quantitative Reasoning Requirement
  • Sociology 1, 3, 3A, or 3AC
  • The College of Letters and Science Reading and Composition requirement. (This is a 2-course series. At UCB: Reading and Composition A + Reading and Composition B)
  • Highly recommended lower-division requirements:
  • It is suggested that three other courses (introductory anthropology, introductory economics, and introductory political science, as listed below) should be taken as preparation for the major, but these courses are not required to declare the major.
• AP Psychology - 3 or higher

The Social Welfare undergraduate major is a designated “group major” grounded in the liberal arts, rather than specialized training in the profession of social work. The curriculum, as reflected in the core major courses, focuses both on the history and

institutions of social work as a field of activity and on the welfare state as a collective enterprise addressing human need. Students gain knowledge of organized networks of public and private social services, and the basic practice methods associated

with the social work profession. In doing so, students acquire the knowledge needed to understand, address, and actively participate in the amelioration of critical social problems in American Society.


For more information:

Jeremy Urban, Undergraduate Major Advisor

UC Berkeley School of Social Welfare

email: swugadvisor@berkeley.edu

https://socialwelfare.berkeley.edu/

general_texts:
The Rausser College of Natural Resources (RCNR) admits students directly into one of its nine undergraduate majors as selected by the applicant at the time of application. Because Rausser College does not admit transfer students as undeclared, each individual major has a distinct set of transfer courses required as major preparation before the applicant is minimally eligible for admission.  


Resources for RCNR transfer applicants: 

  • UC Berkeley Office of Undergraduate Admissions Minimum Requirements for Transfer Admission
  • Rausser College of Natural Resources Transfer Applicants page - includes transfer admission guidelines specific to each Rausser College major, as well as additional information on how to submit a competitive application for your intended major 
  • Rausser College Major Requirements and Sample Degree Plans
  • Rausser College Advising Staff

ABOUT THE SOCIETY & ENVIRONMENT MAJOR


Social and environmental problems are deeply intertwined. This major introduces students to the main approaches and theory for environmental social sciences, including how social science tools can be applied to environmental problems, and how social science theories contribute to understanding environmental problems.  At the upper division level there are three major areas of concentration. Students are exposed to all three areas and choose to focus in one:  U.S. Environmental Policy and Management, Global Environmental Politics, or Justice & Sustainability.


For additional information, please contact the Society & Environment advisor at soc.env.ugrad@berkeley.edu.

Please Note: Applicants are expected to complete all required coursework by the end of the spring term prior to admission. Majors may allow one course pending in the summer term prior to admission if the major has more than five required courses and at least five courses of the required coursework have been completed; in this case, if a requirement includes both a lecture and lab, the lecture and lab together are treated as one course. Majors which require five or fewer required courses to transfer will not allow required coursework to be completed in the summer prior to admission. Please see the Rausser College of Natural Resources Transfer Applicants page for individual requirements by major.


Society & Environment applicants may have the opportunity to complete a single required course in the summer term prior to admission. If a requirement includes both a lecture and lab, the lecture and lab together are treated as one course.



To ensure full articulation of transfer coursework: if a series of courses at a community college is required (e.g., Chemistry 101 + 102 + 103 = CHEM 1A/1AL + CHEM 1B at UC Berkeley), all of the courses in the series must be completed, and must (unless otherwise indicated) be completed at the same community college. Partial completion of the series (e.g., two of the three required courses) may result in no credit toward the requirement(s), and splitting a series of courses between different community colleges is not guaranteed to satisfy the requirement. Courses taken out of series will be evaluated by college faculty during the transfer admissions process. If you have questions about the articulation of a series for your intended major, please email soc.env.ugrad@berkeley.edu.


Minimum Admissions Requirements in Society & Environment:


Equivalent of: 

  • READING & COMPOSITION A + READING & COMPOSTION B - satisfied by full UC IGETC, or may be satisfied with AP/IB/A-Level exam credit
  • ECON 1, ECON 2, ECON C3, or a transferable course in micro-economics (only one required) - may also be satisfied by AP/IB/A-Level exam credit
  • MATH 16A or MATH 51 or STAT 2 - may also be satisfied by AP/IB/A-Level exam credit
  • Transferable Biological Science breadth course - satisfied by full UC IGETC
  • Transferable Physical Science breadth course - satisfied by full UC IGETC
  • Transferable International Studies breadth course - satisfied by full UC IGETC
  • Transferable Social & Behavioral Sciences breadth course - satisfied by full UC IGETC
  • Transferable Arts & Literature or Historical Studies or Philosophy & Values breadth course (only one required) - satisfied by full UC IGETC



Highly Recommended (but not required) Prior to Transfer

  • ESPM Social Science and ESPM Environmental Science core courses if offered at your institution

Major Requirements

Department of Sociology

Cristina Rojas, Undergraduate Advisor

Seng Saelee, Undergraduate Advisor

(510) 642-4766

 

socadv@berkeley.edu

Transfer students who select this major on their College of Letters and Science (L&S) application and are offered admission to UCB L&S will be directly admitted into this major.


If you are interested in this major, it is very important to select this major on your application, and complete as many lower-division major requirements as possible prior to transfer. See details on preparation for this major below.


REQUIRED COURSES:

Complete the approved lower division courses or their equivalents as listed in the “Lower Division Major Preparation Courses” section of this document:


·      Sociology 1 (Introduction to Sociology) and

·      One course in either statistics or logic.

 

NOTE: The Sociology major has a total of 3 lower division prerequisites. Although some community colleges offer the equivalent of UCB’s Sociology 5 (Evaluation of Evidence), most do not. If an equivalent for UCB’s Sociology 5 is not available at your California Community College, it is recommended that transfer students take UCB’s Sociology 5 course in their first semester at UC Berkeley. See “Strongly Recommended” section below for more information.


 

STRONGLY RECOMMENDED

Although some California community colleges offer the equivalent of UCB’s Sociology 5 (Evaluation of Evidence), most do not. It is recommended that transfer students take UCB’s Sociology 5 course in their first semester at UC Berkeley unless it is available at their community college.


For a list of California Community Colleges that offer an equivalent course, please visit the Sociology Major Requirements website and review the information available about the UCB Sociology 5, Evaluation of Evidence requirement.

https://sociology.berkeley.edu/major-requirements


Berkeley Sociology offers only one concentration in the major, a Sociology Research Method Concentration. The Concentration requires students to earn a letter grade of B+ or higher in five specific courses, which includes Statistics and Sociology 5. Please note that in order to be eligible for the Research Methods Concentration, only Statistics may be completed at a California Community College. For questions, please contact a Sociology major advisor.

https://sociology.berkeley.edu/research-methods-concentration


Major Preparation

·      Entering transfer students should plan to complete any remaining prerequisites during their first semester at UC Berkeley.

·      Students must maintain a cumulative and major grade point average of a 2.0 or higher. 

·      Sociology 1 or its equivalent must be completed with a letter grade of at least a D- or higher.

·      Sociology 5 or its equivalent must be completed with a letter grade of at least a C- or higher. 

·      Statistics or logic may be completed with a letter grade of D- or higher, or for a “Pass” grade.

·      Students can remain declared in the major while the last of your prerequisites are in progress at UC Berkeley.

·      If you have completed course work that has not been approved toward the Berkeley Sociology requirements listed below, you may retain syllabi and reading lists for evaluation by the department. Contact a major advisor for more information.


NOTE: The Department of Sociology is not involved in the Admissions process. Students should review UC Berkeley Admissions information in order to determine how to become competitively eligible. For more information on admissions requirements to UC Berkeley, visit the Office of Undergraduate Admissions website: http://admissions.berkeley.edu

IMPORTANT information for students applying for admission to L&S for the fall 2025 application cycle and beyond


Completion of Essential Skills requirements (Reading & Composition, Quantitative Reasoning, and Foreign Language) or

Cal-GETC/IGETC will no longer be a requirement for admission; however, completion of either is strongly recommended

prior to enrollment at UC Berkeley to ensure timely degree progress. More information on new polices is available on

the L&S Transfer Student Applicants website. 


By the end of the spring term preceding fall enrollment at Berkeley, you must complete: 


1) The 7-course pattern (as found in the UC Transfer Admission Eligibility Courses Menu in ASSIST):

·   Four transferable college courses chosen from at least two of the following subject areas:

Seven-Course Breadth) requirements from your community college complete the following steps:

Learn more from the UC Berkeley Office of Undergraduate Admission and specifically about transfer admission preparation. 


Review all available majors at UC Berkeley.

PREPARATION FOR TRANSFER AT THE JUNIOR LEVEL


The major is a flexible, interdisciplinary program offering opportunities for both wide, comparative study of South and Southeast Asian cultures, literature, religion, and history. 


Language

Students majoring in South & Southeast Asian Studies must complete two semesters of one of the languages offered by the department at UC Berkeley. The department teaches 14 languages: 


  • Bengali
  • Burmese
  • Filipino
  • Hindi
  • Indonesian
  • Khmer
  • Malaysian
  • Punjabi
  • Sanskrit
  • Tamil
  • Telugu
  • Thai
  • Urdu
  • Vietnamese


Gateway Courses

All majors must complete two of the following four courses at UC Berkeley, and they need to include an A & a B version of the course from this list:

  • SASIAN 100B
  • SASIAN 100A
  • SEASIAN 101A
  • SEASIAN 101B


Prerequisites

Before declaring the major, students are required to successfully (grade C or higher) complete one language course in the department and one Gateway Course.


More Information

The Berkeley Guide and the department website provide more information about major requirements and course information.


Advising:

Students with questions about transferring into the major in South and Southeast Asian Studies are encouraged to contact our undergraduate major advisor(UMA):

Cassandra Dunn

Department Website: https://sseas.berkeley.edu/

Email: cassandrajj@berkeley.edu

Appointments: Schedule an appointment (in-person or remotely).

general_titles: COLLEGE OF COMPUTING, DATA SCIENCE, AND SOCIETY
general_texts:
Statisticians help to design data collection plans, analyze data appropriately and interpret and draw conclusions from those analyses. Berkeley’s Statistics major is especially focused on training students in state-of-the-art methods and preparing them to critically engage with the rapidly evolving and proliferating applications of data analysis in science, industry, government and many other domains. Students in the major can expect to learn the fundamentals of probability theory, statistical reasoning and inferential methods, statistical computing, statistical modeling and its limitations; and will develop skills in description, interpretation and exploratory analysis of data by graphical and other means.


For more information on this major visit:

https://statistics.berkeley.edu/academics/undergrad/prospective


General contact information:

367 Evans Hall (Main Office), UC Berkeley

stat-ugrad@berkeley.edu

(510) 644-5335 or (510) 643-6131

Required Courses for Admission


  • MATH 51 Calculus I
  • MATH 52 Calculus II


One course from:


  • MATH 53 Multivariable Calculus (minimum C)
  • MATH 54 Linear Algebra & Differential Equationsn -or- MATH 56 - Linear Algebra (minimum C)


NOTE: Statistics does not require full equivalence to Math 54 and will accept just the Linear Algebra course of an articulated Math 54-equivalent series.


Highly Recommended Courses


Completing BOTH Math 53 and Math 54/56 prior to transfer can best prepare a student for the Statistics major.


  • MATH 53 Multivariable Calculus (minimum C)
  • MATH 54 Linear Algebra & Differential Equations -or- MATH 56 - Linear Algebra (minimum C).


NOTE: Statistics does not require full equivalence to Math 54 and will accept just the Linear Algebra course of an articulated Math 54-equivalent series.


One course from:


  • STAT 20 Introduction to Probability and Statistics (minimum C)


  • DATA/COMPSCI/INFO/STAT/C8 Foundations of Data Science (minimum C)


  • If no course articulates to STAT 20 or DATA C8, students preparing for the Statistics major may consider taking STAT 2 - Introduction to Statistics.


  • Most California Community Colleges do not offer an equivalent course to STAT 20 or DATA C8. Taking STAT 2 can be helpful in understanding the discipline and can demonstrate an interest in the field.


  • Because STAT 20 and DATA C8 include additional topics such as programming, causality and machine learning, transfer students are still expected to enroll in STAT 20 or DATA C8 during their first semester at Berkeley if they have not taken the equivalent at their community college.



Students must earn a minimum 2.0 Grade Point Average in MATH 51, MATH 52, MATH 53, MATH 54/56 and one from STAT 20 or DATA C8 with no lower than a C in MATH 53, MATH 54/56, and either STAT 20 or DATA C8.

• The Statistics Department defers to the Mathematics Department’s evaluation of course equivalence to the pre-major math requirements.


  • MATH 51 can be satisfied with a score of 3, 4, or 5 on the AP Calculus AB Exam; or a score of 3 or 4 on the AP Calculus BC Exam.


  • MATH 52 can be satisfied with a score of 5 on the AP Calculus BC Exam.


  • See the Mathematics Department guidelines for A-Level and IB Exam scores needed to waive out of MATH 1A and MATH 1B.


  • A score of 3, 4, or 5 on the AP Statistics Exam can satisfy STAT 2. This does not satisfy the lower division Statistics requirement met by STAT 20 or DATA C8 but can demonstrate an interest in the field.

COLLEGE ADMISSION REQUIREMENTS FOR TRANSFER STUDENTS 


THIS MAJOR IS OFFERED BY THE COLLEGE OF COMPUTING, DATA SCIENCE, AND SOCIETY (CDSS) 


Completion of Essential Skills requirements (Computational Reasoning, Human and Social Dynamics of Data

and Technology, Statistical Reasoning, and Reading and Composition) and Cal-GETC/IGETC are not a

requirement for admission; however, completion of both is strongly recommended prior to enrollment at

UC Berkeley to ensure timely degree progress. If course equivalencies are not available at your community college,

you must plan to take these courses at UC Berkeley.


To understand the CDSS College Requirements, including essential skills, visit:

https://cdss.berkeley.edu/academics/college-degree-requirements-and-policies#section-el-degree-requirements-1


By the end of the spring term preceding fall enrollment at Berkeley, you must complete: 


  1. The 7-course pattern (as found in the UC Transfer Admission Eligibility Courses Menu in ASSIST):
  2. Two transferable courses in English composition;
  3. One transferable course in mathematical concepts and quantitative reasoning;
  4. Four transferable college courses chosen from at least two of the following subject areas:
  5. arts and humanities
  6. social and behavioral sciences
  7. physical and biological sciences


AND 


All required courses as noted by your intended major below. 

Only applicants who have completed 100% of all items above will be considered for admission.

Additional completion of highly recommended courses will serve to strengthen the application. 


For more information on admission to UC Berkeley: 

https://admissions.berkeley.edu 


For specific information on transfer admission to UC Berkeley:

https://admissions.berkeley.edu/apply-to-berkeley/transfer-students/transfer-requirements/ 


For more information on majors at UC Berkeley: 

https://undergraduate.catalog.berkeley.edu/

All courses required for admission must be taken for a letter grade. 


For a competitive application all requirements should be completed by the spring term that precedes fall enrollment. If your college does not offer courses articulated with ENV DES 1 and LD ARCH 12, you should find another school that does. Applicants who are unable to complete ENVDES 1 or LDARCH 12 in the spring term that precedes fall enrollment at UC Berkeley may consider completing the course at UC Berkeley in the summer that precedes fall enrollment. See the CED prospective student website for a list of colleges that offer articulated Environmental Design courses: https://ced.berkeley.edu/admissions/undergraduate-admissions/articulation


Before applying, you may also wish to look into taking the mandatory Lower-Division Major Requirements at UC Berkeley during the summer (See http://summer.berkeley.edu) or via University Extension Concurrent Enrollment if class space is available (See https://extension.berkeley.edu/static/studentservices/concurrent/). 


Some students are able to take one or more of the Lower-Division Major Requirements at UC Berkeley via the Intersegmental Cross-Enrollment program, which allows students who meet certain eligibility criteria AND are enrolled at a California community college to enroll in a maximum of one course per academic term at UC Berkeley on a space-available basis, paying community college fees. 

See http://registrar.berkeley.edu/how-to-enroll-in classes/visitor-and-exchange-programs 


Finally, if it is impossible for you to attend a school that offers courses articulated with the mandatory Lower-Division Major Requirements, you may submit comparable courses for evaluation using the "Evaluation of Transfer Coursework: Prospective Students" form under Transfer Credit Evaluation & Curriculum Petition on this page: https://ced.berkeley.edu/advising/forms-documents

GENERAL EDUCATION/BREADTH REQUIREMENTS 


All courses required for admission, including General Education/Breadth requirements, must be taken for a letter grade. 


Course work must be completed by the end of the spring term that precedes fall enrollment at Berkeley. 


Students may use Advanced Placement (AP), A-Level Exams, and International Baccalaureate (IB) coursework to satisfy certain requirements. View our CED Advising website for more information on High School Exam Credit.


The College of Environmental Design (CED) will accept Cal-GETC/IGETC or Reading and Composition plus 7-Course Breadth to satisfy the General Education Requirements. 


Cal-GETC/IGETC certification will fulfill some, but not all, of the lower division admissions requirements for the College of Environmental Design. Students must still complete all of the Lower-Division Major Requirements listed above. 


IMPORTANT: Students applying to the College of Environmental Design should select breadth courses from the following lists with these caveats: 


1. No more than two CED courses (Architecture, Landscape Architecture,

Environmental Design, Urban Studies, and City and Regional Planning) 

may be used to fulfill CED's breadth requirements. 


2. No more than two courses offered by the same department may be used towards 

the seven breadth requirements. 


7 COURSE BREADTH REQUIREMENT 


Take one course from each of the following seven areas: 


ARTS AND LITERATURE: Courses that involve significant engagement with arts, literature, or language (excluding language instruction or the acquisition of technical skills), either through practical engagement with works of art or through the creation of art. (see approved course list below) 


BIOLOGICAL SCIENCE: Take LD ARCH 12 (see approved course list below)


HISTORICAL STUDIES: Most courses in the department of History, and other courses that deal primarily with the human events, institutions, and activities of the past. (see approved course list below) 


INTERNATIONAL STUDIES: An in depth education of political, cultural, artistic and/or socio-economic life centered on both a country or region other than the United States and in the contemporary period. (see approved course list below)


PHILOSOPHY AND VALUES: Most courses in the department of Philosophy, plus courses with a major focus on religion, ethics, legal values, or leading philosophical figures. (see approved course list below) 


PHYSICAL SCIENCE: Take one of the following: 

PHYSICS 7A or PHYSICS 8A. (see approved course list below)


SOCIAL AND BEHAVIORAL SCIENCES: Take one of the following: 

ECON 1 or ECON 2 or ECON C3/ENVECON C1. (Economics 1, 2, C3 or Envecon C1 will also fulfill the Lower-Division Major Requirement) (see approved course list below)


NOTE: A score of 3 or above on the AP Microeconomics or Macroeconomics exam will also satisfy this requirement for the Sustainable Environmental Design major.

This major is offered by the College of Environmental Design (CED). 


The Sustainable Environmental Design (SED) major recognizes that the emergent field of sustainability is growing rapidly in cross-sector activities from product design and manufacturing to governance and social equity. As the world population grows and urbanizes, the planning and design of systems that produce outcomes that are resilient, resource-efficient, healthy and socially just is profoundly important. The College of Environmental Design, with its long-standing, multidisciplinary focus on innovation and social equity is an ideal setting for an undergraduate major in SED, with a strong focus on systems. 


The major offers students a critical understanding of the sustainability challenges facing regions in California and around the globe, and equips them with the technical and analytical tools key to solving sustainability problems that affect people, products and places. Graduates have many career paths and fields of graduate study open to them as a function of the diversity of topics and tools they will encounter and engage in SED. Students who complete this major will:


  • Understand the features and functions of systems that drive sustainability challenges.
  • Analyze the relationships between technological systems, systems of governance, and production systems.  
  • Identify interactions between sustainability, equity and social justice.
  • Use quantitative analysis to understand the potential of sensors and information dashboards to produce innovation in design and management approaches. 
  • Leverage the potential of strategy, policy, business and institutions to adapt to and influence environmental, social and economic trends. 


Studio Instruction in CED


The Sustainable Environmental Design major is not a studio-based major. Students do not have access to Architecture or Landscape Architecture studio courses.


If you are interested in studio experience for your undergraduate degree, consider applying to the Architecture or Landscape Architecture programs in CED. 


MINIMUM ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS FOR ADMISSION 


For information about admission to the Sustainable Environmental Design major in the College of Environmental Design, see CED's prospective student website:

http://ced.berkeley.edu/admissions/undergraduate/transfer-applicants/


-The personal insight questions section on the UC application is important in the selection process at Berkeley. The College reviews the personal insight questions for

evidence of the student's interest in the chosen major and a thoughtful match between the academic program and the student's academic and career objectives. 


-A minimum 3.0 overall UC transferable grade-point average is required for admission consideration.


-All courses required for admission, including breadth requirements, must be taken for a letter grade. 


-For a competitive application course work must be completed by the end of the spring term that precedes fall enrollment at UC Berkeley. 


-As a community college transfer applicant you must complete, at a minimum, course work identified on ASSIST.org as comparable to the UC Berkeley courses below. 


LOWER-DIVISION MAJOR REQUIREMENTS 


1. Environmental Design 1 

a. For a competitive application all requirements should be completed by the spring term that precedes fall enrollment. If your college does not offer courses articulated with Environmental Design 1, you should find another school that does.

b. Applicants who are unable to complete ENVDES 1 in the spring term that precedes fall enrollment at UC Berkeley may consider completing the course at UC Berkeley in the summer that precedes fall enrollment

2. Landscape Architecture 12 (this course will also fulfill CED’s Biological Sciences breadth requirement) 

a. For a competitive application all requirements should be completed by the spring term that precedes fall enrollment. If your college does not offer courses articulated with Landscape Architecture 12, you should find another school that does.

b. Applicants who are unable to complete Landscape Architecture 12 in the spring term that precedes fall enrollment at UC Berkeley may consider completing the course at UC Berkeley in the summer that precedes fall enrollment

3. Math 16A or Math 51

4. Statistics 2, C8, 20, 21 

5. Physics 7A or 8A (this course will also fulfill CED’s Physical Sciences breadth requirement) 

6. Economics 1, 2, C3, or Envecon C1 (this course will also fulfill CED's Social and Behavioral Sciences breadth requirement)


Courses required for the SED major’s LOWER-DIVISION MAJOR REQUIREMENTS may also be used to complete the General Education requirement for admission, this includes CED Breadth or Cal-GETC/IGETC. For questions about Cal-GETC/IGETC certification, check with your community college counselor for more information.


GENERAL EDUCATION/BREADTH REQUIREMENTS 


READING AND COMPOSITION (R&C) 

Reading and Composition A 

Reading and Composition B 


SEVEN-COURSE BREADTH 

Arts & Literature

Biological Science (Landscape Architecture 12 will also fulfill the Lower-Division Major Requirement)

Historical Studies

International Studies 

Philosophy and Values 

Physical Science (Physics 7A or 8A will also fulfill the Lower-Division Major Requirement) 

Social and Behavioral Sciences (Economics 1, 2, C3 or Envecon C1 will also fulfill the Lower-Division Major Requirement) 


You must fulfill all of the required Lower-Division Major and General Education/Breadth Requirements outlined above to be considered for admission. 

If you are using Cal-GETC/IGETC to fulfill CED's College Requirements, you must have full certification. Partial certification will not complete the requirements. Be sure to check with your community college about the procedures involved in certification of Cal-GETC/IGETC. The University will require the official certification by the July 1 deadline. 

If you will not complete Cal-GETC/IGETC certification, you must follow exactly the articulation agreements between your school and the CED Sustainable Environmental Design major as described on this ASSIST.org website. 

Regardless of how you complete the General Education/Breadth Requirements, you must also complete the Lower-Division Major Requirements with articulated courses outlined on ASSIST.org

COLLEGE ADMISSIONS REQUIREMENTS FOR TRANSFER STUDENTS 


THIS MAJOR IS OFFERED BY THE COLLEGE OF LETTERS AND SCIENCE (L&S)


IMPORTANT information for students applying for admission to L&S for the fall 2025 application cycle and beyond


Completion of Essential Skills requirements (Reading & Composition, Quantitative Reasoning, and Foreign Language) or

Cal-GETC/IGETC will no longer be a requirement for admission; however, completion of either is strongly recommended

prior to enrollment at UC Berkeley to ensure timely degree progress. More information on new polices is available on

the L&S Transfer Student Applicants website. 


By the end of the spring term preceding fall enrollment at Berkeley, you must complete: 


1) The 7-course pattern (as found in the UC Transfer Admission Eligibility Courses Menu in ASSIST):

·   Two transferable courses in English composition;

·   One transferable course in mathematical concepts and quantitative reasoning;

·   Four transferable college courses chosen from at least two of the following subject areas:

o arts and humanities

o social and behavioral sciences

o physical and biological sciences


AND


2) Major Requirements: 

Follow the guidance on preparation for this major below. 


For more information on L&S General Education requirements:


For information on courses that will satisfy L&S General Education (Essential Skills and

Seven-Course Breadth) requirements from your community college complete the following steps:

  1. Go to "Search below for articulation agreements: Major, department, and campus-specific general education agreements”
  2. Click on the down arrow to select: Academic Year, Institution: UC Berkeley, and Agreements with Other Institutions: (Your CA Community College). 
  3. Click on “View Agreements”.
  4. Under “View Agreement by” select “General Education/Breadth”. 
  5. Click on the “General Education/Breadth” radio button, then click on “View Agreement”


Learn more from the UC Berkeley Office of Undergraduate Admission and specifically about transfer admission preparation. 


Review all available majors at UC Berkeley.

Within the Theater and Performance Studies curriculum, we engage with performance on physical, intellectual, and aesthetic levels. It is our hope that students will not only grow as performers, but also as artists, thinkers, makers, and viewers of the whole artistic event.


The practical focus of the major is to create theater of all kinds using all its art forms. Whether new to theater or seasoned with years of training and skill, all students receive an education that engages them fully. Your focus may be on acting, technical theater or design, performance studies, or some combination of these. Equally important to us is the study of theater and dance performance theory, history, culture, and literature, thereby balancing the practical with the theoretical. Students engage in other upper division electives in stage management, playwriting, directing, choreography, sound design, scenic design, costume design, or lighting design, as well as a myriad of performance opportunities.


The theater training and academic courses offered by our department are geared toward the student who is interested in learning about theater and performance from multiple perspectives. As either a major or minor in Theater and Performance Studies, you will study with nationally and internationally known faculty, respected for their scholarly research and for their creative work. Our graduates have gone on to professional careers in all theatrical fields and graduate schools all over the world. Our alumni include professional actors on stage and screen, arts journalists, stunt actors, directors, producers, playwrights, and more.


Further departmental opportunities include student-directed theater performances and projects, honors projects, internships in local Bay Area theaters, teaching courses in the department, and invitations to diverse and exciting lectures and performances. Students also have access to world-renowned visiting guest artists through our close relationship with Cal Performances and our extensive network in the field.


For more information:

Laxmi Kumaran

Undergraduate Academic Advisor

Department of Theater, Dance and Performance Studies

15-B Dwinelle Hall (Level C)

laxmik@berkeley.edu

tdps.berkeley.edu

PREPARATION FOR TRANSFER AT THE JUNIOR LEVEL


No audition is required for admission into the College or the major.


Auditions are required for enrollment into acting courses. Students who have not received course credit for an acting class at a previous college must start with auditioning for Fundamentals of Acting I. Students who have received course credit for one acting course may audition for Fundamentals of Acting II. Students who have received course credit fro more than one acting course may audition for Intermediate Acting.


The following lower division Theater and Performance Studies courses are required for the major:


  • 10 Fundamentals of Acting I
  • 60 Introduction to Technical Theater and Production
  • 26 Introduction to Performance Studies
  • 52AC Dance in American Cultures or 25AC The Drama of American Cultures


NOTES:

  • A transferable beginning acting course comparable to THEATER 10 may be used to satisfy a major requirement.
  • Courses comparable to THEATER 25AC, 52AC, and 26 are generally not available at the community college and must be taken at Berkeley.
  • THEATER 25AC/52AC may not be fulfilled by any other American Cultures (AC) course.
  • AP and IB courses do not fulfill major prerequisites.

This major is offered by the College of Environmental Design (CED).


The undergraduate major in Urban Studies introduces students to cities and urban environments as objects of study, analysis, criticism, and planned change and social transformation.


The major has a core in urban studies and planning with courses in city planning and environmental design, and an interdisciplinary curriculum in various urban-related social science fields and disciplines. The flexibility of the program makes it possible for students to pursue individual interests under the guidance of an advisor. Opportunities for more in-depth course work are available in the areas of comparative planning, housing, community development, transportation, and urban political economy.


Students who complete the B.A. degree in Urban Studies may pursue graduate studies in planning and various social science disciplines, or employment opportunities with public agencies, nonprofit organizations, and private firms and service providers.


MINIMUM ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS FOR ADMISSION


For information about admission to the Urban Studies major in the College of Environmental Design, see CED's prospective student website: http://ced.berkeley.edu/admissions/undergraduate/transfer-applicants/


-The personal insight question section on the UC application personal statement is important in the selection process at Berkeley. The College reviews the personal insight questions for evidence of the student's interest in the chosen field and a thoughtful match between the academic program and the student's academic and career objectives.


-A minimum 3.0 overall UC transferable grade-point average is required for admission consideration.


-All courses required for admission, including breadth requirements, must be taken for a letter grade.


-For a competitive application course work must be completed by the end of the spring term that precedes fall enrollment at UC Berkeley.


-As a community college transfer applicant you must complete, at a minimum, course work identified on assist.org as comparable to the UC Berkeley courses below.


LOWER-DIVISION MAJOR REQUIREMENTS


  1. Environmental Design 1
  2. For a competitive application all requirements should be completed by the spring term that precedes fall enrollment. If your college does not offer courses articulated with ENV DES 1, you should find another school that does.
  3. Applicants who are unable to complete ENVDES 1 in the spring term that precedes fall enrollment at UC Berkeley may consider completing the course at UC Berkeley in the summer that precedes fall enrollment
  4. Statistics 2, C8, 20, 21
  5. Economics 1, 2, C3, or Environmental Economics C1 (this course will also fulfill CED's Social and Behavioral Sciences breadth requirement)
  6. For a more competitive application complete the economics requirement by the spring term that precedes fall enrollment at UC Berkeley 
  7. If your articulation includes microeconomics and macroeconomics as separate courses and you cannot complete both by the spring term that precedes fall enrollment at UC Berkeley here are is an alternative option:
  8. complete microeconomics by the spring term that precedes fall enrollment 
  9. complete macroeconomics no later than by the spring term that precedes fall enrollment
  10. Two- Lower-Division Major Electives 
  11. Complete any two from the following four areas - see course lists below
  12. Community Development
  13. Design
  14. Society and Culture
  15. Environmental Resources and Planning


Courses required for the Urban Studies major’s LOWER-DIVISION MAJOR REQUIREMENTS may also be used to complete the General Education requirement for admission, this includes CED Breadth or Cal-GETC/IGETC. For questions about Cal-GETC/IGETC certification, check with your community college counselor for more information.


GENERAL EDUCATION/BREADTH REQUIREMENTS


READING AND COMPOSITION (R&C)

Reading and Composition A

Reading and Composition B


SEVEN-COURSE BREADTH

Arts & Literature

Biological Science

Historical Studies

International Studies

Philosophy and Values

Physical Science

Social and Behavioral Sciences (Economics 1, 2, C3 or Environmental Economics C1 will also fulfill the Lower-Division Major Requirement)


You must fulfill all of the required Lower-Division Major and General Education/Breadth Requirements outlined above to be considered for admission.


If you are using Cal-GETC/IGETC to fulfill CED's College Requirements, you must have full UC certification. Partial certification will not complete the requirements. Be sure to check with your community college about the procedures involved in certification of Cal-GETC/IGETC. The University will require the official certification by the July 1 deadline.


If you will not complete Cal-GETC/IGETC certification, you must follow exactly the articulation agreements between your school and the CED Urban Studies major as described on this ASSIST.org website.


Regardless of how you complete the General Education/Breadth Requirements, you must also complete the Lower-Division Major Requirements with articulated courses outlined on ASSIST.org.


For more information on applying to CED:

College of Environmental Design

250 Bauer Wurster Hall

For more information on admission to UC Berkeley:

https://admissions.berkeley.edu/


For more information on majors at UC Berkeley:
